###### Foncia Management SAS
**€400,000,000 3.375% Senior Secured Notes due 2028**

###### Flamingo Lux II SCA
**€250,000,000 5.000% Senior Notes due 2029**

Foncia Management SAS, a simplified joint stock company (société par actions simplifiée) organized under the laws of France (the “Senior Secured Notes Issuer”), is offering €400 million aggregate principal
amount of its 3.375% Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the “Senior Secured Notes”). Flamingo Lux II SCA, a partnership limited by shares (société en commandite par actions) organized under the laws of
Luxembourg (the “Senior Notes Issuer” and, together with the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the “Issuers”), is offering €250 million aggregate principal amount of its 5.000% Senior Notes due 2029 (the “Senior
Notes” and, together with the Senior Secured Notes, the “Notes”).

The Senior Secured Notes will bear interest at a rate of 3.375% per annum and the Senior Notes will bear interest at a rate of 5.000% per annum. Each Issuer will pay interest on the Notes, as applicable, semiannually in arrear on each of March 31 and September 30, commencing on September 30, 2021. The Senior Secured Notes will mature on March 31, 2028. The Senior Notes will mature on March 31, 2029.

Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Senior Secured Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% plus a “make whole” premium
as described in this Offering Memorandum. Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, no more than 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior
Secured Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price specified in this Offering Memorandum, provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the original aggregate principal
amount of the Senior Secured Notes (including the original principal amount of any additional Senior Secured Notes) remains outstanding immediately thereafter. Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer may also redeem up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (including any additional Senior Secured Notes) in each calendar year at a redemption price
equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. At any time on or after March 31, 2024, the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the Senior Secured Notes at the redemption prices specified in this Offering Memorandum.

Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Notes Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Senior Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% plus a “make whole” premium described in this
Offering Memorandum. Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, no more than 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Notes with the net cash proceeds
from certain equity offerings at the redemption price specified in this Offering Memorandum, provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Notes (including the
original principal amount of any additional Senior Notes) remains outstanding immediately thereafter. At any time on or after March 31, 2024, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the Senior Notes
at the redemption prices specified in this Offering Memorandum.

Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control or upon certain asset sales, the relevant Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase all the outstanding Notes of the applicable series at a
purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof plus any accrued and unpaid interest to the date of the purchase. A change of control, however, will not be deemed to have occurred on one
occasion if, pro forma for such change of control, a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the
relevant Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all of the relevant series of Notes.

In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable series of outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw
such Notes in such tender offer and the applicable Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of such Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, such
Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes of such series that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder
of such Notes.

On the Issue Date and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Issue Date Guarantors (as defined herein)
on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. Within 180 days from (and excluding) the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein) and substantially simultaneously
with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the New Senior Credit Facilities (as defined herein), the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors
(as defined herein) on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively.

On the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees (as defined herein) will be secured on a first priority basis by the Issue Date
Senior Secured Notes Collateral (as defined herein). Within 180 days from (and excluding) the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under
the New Senior Credit Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by the Post-Closing Collateral (as defined herein, and together with
the Issue Date Senior Secured Notes Collateral, the “Senior Secured Notes Collateral”). The Senior Secured Notes Collateral will also secure the New Senior Credit Facilities on a first priority basis. On the
Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Notes and the Senior Notes Guarantees will be secured, on a first or second priority basis, as applicable, by security interests in the Senior Notes
Collateral (as defined herein).

The Notes will be structurally subordinated to all obligations of the relevant Issuers’ subsidiaries that do not guarantee the relevant Notes and effectively subordinated to any existing and future debt of the
relevant Issuers and the Guarantors that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the relevant Notes, as applicable, to the extent of the value of such property and assets. The validity and enforceability
of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor (as defined herein) and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and
_Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances._

The Notes will be in registered form in minimum denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. The Notes will be represented on issue by one or more global notes, which will
be delivered in book-entry form through Euroclear Bank SA/NV (“Euroclear”) and Clearstream Banking S.A. (“Clearstream”) on or about the Issue Date. Interests in each global note will be exchangeable for
the relevant definitive notes only in certain limited circumstances. See “Book-Entry; Delivery and Form.”

There is currently no market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the
Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance, however, that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the
Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Exchange is not a regulated market pursuant to the provisions of Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments, as amended.

**Certain Changes in Accounting Standards and Accounting Policies**

On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on
November 9, 2017. On January 1, 2019, we adopted IFRS 16. We applied IFRS 16 using the cumulative catch
up approach, and the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 16 was recognized as an adjustment to the
opening balance of retained earnings at the date of application, while comparative financial information and our
audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2018 has not been restated and
instead apply IAS 17 and IFRIC 4, which were the equivalent predecessor accounting standard in effect at that
time. IFRS 16 introduces new or amended requirements with respect to lease accounting. It introduces
significant changes to lessee accounting by removing the distinction between operating and finance lease and
requiring the recognition of a right of use asset and a lease liability at commencement for all leases, except for
short term leases and leases of low value assets. In contrast to lessee accounting, the requirements for lessor
accounting have remained largely unchanged. Our Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019
and 2020 exclude €36.0 million and €40.2 million, respectively, of rent costs not incurred as operating expenses
as a result of the application of IFRS 16. Due to the adoption of IFRS 16 and the associated accounting policy
changes applied, our audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019
and 2020 are not directly comparable with our audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year
ended December 31, 2018.

**Other financial measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains non-IFRS measures and ratios, including: Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA Margin, Adjusted Revenue, EBITDA, EBITDA Margin, Operating Cash Flow, Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA,
Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate, Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA,
Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted Revenue and leverage and coverage
ratios that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. We present non-IFRS measures because
we believe that they and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other
interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. The non-IFRS measures may not be
comparable to similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not
be considered in isolation or as a substitute for an analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. For
more information about how we define these non-IFRS measures, see “Summary—Summary Historical
_Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Other Financial_
_and Operating Data—Other financial data.” Non-IFRS measures and ratios are not measurements of our_
performance or liquidity under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Other companies in
our industry may calculate these measures differently and, consequently, our presentation may not be readily
comparable to other companies’ figures. In particular, you should not consider our non-IFRS measures to be
alternatives to (i) profit for the period (as determined in accordance with IFRS) as a measure of our operating
performance, (ii) cash flows from operating, investing and financing activities as a measure of our ability to
meet our cash needs or (iii) any other measures of performance under generally accepted accounting principles.
Non-IFRS measures have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation, or as a
substitute for an analysis of our results as reported under IFRS. Although certain of this data has been extracted
or derived from our consolidated financial statements contained in this Offering Memorandum, this data has not
been audited or reviewed by our independent auditors. In this Offering Memorandum:

“Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as EBITDA before asset disposal, completed acquisition, minority interest and
COVID-19 impacts.

“Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA divided by Adjusted Revenue for the relevant
period.

“Adjusted Revenue” means revenue as adjusted for asset disposals, completed acquisitions, minority interests
and COVID-19 revenue impacts for the relevant periods.

“current capital expenditures” means the funds used to buy, maintain, or improve our fixed assets, including on
information technology, branches refurbishments, excluding the expenditures used in connection with
acquisitions.

“cost of net debt” is calculated as the cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less
financial income from cash investments.


-----

“EBITDA” is defined as net profit before net loss from discontinued operations, Income tax expense, share of
profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies, other financial income and expenses, net income from cash and
cash equivalents, cost of gross debt, non-recurring operating income (expenses) and elimination of net additions
to depreciation, amortization and impairment of assets.

“EBITDA Margin” is calculated as EBITDA divided by revenue for the relevant period.

“Operating Cash Flow” refers Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA adjusted for provisions, change in net working capital,
change in CICE (a tax credit for employment and competitiveness created in 2013 in France) and current capital
expenditures.

“Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA” is calculated as EBITDA adjusted for the pre-IFRS-16 impact on leases at our French
and international premises.

“Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate” is calculated as Operating Cash Flow divided by Pre-IFRS-16
EBITDA for the relevant period.

“Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin” is calculated as EBITDA pre-IFRS-16 divided by revenue for the relevant
period. For the year ended December 31, 2019, for pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin, total revenue was adjusted
for asset disposals.

“Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA” is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA adjusted for the expected EBITDA
impact of closed acquisitions in 2021, acquisitions with signed share purchase agreement expected to close in
the first half of 2021, acquisitions under exclusivity expected to close in the first half of 2021, additional
synergies from acquisitions (from 12 to 18 months), capped transfer fee since June 1, 2020 and Agency of the
Future / Millenium cost and efficiency gains for the relevant periods.

“Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is calculated as Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA divided by
Pro Forma M&A Adjusted Revenue for the relevant period.

“Pro Forma M&A Adjusted Revenue” means Adjusted Revenue as adjusted for the expected revenue impact of
closed acquisitions in 2021, acquisitions with signed share purchase agreement expected to close in the first half
of 2021, acquisitions under exclusivity expected to close in the first half of 2021, additional synergies from
acquisitions (from 12 to 18 months), capped transfer fee since June 1, 2020 and Agency of the Future /
Millenium cost and efficiency gains for the relevant periods.

“Recurring operating profit (loss)” includes all income and expenses directly related to our businesses, with the
exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses).” Recurring operating profit
(loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes
all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items. Costs relating to business
combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss).

For a further description of certain of these non-IFRS measures, see “Summary—Summary Historical Financial
_Information and Other Data.”_

**Overview**

We are the European leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market, providing services to both
individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”). We assist
our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and
comprehensive service offerings. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand
through a unique network of over 500 branches. We also hold leading positions in Switzerland and Germany
and have a strong presence in Belgium and Luxembourg in which we operate under various brands through a
network of over 100 branches.

We have expanded our size and reach through bolt-on acquisitions and completed over 220 acquisitions since
2016. In addition to our successful M&A track record, our recent performance has been marked by
achievements in operations, digitization, and our IT and communications infrastructure. We believe our success
is the result of a unique integrated ecosystem of real estate services, which provides the opportunity for organic
growth via cross-selling of additional services with recurring revenues and external growth through bolt-on
acquisitions.

We operate an integrated business model across a wide range of real estate services and divide our real estate
services into the following businesses:

    - **Residential Real Estate Services (representing 60% of 2020 revenue) consisting of**

        - **Joint Property Management (representing 30% of 2020 revenue) through which we**
are mandated by landlords to manage jointly owned building areas and equipment.

        - **Lease Management and Renting (representing 30% of 2020 revenue) through**
which we manage properties on behalf of landlords and assist landlords and tenants
throughout their rental process.

    - **Real Estate Brokerage (representing 13% of 2020 revenue) through which we assist property**
owners and buyers throughout the real estate sales process.

    - **Ancillary Services (representing 6% of 2020 revenue) through which we provide services that**
are complementary to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, including insurance and
inventories services.

    - **Digital Services (representing 4% of 2020 revenue) through which we operate services**
relying on digital platforms such as online real estate valuation and brokerage.

    - **B2B Services (representing 4% of 2020 revenue) through which we provide real estate**
services to our commercial and institutional customers, as well as adjacent real estate services
such as insurance and diagnostics.

    - **International Services (representing 13% of 2020 revenue) through which we provide the**
full spectrum of real estate services through our international operations in Germany,
Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg.


-----

**Our Strengths**

**_Sector leadership focused on strongest economies in Western Europe providing competitive advantages_**

We have established ourselves as a leader for residential real estate services in France, Switzerland, Germany,
Belgium and Luxembourg by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative services uniquely suited to the
needs of our customers. As of August 2019, we were the number one player in the French real estate services
market, with approximately 13% market share, according to an international report provider. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, we managed approximately 1.8 million dwellings in France, which is approximately two
times the number of dwellings managed by our next closest competitor according to publically available
information for the year ended 2020. Outside of France, we hold leading positions in Switzerland and Germany
and have a strong presence in Belgium and Luxembourg. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we operated
over 100 branches in these countries, which collectively accounted for 13% of our revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2020.

Our scale, operations and service offerings provide us with a clear competitive advantage. Our centralized
processes result in lower internal costs and enable improved customer service compared to our typically small,
individual-owned competitors. Our comprehensive range of innovative services, such as FONCIA 24/7 (our
assistance service for our joint property management customers), Prowen (our centralized energy service that
reduces client costs on gas and electricity), and Assurimo, (our real estate insurance service), differentiate us
from competitors. Our comprehensive network of over 500 branches covering all major French cities is one of
the largest offerings in the market and results in close proximity to our customers and the dwellings that we
manage; unique market positioning in negotiations with third-party repair and maintenance service suppliers
resulting in decreased costs; and financial resources that allow us to expand our customer portfolio through
acquisitions. We have been able to successfully enter markets through acquisitions and expanded our operating
geography, despite the regulatory and technological requirements that create barriers to participation in the real
estate services market. Our regional and national regulatory and real estate industry expertise and our leadership
team’s extensive experience in the real estate services industry are key to meeting and complying with such
requirements. Our strong reputation for quality and service and multi-branded strategy have also supported our
ability to grow in existing markets and enter new markets.

**_Loyal and diverse customer base and synergetic business model in a resilient market_**

Our large and diversified client base, integrated ecosystem of residential real estate services and high customer
retention rates drive a high level of recurring revenues (75% in the year ended December 31, 2020).

We have grown our diversified customer base to approximately 1.5 million dwellings in our French Joint
Property Management business and over 330,000 dwellings in our French Lease Management business as at
December 31, 2020. Through our synergetic business model, we are able to cross sell our services to our
diverse customer portfolio across our business lines, which in turn leads to further organic growth. For
example, our proven ability to cross-sell is highlighted by the high penetration rates of Assurimo, our
specialized property insurance brokerage unit (providing property insurance, homeowners’ insurance policies
and brokerage services) through which we currently provide insurance services to 61% of our French Joint
Property Management buildings. Similarly, we currently provide technical services to approximately 88% of
our Lease Management customers through our dedicated business, Constatimmo. We believe that we are well
positioned to target new customers, including B2B customers, given our knowledge regarding fulfilling
requirements for our B2C customers.

The addressable markets in which we operate are characterized by high outsourcing rates, with a high and stable
portion of joint property or condominium owners (85% in France) under external management, as of August
2019 using services like our Joint Property Management business. Property owners tend to rely on expert
services such as ours due to the volume of work and amount of legal and accounting know-how required to
directly interface with tenants and other counterparties. Moreover, landlords rarely switch leasing managers
during a tenancy, given the risks and costs involved in switching service providers and the limited potential
benefit. We believe that through the integrated ecosystem of high-quality services we consistently provide we
have established high customer retention rates, and long lasting customer relationships, certain of which last
more than 20 years. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we lost only 3.5% and 8.4% of customers from our
Joint Property Management and Lease Management businesses, respectively. Moreover, 36% of our customers
from our Joint Property Management business in France entered into contracts of three or more years and 24%
for two to three years for the year ended December 31, 2020. Due to our broad and diverse customer base, we
are not reliant on any particular customer.


-----

According to an international report provider, the French property management market is estimated to be €12.2
billion in August 2019, of which €5.3 billion is captured by property management companies, with the rest
serviced in-house. The externally serviced property management market has grown by approximately 2%
annually between 2014 and 2019. This stable growth has been driven by population dynamics and the
construction of collective units. We continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow through acquisition of
customer portfolios, cross-selling of related services to our large client base and the addition of new revenue
opportunities for our existing services.

**_Strong and predictable cash flow generation_**

We have a track record of steady cash flow generation, driven by a high level of recurring revenues, which has
enabled us to establish a history of consistent deleveraging. Our trend of improving EBITDA conversion rates
has continued with a Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate, of approximately 76% for the year ended
December 31, 2020, compared to 71% for the year ended December 31, 2019. Despite our regular M&A
activity, our discretionary spend on acquisitions provides us with flexibility to manage our cash flow and reduce
our financial leverage. In addition, from 2016 to 2019, we reduced our total net leverage by approximately 0.6x
on average per year. Further, our business requires limited maintenance capital expenditures, (accounting for
approximately 6% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020), and is characterized by limited working
capital requirements.

Our revenue increased at a CAGR of 5.4% and was €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 up
from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Our margin resilience is supported by an adaptable
cost structure for the more cyclical flow Brokerage business, as Brokerage salary costs include a significant
variable portion that is indexed on commissions. Our Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 26.9%, 26.8% and 22.3%
for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

Our recurring, stable revenue is in part due to our complementary business profiles across our branches,
experienced management and sales force teams, and fee-based services in connection with our Joint Property
Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses which accounted for 69% of our revenue in France
for the year ended December 31, 2020. In addition, our high proportion of recurring revenues (75% in 2020)
and balanced portfolio of services split between stock and flow businesses with limited correlation have
supported our resilience during adverse economic conditions, achieving a substantially stable performance in
2020 despite unprecedented government measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

**_Continuous investments in operational improvement through our innovative technology platforms reinforces_**
**_our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains_**

We continuously invest in cutting edge technology in order to offer the best multi-channel services to our
customers. Since 2017, we have upgraded a significant portion of our IT and communication infrastructure
including utilizing a mix of integrated and outsourced solutions, transitioning to a single telecom provider, and
streamlining our finance and human resources functions with Workday, which enabled us to quickly and
effectively transition to a work-from-home environment during the COVID-19 pandemic. We have also
leveraged our technological know-how combined with our knowledge of the real estate industry to design and
launch a go-live version of our new ERP system, Millenium, which we have piloted at one of our branches in
France in 2020. Millenium integrates all of our IT and resource planning functions into one database to better
meet our customers’ needs and address internal business challenges. Millenium increases the digitization of our
activities with the aim of helping customers by creating greater transparency and improving our operations with
standardized, digital processes to increase efficiency and to improve the speed at which we can serve our
customers. We believe our high levels of investment in IT for our corporate platform and customer interface
service such as over recent years give us a competitive edge in the current environment.

The digitization, standardization and automation offered by Millenium complement our already synergetic
business model and will allow us to more quickly leverage our customer database to identify cross-selling
opportunities leading to greater operating efficiencies and inter-business synergies. We believe that
Millenium’s compatibility with big data, AI and IoT, will allow us to explore new business opportunities and
provide access to a number of revenue-enhancing opportunities. For example, we are developing a new
operational model called “Agency of the Future” which will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real
estate services and aims at improving client satisfaction and reducing our customer churn rate, which we believe
will, in turn, lead to greater opportunities for organic growth. In addition, we believe that the gains of
Millenium and the development of Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in
2022. We have invested in, and will continue to invest in, technology to continually improve our internal


-----

operations in order to provide our customers with product offerings that meet their needs and make us the
number one choice among residential real estate service providers.

**_Consolidation platform with proven track record of executing value accretive acquisitions to drive_**
**_incremental EBITDA growth_**

In addition to our organic growth, we maintain a successful, low-risk strategy of growth through small, bolt-on
acquisitions. We completed 220 acquisitions from January 2016 to December 2020, which represented
approximately €386.0 million of acquired revenues (including gross revenues for Leemo netted for commissions
to agents in our financial accounts). In the year ended December 31, 2020, we made 61 acquisitions in our
primary French market and in other geographies, representing approximately 60,000 new Lease Management
dwellings and approximately 171,000 new Joint Property Management dwellings and approximately €111.0
million of acquired revenues. We completed 61 acquisitions which contributed to our Adjusted EBITDA that
reached €286.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to €258.8 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019. Consolidation is a natural trend in the highly fragmented markets we operate in,
accelerated by increasing regulations, and we play a key role in the market by defining new quality standards
and unrivalled execution processes. We have a strong M&A team, with a disciplined approach that is dedicated
to identifying, diligencing, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions in our five geographical
regions. Our long-standing integration experience, including a dedicated post-acquisition integration team,
enables us to extract full synergy potential from acquired businesses, with both cross-selling and cost synergies.
We have identified a number of potential targets in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg to
continue growing and, importantly, reinforcing our leadership in the market.

**_Highly experienced management team with proven execution capabilities and focus on growth and value_**
**_creation_**

Our management team, led by our Chief Executive Officer, Philippe Salle, have significant experience in the
industry and proven track record of delivering business and revenue growth, executing investment plans, driving
continuous improvement of our European enterprise and generating high returns on capital. Our management
team comes from various industries and geographies and is supported by five heads of region, who have
extensive experience in real estate and enable us to provide our customers with tailored expertise and service.

We believe that the collective industry knowledge and leadership of our management team positions them well
to continue our successful organic and external growth and execute our strategies. Further, our management
team encourages growth through a focus on operational efficiency and innovation including through the
management’s dynamic external growth policy that enabled us to, among others, establish our market leading
presence in Germany, successfully divest our non-core businesses to focus on our core, synergetic businesses
and more recently, by the ongoing overhaul of our IT infrastructure, including the development of Millenium
and enabling our planned transition to our new operational model, “Agency of the Future.” This is
demonstrated by the consistent increase in our revenues which increased at a CAGR of 5.4% and was €961.5
million for the year ended December 31, 2020 (€1,013 million excluding the impact of the COVID-19
pandemic) up from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018.

**Our Strategies**

**_Industry-leading technology to further reinforce our competitive advantage_**

We are committed to providing the best real estate services offerings to our customers by investing in industryleading IT and data platforms, which in turn supports our market share gains. Our most recent digital
innovation, Millenium, an in-house developed ERP system that is device-agnostic, cloud-based and driven by
artificial intelligence, will allow us to fully digitalize all of our businesses and establish a highly personalized
digital relationship with our customers. We believe that Millenium will also allow us to better, more efficiently
serve our customers, cross-sell across our platforms and therefore capture greater market share from existing
customers and generate business from new customers.

Our IT and data platforms are subject to a process of continuous improvement and innovation, which we support
with ongoing investments, such as the team of over 80 developers and specialized professional we hired to
create Millenium. We believe that our robust investments in our IT and data platforms provide us with a
significant competitive advantage, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic when businesses have been
required to transition to a work-from-home environment. Additionally, our ongoing and historical use of big
data, AI and IoT to create new business opportunities enables us to maintain a cutting edge development


-----

program while minimizing the risks traditionally associated with experimentation. For example, we are in the
process of developing our new operational model, Agency of the Future, which we believe will generate
significant savings, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and
back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time
spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain
tasks that were previously done manually, such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges. Since 2018,
we have invested approximately €100 million into our IT projects, and we believe that the gains of Millenium
and Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in 2022.

We have developed, and continue to develop, innovative solutions based on emerging trends that are aimed at
providing our customers with the highest quality, optimal solutions for their real estate needs. We are constantly
looking for ways to improve our offerings and develop new solutions for our customers, which we expect to
drive incremental growth and positively impact our revenue.

**_Continue to drive organic growth and pursue targeted and opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions in core French_**
**_market_**

Our goal is to continue to deliver organic growth in France. We have been successful in achieving incremental
organic revenue growth through active cross selling efforts across our ancillary services. We intend to continue
to benefit from this growth through expanding our service offerings by introducing new business lines. In
addition, we aim to reduce our customer churn rate further by improving client satisfaction, including as a result
of the overhaul of our IT systems.

In addition, we have made, and intend to continue to make, bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market and
the other geographies in which we operate to supplement our organic growth, solidify our current market
position and expand our presence. We have a strong track record of successfully identifying, completing and
integrating opportunistic acquisitions. From January 2016 to December 2020, we completed approximately 220
acquisitions. We believe that our strong brand, broad platform and our dynamic infrastructure have allowed us
to generate growth and operating cash flows through acquisitions. Recent examples of targeted acquisitions in
France that have accelerated our growth and have allowed us to better address customer needs include Gérance
de Passy and LoftOne, in our RRES business, Yxime and Perial in B2B and in the German B2B segment, Paul
Immobilien and SogerTec. We intend to continue to further strengthen our strong position in the market by
pursuing opportunistic acquisitions in our existing geographies to accelerate our growth, and we aim to do so by
leveraging our internal expertise.

We have an M&A team that is dedicated to identifying growth opportunities. Our team deploys a disciplined
and systematic approach and focuses on opportunities that will enhance the offerings and services we provide in
France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg.

**_Continue to grow internationally_**

We have expanded, and plan to continue to expand, our geographic footprint in Europe, organically and through
targeted and opportunistic acquisitions. We intend to leverage our expertise and know-how as well as our
highly localized real estate providers to penetrate European markets where there is an unmet demand and an
opportunity for further expansion, as evidenced by factors such as population dynamics and the construction of
collective units, accompanied by increases in price and service level and a higher degree of outsourcing driven
by regulatory changes. We strategically pursue new markets while remaining committed to expanding in
France, Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg as these markets offer us proximity to existing
customers and expansion opportunities in countries where we have established brand recognition. We also plan
to enter European markets, where we believe local markets have strong fundamentals, such as the United
Kingdom, the Netherlands, Denmark, Scandinavian countries, Austria and various other Eastern European
countries where we aim to become the market leader. Our expertise and solutions are scalable from region to
region, and we believe that as we continue to expand, we can increase market share by deploying practices and
strategies that have proven to be successful in other markets.

**_Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) Leadership_**

We are committed to ESG matters and providing a safe and healthy environment for all of our customers and
employees. Our corporate social responsibility strategy is based on the following key commitments: supporting
sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the well-being of our customers and
our employees and ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. Our


-----

ESG initiatives are also focused on protecting the environment while also ensuring that our operations have
minimal impact on the environment.

We also aim to work with our clients, contractors and suppliers to improve efficiency, conserve natural
resources and reduce waste and emissions. We focus on energy transition of buildings under management by
developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In 2021, we aim
to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects, partner
with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment and reduce our carbon footprint.

**The Transactions**

On the Issue Date, the Issuers will issue the Notes offered hereby and use the proceeds of the Offering, together
with drawings under the New Term Loan Facility:

    - to repay the Existing Senior Facilities,

    - to repay the Existing Revolving Credit Facility,

    - as funds earmarked for identified acquisitions anticipated to close during the first half of 2021,

    - to make a distribution to shareholders, and

    - to pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions.

The estimated sources and uses of the proceeds from the Offering are set forth in “Use of Proceeds.”

The Offering and the application of the proceeds from the Offering, together with the entry by the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer and certain of its subsidiaries into the New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and
application of drawings thereunder, in each case as set forth under “Use of Proceeds,” are collectively referred
to in this Offering Memorandum as the “Transactions.” See also “Description of Other Indebtedness—New
_Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.”_

**The Sponsors**

Founded in 1996, Partners Group is a global private markets investment management firm with USD 109 billion
in assets under management in private equity, private real estate, private infrastructure and private debt as at
December 31, 2020. The firm manages a broad range of customized portfolios for an international clientele of
institutional investors. Partners Group is headquartered in Zug, Switzerland and has offices in Denver, Houston,
New York, Toronto, São Paulo, London, Guernsey, Paris, Luxembourg, Milan, Munich, Dubai, Mumbai,
Singapore, Manila, Shanghai, Seoul, Tokyo and Sydney. The firm employs around 1,500 professionals and is
listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange (symbol: PGHN) with a major ownership by its partners and employees. It
had a market capitalization of CHF 28.7 billion as at February 19, 2021.

In private equity, Partners Group manages assets of USD 52 billion and has on behalf of its clients directly
invested in more than 250 businesses since inception. The investment focus in private equity is on profitable
companies with strong growth potential and value-add opportunities in six industry verticals. Partners Group
pursues a diversified and global relative value approach across geographic regions and industries. Selected
private equity investments include Techem, Rovensa, Ammega, SPi Global, Schleich, Cerba HealthCare, Global
Logic and KinderCare Education.

CDPQ is a long-term institutional investor that manages funds primarily for public and parapublic pension and
insurance plans from the province of Québec, Canada. It receives money on deposit from its clients (known as
“depositors”) and manages these funds while seeking optimal return on investment, in accordance with
depositors’ investment policies. CDPQ is one of Canada’s largest institutional fund managers, with CAD 333
billion in assets as at December 31, 2020. It invests globally in major financial markets, private equity,
infrastructure, real estate and private debt. CDPQ was constituted in 1965 by an act of the Québec National
Assembly.

**Recent Developments**

**_Current Trading_**

Based on our management accounts, we estimate that for the month ended January 31, 2021 compared to the
month ended January 31, 2020, our revenue increased by approximately 7.3%, from approximately €74.7
million for the month ended January 31, 2020 to approximately €80.2 million for the month ended January 31,
2021. We estimate that our reported EBITDA for the month ended January 31, 2021 increased by
approximately 7.8% from approximately €17.1 million for the month ended January 31, 2020 to approximately
€18.5 million for the month ended January 31, 2021. As of January 31, 2021, we estimate that we had cash and
cash equivalents of €63.8 million.

While our operations have remained resilient throughout the COVID-19 pandemic and we are fully operational
across all business areas, we expect some carry-over impact notably as a result of the November 2020 lockdown
in France during which fewer property transactions took place, which will be reflected in our first quarter 2021
financial statements, in line with the customary three month lag between signing of brokerage transactions and
revenue recognition upon closing. This impact is expected to primarily affect the results of our Joint Property
Management (mainly on our additional fees) and Brokerage businesses.

_Joint Property Management_

In the one month ended January 31, 2021, we estimate that our Joint Property Management business revenues
increased by 7% compared to the one month ended January 31, 2020 to €25.3 million. For more information,
see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors
_Affecting Results of Operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.”_

_Brokerage Business_

In the one month ended January 31, 2021, we estimate that our Brokerage business revenues decreased by 3%
compared to the one month ended January 31, 2020 to €9.9 million. This decrease was primarily related to the
November 2020 lockdown in France and due to property viewings being limited as fewer customers purchased,
rented or sold properties. We expect that the impact of the November 2020 lockdown will be reflected in our
2021 financial statements because we recognize revenue in our Brokerage business up to three months following
the signing of a transaction. For more information, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—COVID-19 pandemic_
_impact on our business.”_

**CORPORATE STRUCTURE AND CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS**

The following diagram shows a simplified summary of our corporate and principal financing structure after
giving effect to the Transactions. All entities shown below are 100% owned unless otherwise indicated. The
chart does not include all entities in our group or all of the debt obligations thereof. For a summary of the debt
obligations identified in this diagram, see “Capitalization,” “Description of the Senior Secured Notes,”
“Description of the Senior Notes” and “Description of Other Indebtedness.”

(1) The Senior Notes Issuer is indirectly controlled by funds managed and/or advised by Partners Group and holding together, indirectly,
approximately 92.3% of the shares in the Senior Notes Issuer. The remaining 7.7% equity interests are held directly or indirectly by
certain members of management. See “Principal Shareholders.”

(2) The Senior Notes Issuer will issue €250 million aggregate principal amount of 5.000% Senior Notes due 2029. On the Issue Date, the
Senior Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer and will (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and
future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes; (ii) rank
senior in right of payment to any future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to
the Senior Notes Issuer; (iii) be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer and its
subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Senior Notes, or that secure such indebtedness on a priority
basis (including, with respect to the Shared Collateral, obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes and the New Senior Credit
Facilities Agreement), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness; and (iv) be structurally
subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Senior Notes Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the
Senior Notes, including obligations to trade creditors.

(3) The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will issue €400 million aggregate principal amount of 3.375% Senior Secured Notes due 2028. On
the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and (i) rank pari passu in right
of payment with all of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is not subordinated in right of payment
to the Senior Secured Notes, including any indebtedness under the New Senior Credit Facilities and certain hedging obligations, if any;
(ii) rank senior in right of payment to all of the Senior Secured Note Issuer’s existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the
Senior Secured Notes Issuer, including the Senior Notes; (iii) be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of the
Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries and the Guarantors that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior
Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; and (iv) be structurally subordinated to
any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes,
including obligations to trade creditors.

(4) On or around the Issue Date, we will enter into the New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement. The New Senior Credit Facilities include
the New Revolving Credit Facility, which provides for up to €437.5 million of senior secured credit borrowings and letters of credit
and ancillary facilities, and the New Term Loan Facility in a principal amount of €1,275 million. We expect the New Revolving
Credit Facility to be undrawn on the Issue Date. The New Senior Credit Facilities will be guaranteed by all of the Senior Secured
Notes Guarantors on a senior basis, pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees and senior to the Senior Notes Guarantees.
The New Senior Credit Facilities will be secured by the Senior Secured Notes Collateral on a first-ranking basis, pari passu with the
Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement” and “Summary Historical
_Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data.”_

(5) On the Issue Date and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be
guaranteed by the Issue Date Guarantors on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. On the Issue Date, the Senior


-----

Secured Notes will also be secured on a first priority basis by the Issue Date Senior Secured Notes Collateral and the Senior Notes will
be secured on a first priority basis by an account pledge granted by the Senior Notes Issuer in respect of its material bank accounts and,
on a second priority basis, by the Shared Notes Collateral. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and
the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations
_and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the_
Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances.

(6) Within 180 days from (and excluding) the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with
the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the New Senior Credit Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes
will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. Within 180 days from
(and excluding) the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under
the New Senior Credit Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by the Post-Closing Collateral. The Senior Secured Notes
Collateral will also secure the New Senior Credit Facilities on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes. The Post-Closing
Collateral includes, among other security, pledges over the shares of the Pledged Opcos. The Pledged Opcos do not provide a
guarantee and the share pledge over such Pledged Opco does not constitute a debt obligation of the Pledged Opcos but rather a security
interest in the shares of such entities and, upon enforcement, creditors could take control of the Pledged Opcos and sell the property
and assets of such Pledged Opcos to satisfy their direct obligations and their indirect claims. As Noteholders are not direct creditors of
the Pledged Opcos, the Noteholders’ claims are structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of any Pledged Opcos,
including their obligations to trade creditors. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of
each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and
_Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the_
Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. For the year ended December 31, 2020, the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer, the Guarantors and the Pledged Opcos generated 54.3% of our consolidated EBITDA (and 33.8% excluding
Pledged Opcos). As of December 31, 2020, our subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes had €7.4 million of indebtedness,
excluding accrued interest, bank overdraft and deposits and guarantees received.

(7) The Senior Notes Issuer as lender and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as borrower may enter into a proceeds loan (the “Proceeds
Loan”) for a principal amount equal to the principal amount of the Senior Notes on or about the Issue Date.

(1) Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA is a non-IFRS measure. We define Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA as EBITDA adjusted for the IFRS-16 impact on

leases at our French and international premises and includes IAS 17 adjustments for leasing for vehicles, copy machines and laptops,
and also reflects the impact of certain asset disposals for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019. We adopted IFRS 16 on
January 1, 2019. As a result, we experienced an increase in EBITDA of €40.2 million and €36.0 million for the years ended December
31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, due to rent costs no longer being incurred as operating expenses. Our EBITDA for the year ended
December 31, 2018 is already presented on a pre-IFRS-16 basis. We present Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA as additional information because
we believe it is helpful to investors in facilitating comparability of our results across the periods presented and evaluating the
performance of the underlying business. However, Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and
should not be considered as an alternative to measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS.

(2) Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin and EBITDA Margin is calculated as Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA and EBITDA, respectively, divided by
revenue for the relevant period. For the year ended December 31, 2019, for pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin, total revenue was adjusted
for asset disposals.

(3) EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are non-IFRS measures. We define EBITDA as net profit before net loss from discontinued
operations, Income tax expense, share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies, other financial income and expenses, net income
from cash and cash equivalents, cost of gross debt, non-recurring operating income (expenses) and elimination of net additions to
depreciation, amortization and impairment of assets. We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA before asset disposal, completed
acquisition, minority interest and COVID-19 impacts. We present EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as additional information because
we believe they are helpful to investors in highlighting trends and evaluating the performance of the underlying business. However,
other companies may present EBITDA or Adjusted EBITDA differently than we do and therefore comparability may be limited.
EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are not measures of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative
to net profit as an indicator of our operating performance, profitability, liquidity or any other measures of performance derived in
accordance with IFRS. The following table reconciles net profit (loss) for the period to EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA for the periods

Property Management and disruptions with the postal service, which led to delays in sending invoices and receiving fees in Lease
Management. We also experienced some offsetting effects such as government programs to supplement salaries for employees
who were unable to work as well as a decrease in headquarter costs and performance bonuses.

flow businesses. We calculated the adjustments by assessing our actual performance against our budgeted metrics for these business
lines based on historic performance, while taking into account offsetting effects such as government programs and cost savings, as well

We have not adjusted our EBITDA for the impact of the Brokerage and Lettings business lines, which are our primarily non-recurring
flow businesses. Our Brokerage business line was particularly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic during the first lockdown from
March to May 2020. During this time, we were not able to recognize revenue due to the cessation of notary services, and the closure of
our agencies and the limited ability for people to move led to a reduction in new transactions. As a result of the restrictions imposed
during the second lockdown in France lasting approximately two months from October 30, 2020 (the “second lockdown”), the number
of new transactions was impacted, but not as significantly, and notaries were allowed to work, which enabled us to recognize revenue
during this period. The renting side of our Lease Management and Renting business is a transaction-based business that also
experienced a decline in revenue when the French government largely prohibited people from moving to new properties during the
initial lockdown and, to a lesser extent, during the second lockdown. Constatimmo, which performs diagnostic and inventory reviews,
experienced a similar decrease in revenue as a result of fewer lettings and therefore fewer individuals requiring its services.

For a more detailed description of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business, including the breakdown of lost revenue by
business line, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key factors affecting
_results of operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.”_

at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the target for the full year based on its
historical data and includes the impact of estimated churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to each acquired
company’s integration in our operational model, which are calculated based on the historical churn and cost savings we have
achieved with prior acquisitions. These figures are diligenced in connection with each acquisition and validated by our
operational and regional teams who integrate the target as part of their perimeter and track their performance against budgeted
figures. Most of the acquisitions are integrated within three to six months and are then part of the organic perimeter of the Group.
The types of cost synergies that are recognized in the first year following an acquisition, many of which are recognized on day
one, typically include target management costs if they do not stay with the business, staff costs related to functions such as
headquarters and accounting, advertising costs, non-recurring items such as recruitment fees and subcontracting and accounting
adjustments such as taxes and leases, which we record below EBITDA.

(b) Represents the pro forma impact of potential acquisitions where we have signed share purchase agreements and expect to close in
the first half of 2021, as if such acquisitions had closed at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the
estimated EBITDA of the acquisition for the full year based on its historical data and includes the impact of the estimated churn
and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to the integration in our operational model. These figures are calculated on
the same basis as described in footnote (3)(a) above.

(c) Represents the pro forma impact of potential acquisitions that we have under exclusivity arrangements and expect to close in the
first half of 2021, as if such acquisitions had closed at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated
EBITDA of the acquisition for the full year based on its historical data and includes the impact of the estimated churn and the
full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to the integration in our operational model. These figures are calculated on the same
basis as described in footnote (3)(a) above. Based on our M&A track record since 2016, we have a 95% success rate for closing
an acquisition when we have a transaction under an exclusivity arrangement. However, there can be no guarantee that the same
rate will materialize with respect to future acquisitions. For purposes of determining our Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, we
have only included €7.1 million out of the €12.9 million estimated impact from the total number of acquisitions under exclusivity
which are expected to close in the first half of 2021.

(d) Represents additional further synergies and churn from acquisitions in the 12 to 18 months after the closing date, in addition to

those already considered in pro forma EBITDA figures in the first 12 months. These synergies include cost synergies related to
employee costs, rents, Millenium gains and other costs such as accounting, insurance, IT maintenance and legal costs, travel
expenses and bank fees and revenue synergies related to, for example, insurance implementation, the GLI guarantee and crossselling opportunities between our different divisions. Our synergy estimates are based on a number of assumptions made in
reliance on the information available to us relating to each individual acquisition and our judgments based on such information.
The assumptions used in estimating synergies are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and
competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those contained in the synergy
benefit estimates.

(e) Since June 1, 2020, transfer fees have been capped by the French government at €317 (excluding VAT) per transaction by the

French government. We estimate this will decrease the average transfer fee by €80, which results in a yearly impact of a loss of
€4.8 million on a full-year basis based on an estimated 60,000 transfer fee transactions. In order to offset this €4.8 million
impact, we have set up initiatives to increase the penetration rate of DSP (“Pré Etat Daté”) services in our Joint Property
Management business, which we estimate had a positive full-year impact of €2.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020,
which results in an overall impact of €2.1 million for the year. The adjustment of €875 thousand corresponds to the estimated
negative impact of the decrease in transfer fees and gains from subsequent initiatives in first five months of 2020.

(f) Represents the estimated gains from efficiencies from the Agency of the Future project by 2022, following the deployment of our
new ERP system, Millenium. We are designing a new organizational model named Agency of the Future, which will be
implemented following the roll-out of Millenium in 2022. As a result, we estimate gains, mainly related to (i) staff costs
synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees, an increase in
productivity and reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitalization and
automation of certain tasks previously done manually (such as collection of reminder fees or postal charges). We have quantified
the impact of the plan by (i) identifying potential for productivity improvement, such as analyzing time spent by employees for
their principal tasks in a select number of agencies and identifying potential for improved processes after implementing these
projects, (ii) reinvesting and improving service quality by, for example, defining a goal for the joint property management and
lease management business and the principal tasks of managers and assistants and quantifying the reinvestment necessary in
specific roles in order to put this target organization in place and (iii) scaling of the network resulting from the options for
improvement of processes and required reinvestment. For the year ended December 31, 2020, capital expenditures in connection
with Millenium and Agency of the Future were €17 million. We anticipate capital expenditures of €19 million in the year ended


-----

December 31, 2021 for the development and the deployment of Millenium. By the end of 2022, we estimate approximately €15

these projects. For more information, see “Business—Digital Transformation and IT Systems.” The above information and
