**RISK FACTORS**

_In addition to the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum, you should carefully consider the_
_following risk factors before purchasing the Notes. The risks and uncertainties we describe below are not the_
_only ones we face. Additional risks and uncertainties of which we are not aware or that we currently believe_
_are immaterial may also adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. If any of_
_the possible events described below were to occur, our business, financial condition and results of operations_
_could be materially and adversely affected. If that happens, we may not be able to pay interest or principal on_
_the Notes when due, respectively, and you could lose all or part of your investment. This Offering Memorandum_
_also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ_
_materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including_
_the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

**Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry**

**_The success of our business is significantly related to general economic conditions and, accordingly, our_**
**_business, operations and financial condition could be adversely affected by economic slowdowns, liquidity_**
**_pressure, fiscal or political uncertainty and possible subsequent declines in property sales and leasing_**
**_activities in one or more of the geographies or industry sectors that we serve._**

Periods of economic weakness or recession, rising interest rates, fiscal or political uncertainty, market volatility,
declining employment levels, declining demand for residential or commercial real estate, falling real estate
values, disruption to the global capital or credit markets or the public perception that any of these events may
occur, may negatively affect the performance of our business. In addition, any of these events may have a direct
impact on our ability to collect payments that we are owed under our rent payment guarantee (“Garantie de
_loyers impayés”) and occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation”), which we offer to certain residential_
landlords and lessors, respectively. See “—Low demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or
_tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which_
_may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.”_

Our results of operations are significantly impacted by economic trends, government policies and the real estate
markets in the countries in which we operate. These include the following: overall economic activity, changes
in interest rates, the impact of tax and regulatory policies, the cost and availability of credit and the geopolitical
environment. The performance of our RRES services depends on our ability to collect fixed fees, charge
variable fees for ancillary services, find tenants to bill transaction fees and collect rents. Our Joint Property
Management business model is composed of fixed fees and variable fees related to additional services that could
decline due to adverse economic conditions or administrative restrictions such as pandemic lockdowns.

Additionally, the revenue derived from the Lease Management side of our Lease Management and Renting
business is generally based on a percentage of rent collections from the properties we manage and, with respect
to the renting side of the Lease Management and Renting business, from the one-off fees we receive for each
new lease agreement entered into by our customers. The revenue generated by our business can be affected by
many factors, including: (i) the magnitude of defaults by tenants under their respective leases, which may
increase during distressed economic conditions; (ii) real estate and financial market conditions prevailing
generally and regionally; and (iii) our ability to attract and retain creditworthy tenants, particularly during
economic downturns. If tenants are unable to pay their rents, we are unable to collect the fees that are typically
directly deducted from these rental payments. Adverse economic conditions or political or regulatory
uncertainty could also impact our Brokerage business as it may lead to a decline in property sales and/or a
reduction in sales prices, which in turn could reduce the commissions and fees that we earn in brokering such
transactions. Economic, political and regulatory uncertainty, as well as significant changes and volatility in the
financial markets, business environment and the global landscape, make it increasingly difficult for us to predict
our future financial performance. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
_Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Macroeconomic and market conditions.”_

Following Brexit on January 31, 2020, the UK entered into a transition period which terminated on
December 31, 2020, before which on December 24, 2020, the UK and the European Union agreed to a trade
deal (the “Trade and Cooperation Agreement”) which was ratified by the UK on December 30, 2020 and is still
subject to formal approval by the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union. While it is
difficult to predict the effect of Brexit on the European and global economy, uncertainty regarding new or
modified arrangements between the UK and the European Union could result in additional volatility in the
markets, increased costs and a material adverse effect on consumer behavior. Brexit has created political


-----

uncertainty within the European Union, uncertainty in international financial markets and reduced economic
growth in certain jurisdictions. It is possible that other members of the European monetary union could hold
similar referendums regarding their membership within the Eurozone in the future.

Any of the foregoing risks, if they were to occur, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_The current outbreak of the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19, has caused severe disruptions in the global_**
**_economy and financial markets which could adversely affect our business._**

The global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic has continued to cause significant volatility, uncertainty and
economic disruption. The extent to which the coronavirus pandemic impacts our business, operations and
financial results will depend on numerous evolving factors that we may not be able to accurately predict,
including: the duration and scope of the pandemic; governmental, business and individuals’ actions that have
been and continue to be taken in response to the pandemic; the impact of the pandemic on economic activity and
actions taken in response thereto; the effect on our customers, our customer’s financial position and customer
and tenant demand for, and ability to pay for, our services; our ability to provide our services, including the
impact of travel restrictions and staff working from home; and any closures of our offices and facilities. The
COVID-19 pandemic had several significant effects on our business, including decreased demand for our
services as a result of the slowdown in the European economies in which we operate and our inability to offer
certain services as a result of government lockdown measures. In accordance with the decisions taken by most
European governments in order to comply with social distancing recommendations, all premises (branches and
head offices) were closed to the public during the lockdown period in France, Switzerland, Germany and
Belgium, from approximately mid-March to mid-May 2020 (the “first lockdown”), as well as to employees
(barring exceptional cases). During that period, real estate agents were barred from traveling to sign mandates
or show properties and notaries were closed, which prevented any brokerage transactions from closing. For
further discussion on notary execution, see “Regulation—France—Hoguet.” Moving into new premises during
this period was particularly complicated, as only moves that could not be postponed could be carried out, which
resulted in reduced letting fees for the period. The first lockdown measures imposed on the French, Swiss,
German and Belgian population also negatively impacted our fee collection with an increasing number of
residential and commercial tenants not being able to pay their rent on time or at all, although the rents remained
owed as a matter of law. The lease management market was also affected as we collect a portion of rents via
check, and there were disruptions with postal service, which led to delays in sending and receiving invoices and
fees. For further discussion on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our various businesses, see
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors
_Affecting Results of Operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.”_

The success of our business is significantly related to general economic conditions, and thus the disruption
caused by these factors could further impact some or all of our business divisions. The COVID-19 pandemic is
ongoing, and there is a significant risk of recurring outbreaks in affected countries, and possible future
mutations in the virus may prove difficult to contain. For example, many countries in Europe have reintroduced full or partial lockdowns in late 2020 in order to stem subsequent waves of higher infection rates.
The effects of the COVID-19 pandemic or further lockdown measures could also adversely impact our ability to
deliver our services. We anticipate some continuing impact on our EBITDA and revenue at least through the
first half of 2021, but the impact may be longer lasting and we can offer no assurances as to when or if such
impact will end. Any of these events could cause or exacerbate the risks and uncertainties described herein and
could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We have numerous local, regional and national competitors across all of our businesses and the geographies_**
**_that we serve, and further industry consolidation, fragmentation or innovation could lead to significant_**
**_future competition._**

We compete across a variety of businesses within the residential and commercial property services industry,
including management of jointly owned properties, rental management and lettings, property transaction
intermediation, specialized property insurance brokerage, technical due diligence and inventories and consulting
services for commercial and office properties, business-specific IT services, marketing of properties by blocks
or lots and technical maintenance. Although we are Europe’s leading providers of residential real estate
services, our relative competitive position varies significantly across geographies and businesses. Depending on
the geography, property type or business, we face competition from other residential or commercial real estate
services providers and investment firms, in-house corporate real estate departments, developers, institutional
lenders, insurance companies, investment banking firms, investment managers, accounting firms and consulting


-----

firms. Some of these firms may have greater financial resources allocated to a particular geography, property
type or business than we have allocated to that geography, property type or business. In addition, future changes
in laws could lead to the entry of other new competitors or further consolidation of the industry. For example,
increased regulation following the implementation of the 2014 French access to housing and urban renovation
law, l’accès au logement et un urbanisme rénové (“ALUR law”), and the increasing need to invest in the
digitization of services has led to the increased consolidation of a highly fragmented market. For further
discussion on the ALUR law, see “Regulation—France—ALUR.” Reaching critical scale is important for the
digitization and industrialization of processes in order to reduce costs and improve customer service. Our
industry is highly fragmented among regional, local and boutique providers. Although many of our existing
competitors are local or regional firms that are smaller than we are, some of these competitors are larger or have
a stronger presence on a local or regional basis or in their primary markets. We are further subject to
competition from large national and multinational firms that have similar services to our commercial real estate
business, and it is possible that further consolidation in the residential and commercial real estate industry could
lead to much larger competitors in the geographies, property types and businesses that we serve. In addition,
disruptive innovation by existing or new competitors could alter the competitive landscape in the future and
require us to accurately identify and assess such changes and make timely and effective changes to our strategies
and business model to effectively compete. Further, we also face competition from service providers, who may
have greater knowledge of their home markets, a better understanding of the specificities of regulations and
local legislation and established reputations in their region. There is no assurance that we will be able to
effectively compete, maintain current fee levels or margins, or maintain or increase our market share.

**_Low demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our_**
**_fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our_**
**_business, financial condition or results of operations._**

Low demand for housing generally, or at a particular location due to economic, social or other conditions, may
lead to a lower demand for our services. Moreover, our customers’ tenants could experience a change in their
financial situation at any time, including as a result of global economic events, natural disasters and public
health or pandemic crises. Our customers’ tenants may delay lease commencements, decline to extend or renew
their leases upon expiration, fail to make rental payments when due, or declare bankruptcy. Any of these
actions could result in the termination of the tenants’ leases, or expiration of existing leases without renewal,
and the loss of rental income attributable to the terminated or expired leases. Although a significant portion of
our revenues are derived from “stock” businesses consisting of providing fee-based services to our customer
portfolio, the loss of income by our customers could hinder their ability to pay such fees. Moreover, while our
fees for our Joint Property Management business are expected to be paid by the landlords whether or not the
property is being rented or occupied by the landlord, for our Lease Management and Renting business, our fees
are paid only if the properties are being rented and paid for by the tenants. Therefore, lease terminations may
result in a decrease in fees that we receive. Additionally, even if the lease continues, but the tenant fails to pay
rent, we will not be able to collect our fees because they are automatically deducted from rental payments. We
also are prohibited by law in France from evicting tenants in the winter so the effect of non-payment may be
greater during that time because we will not be able to evict and re-let the property as quickly as during other
times in the year. See “Regulation.” In the event of a tenant default or bankruptcy, we may experience delays
in enforcing our rights and may incur substantial costs in protecting our customers and re-letting their property.
If commercial leases are terminated or defaulted upon, it may be difficult to find a tenant to whom the property
can be re-let.

We also offer a rent payment guarantee (“Garantie de loyers impayés”) to certain residential landlords who have
entrusted us with the management of their property. Under this guarantee, we bear the cost of any unpaid rent
and advance such rent to landlords. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and thus
represent a risk of non-recovery.

We also offer an occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation”) to a small number of lessors to protect against
vacant properties for up to six months if we are unable to find a tenant on selected apartments in new buildings.
As a result, we may bear the cost of any unoccupied properties under this guarantee. For example, the quantity
of unpaid rent typically increases during the winter months when we are prohibited from evicting people under
French law, and thus it is possible that we may experience an increase in loss of revenues if we are unable to
rent such properties. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, our stock increased temporarily as it
built up when we were unable to process disputes and evictions as a result of the first lockdown restrictions. In
this case, the COVID-19 pandemic did not result in a significant increase in unpaid rent or defaults, however,
we cannot ensure that our revenues will not be negatively impacted as a result of future lockdowns or other
COVID-19-related disruptions.


-----

There is no assurance that we will receive payments that we are owed under our rent payment and occupancy
guarantees; therefore, both represent a large source of potential risk. Moreover, the occurrence of any of the
situations described above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of
operations. For information about our guarantee programs, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Rent payment_
_and occupancy guarantees” and “Business—Our Businesses—Residential Real Estate Services (France)—Lease_
_Management and Renting.”_

**_Our ability to grow our business relies significantly upon our acquisition strategy and there can be no_**
**_guarantee that sufficient or appropriate acquisition opportunities will be available to us, that we will be able_**
**_to close any or all acquisitions under purchase agreements, exclusivity arrangements or letters of intent, or_**
**_that financing will be available on acceptable terms._**

A significant component of our growth over time has been generated by acquisitions. We routinely explore
acquiring other businesses and assets, and in the year ended December 31, 2020, we completed 61 acquisitions.
We plan to continue to expand our business externally through similar acquisitions depending in part upon the
continued availability of suitable acquisition candidates at favorable prices and upon advantageous terms and
conditions, which may not be available to us, as well as sufficient funds from our cash on hand, cash flow from
operations, existing debt facilities and additional indebtedness to fund these acquisitions.

The number of acquisitions we pursue largely depends on the quality of the potential target and a key point of
focus during our due diligence on a potential target, and the primary reason we decline to pursue a target after
entering into a letter of intent, is the quality of the target’s client accounting. The success of our acquisition
strategy depends on the ability of our senior management to identify suitable acquisition candidates, to
accurately assess the value, strengths, weaknesses, contingent or other liabilities and potential profitability of
such acquisition candidates, to obtain any necessary permits or approvals from regulatory bodies and to
integrate the operations of such businesses once they are acquired. Our success in making additional
acquisitions depends on the availability of, and competition for, suitable acquisition candidates. Further, we
may be unable to identify or complete promising acquisitions for many reasons, including any misjudgment of
the key elements of an acquisition, quality of client accounting, competition among buyers, the high valuations
of businesses in our industry, the need for regulatory and other approvals, lack of internal resources to actively
pursue all attractive opportunities and availability of capital. Even after entering into a share purchase
agreement, exclusivity agreement or letter of intent, there can be no assurance that such acquisition will close
until such transactions are finalized, which may also impact the Adjusted EBITDA presented in this Offering
Memorandum. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We present information
_relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma_
_Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum;_
_certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and_
_judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.”_

When we do identify and complete acquisitions, we may face financial, managerial and operational challenges,
including diversion of management attention and resources needed for existing operations, difficulty with
integrating acquired businesses, acquiring businesses that are not consistent with our long-term strategies,
integration of different corporate cultures, increased expenses, potential dilution of our brand, assumption of
unknown liabilities, indemnities, potential disputes with the sellers and the need to evaluate the financial
systems of and establish internal controls for acquired entities.

We have historically financed acquisitions through a variety of sources, including our own cash reserves and
debt financing. While we intend to continue to finance acquisitions from these sources in the future, we may
have insufficient cash reserves to fund acquisitions, and adverse market conditions or other factors may prevent
us from obtaining debt finance on acceptable terms or at all. If we are unable to implement our acquisition
strategy, obtain sufficient financing or integrate acquired businesses successfully, our business and prospects for
growth could be negatively affected. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
_Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Acquisitions_
_and disposals.”_


-----

Given the various risks to which we are exposed and the uncertainties inherent in our business, we cannot
guarantee the successful implementation of our acquisition strategies. Additionally, our strategies may put
operational strain on our business and consume management time and focus to the detriment of our existing
business operations. If we do not meet our strategic objectives or achieve the results initially expected, we may
be unable to recover our investment or this may otherwise have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition or results of operations. We may not realize the expected benefit of our past or future
acquisitions or we may face unforeseen costs or liabilities. In the past, we have grown through a combination of
organic development and bolt-on acquisitions, and we intend to continue this combination in the future. Growth
through acquisitions entails certain risks, including the risk of a failure to realize the expected benefits of the
acquisitions and incurrence of unexpected risks and obligations.

Our ability to realize the benefits we anticipate from our acquisition activities, including any anticipated sales
growth, cost synergies and other anticipated benefits, will depend in large part upon whether we are able to
integrate such businesses efficiently and effectively. Integration is an ongoing process, and we may not be able
to fully integrate such businesses smoothly or successfully, and the process may take longer than expected.
Successful integration of acquired businesses will also depend on our ability to effect any required changes in
operations or personnel and may require capital expenditures or the funding of unforeseen liabilities. The
integration and operation of any future acquisitions may expose us to certain risks, including the following:
liability related to the mishandling of customer cash accounts; difficulty in integrating the acquired businesses in
a cost-effective manner, including the full integration of the acquired business account management into our IT
system, management information and financial control systems; unforeseen legal, regulatory, contractual, labor
or other issues arising out of the acquisitions; significant unexpected liabilities or contingencies arising from the
acquisitions; potential disruptions to our ongoing business caused by our senior management’s focus on the
acquired companies; and post-acquisition performance not meeting our expectations or plans. We are required
to have separate customer accounts in our Joint Property Management business, and if a target has poor
customer accounting policies, it could lead to difficulties collecting customer balances or complying with
applicable law. There can be no assurance that our future acquisitions will be made on appropriate terms or at
an acceptable cost or can be successfully integrated with the rest of our businesses. A failure to identify
appropriate acquisitions could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of
operations.

Our failure to realize the expected benefits or synergies of past or future acquisitions could result in the lack of
implementation and achievement of our growth strategy may prevent us from obtaining the advantages that the
acquisitions were intended to create, or could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition
or results of operations.

**_A failure to appropriately address actual or perceived conflicts of interest could adversely affect our_**
**_businesses._**

Our company has different businesses and a broad customer base and is therefore subject to numerous potential,
actual or perceived conflicts of interests in the provision of services to our existing and potential customers. For
example, conflicts may arise from our position as broker to both landlords and tenants in residential real estate
lease transactions or our Brokerage business could have inside information about a property or the property
owner’s circumstances relative to other brokers as a result of our managing that property through our RRES
business. In certain cases, we are also subject to fiduciary obligations to our customers. We have adopted
various policies, controls and procedures to monitor, address and limit actual or perceived conflicts, such as an
officer in charge of our risk management team, anti-bribery software, a whistleblower hotline and data
compliance procedures, but these policies and procedures may not be adequate or may not be adhered to by our
employees.

Appropriately dealing with conflicts of interest is complex and difficult, and our reputation could be damaged
and cause us to lose existing customers or fail to gain new customers if we fail, or appear to fail, to identify,
disclose and appropriately address potential conflicts of interest or fiduciary obligations, which could have an
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, it is possible that in
some jurisdictions, regulations could be changed to limit our ability to act for parties where conflicts exist even
with informed consent, which could limit our market share in those markets. We cannot guarantee that future
conflicts of interest will not cause material harm to us.

**_We are subject to various risks related to managing large numbers of residential properties, and our failure_**
**_to effectively perform property management functions or to effectively manage our portfolio and operations_**
**_could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations._**

As of December 31, 2020, we managed approximately 48,000 buildings and approximately 1.5 million
dwellings in France under our Joint Property Management business and approximately 330,000 dwellings in
France under our Lease Management and Renting business. It may be difficult for us or our agents (including
real estate brokers and subcontractors hired by other third parties we engage) to regularly inspect such properties
and manage the maintenance and upkeep on behalf of our customers and to ensure compliance with regulatory
requirements. Additionally, we may find it difficult to manage tenants if they encounter difficulties with the
properties they rent. For example, although there are certain basic necessities that must function properly, such
as heat or water, we cannot force a landlord to comply with all tenant requests if they are not mandated by law.
Therefore, a tenant may have an unfavorable view of us as property manager for unresolved requests that the
landlord will not approve or if they are unhappy with the quality of work commissioned by the landlord, which
can present a risk to our reputation. The occurrence of any such development could have a material adverse
effect on our reputation, business, financial condition or results of operations.

Our ability to perform the property management services will be affected by various factors, including, among
other things, engaging the appropriate subcontractors, maintaining sufficient personnel and retaining key
personnel at the number of our properties that we manage under our Lease Management and Renting and Joint
Property Management businesses. No assurance can be made that we will continue to be successful in attracting
and retaining skilled personnel, in integrating any new personnel into our organization or in engaging with the
appropriate subcontractors at reasonable costs.

Our future success will depend, in part, upon our ability to successfully monitor our operations, costs, regulatory
compliance and service quality and maintain other necessary internal controls. Our inability to effectively
perform the property management services on the properties managed by us as part of our Lease Management
and Renting and Joint Property Management businesses, or to effectively manage our portfolio and operations,
could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.

**_We may not realize any or all of our estimated cost savings, gains and synergies, which would have a negative_**
**_effect on our results of operations._**

In the past, we have grown through a combination of organic development and significant bolt-on acquisitions,
and we intend to continue this combination in the future. Any cost savings, gains and synergies that we realize
from these bolt-on acquisitions may differ materially from our estimates. The estimates contained herein are our
current estimates, but they involve risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that may cause our actual
results, performance or achievements to be materially different from any future results, performance or
achievements expressed or implied by such estimates. Our ability to realize the expected cost savings, gains and
synergies associated with the adjustments included when calculating Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA and other non–IFRS financial measures depends on factors beyond our control, such as operating
difficulties, increased operating costs, competitors and customers, delays in implementing initiatives and general
economic or industry conditions. We may be required to make cash expenditures to achieve such cost savings,
gains and synergies, and these costs are not reflected in Adjusted EBITDA or Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA.
We cannot assure you that these cash expenditures to achieve such cost savings, gains and synergies will not be
higher than we anticipated. In addition, we may not fully realize such cost savings, gains and synergies within
12 months of the completion of the respective acquisitions, and may not do so at all. Further, our churn rate in
respect of the bolt-on acquisitions may be higher than expected. Accordingly, you should not view our
presentation of this adjustment in our Adjusted EBITDA or Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as a projection that
we will achieve these cost savings or gains. Our ability to realize these anticipated gains and synergies is
subject to significant uncertainties and you should not place undue reliance on the adjustments in evaluating our
anticipated results.

In addition, any cost savings, gains and synergies that we realize may be offset, in whole or in part, by
reductions in revenues, or through increases in other expenses, including as a result of the actions we take. For
example, reducing sales, marketing and customer support could result in lower revenue and could lead to
disruption of our operations, loss of or inability to recruit key personnel, decline in employee productivity,
weakening of internal standards, controls or procedures, and impairment of key customer and supplier
relationships. Further, no third party, including our independent auditors or any of the initial purchasers, has
performed any assurance procedures or expressed an opinion with respect to these estimated cost savings or
gains, or their respective achievability. As a result, our future performance may differ significantly from the pro

**_We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted_**
**_EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this_**
**_Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved_**
**_certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them._**

The Offering Memorandum includes certain statements and figures relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
Margin and other non-IFRS measures. Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA and other metrics calculated using
Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA include estimated results of acquired businesses assuming such
acquisitions were made at the beginning of the period presented. We calculated such figures using third-party
quality of earnings assessments and the information and records available from the acquired businesses, which
in certain instances was based on unaudited financial information or management schedules and therefore
required significant assumptions and estimates, may not be up to date or may not be prepared on the same basis
on which we prepare our accounts. While these figures are based upon the latest available financial information
from the acquired business at the time we built each business case, actual figures may differ. Moreover, we can
offer no assurances that any anticipated acquisitions will close or that we will recognized our estimated cost
savings or efficiency gains. In addition, Pro Forma Revenues, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma M&A
Adjusted EBITDA also gives effect to the impact that the COVID–19 pandemic had on our business in the year
ended December 31, 2020. This adjustment is for illustrative purposes only. While we believe these estimates
and assumptions to be reasonable, some or all of this information may prove to be inaccurate or incomplete. As
a result, you should not unduly rely on such information in making an investment in the Notes. See also “Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our ability to grow our business relies significantly_
_upon our acquisition strategy and there can be no guarantee that sufficient or appropriate acquisition_
_opportunities will be available to us, that we will be able to close any or all acquisitions under purchase_
_agreements, exclusivity arrangements or letters of intent, or that financing will be available on acceptable_
_terms.”_

**_We may be unable to effectively manage our growth into new geographies._**

Our growth plan includes expansion into new or recently entered regions, particularly in Europe. Expanding
into these geographies involves significant expenditures, over a period of several years, hiring and training of
personnel, and marketing efforts to introduce our brand to the new geography. We may not accurately predict
such costs or accurately anticipate operational difficulties caused by local conditions, and therefore may not
achieve our financial and strategic objectives for our operations in the new geographies. Accordingly, we may
incur losses as we expand our operations. Some examples of the risks encountered in entering new regions
include:

    - increased investment associated with understanding new geographies and following trends in
these areas in order to effectively compete;

    - increased costs associated with adapting our products and services to different requirements in
the local markets areas, which may decrease our margins and profitability;

    - challenges relating to developing and maintaining appropriate understanding and complying
with new regulatory schemes;

    - reduced ability to predict our performance because we will have less experience in the new
geographies than in our existing geographies; and

    - political, regulatory and other local risks.

To the extent we are not able to effectively manage our growth into new geographies, our financial results could
be adversely impacted.

**_Our brands and our reputation are key assets of our company, which will be affected by how we are perceived_**
**_in the marketplace._**

Our brands and their respective attributes are key assets, and we believe our continued success depends on our
ability to preserve, grow and leverage the value of our brands. Our ability to attract and retain customers is
highly dependent upon the external perceptions of our level of service, trustworthiness, business practices,
management, workplace culture, financial condition, our response to unexpected events and other subjective
qualities. Negative perceptions or publicity regarding these matters, even if related to seemingly isolated
incidents and whether or not factually correct, could erode trust and confidence and damage our reputation
among existing and potential customers, which could make it difficult for us to attract new customers and
maintain existing ones. Negative public opinion could result from actual or alleged conduct in any number of
activities or circumstances, including the personal conduct of individuals associated with our brand, the
handling of customer complaints, regulatory compliance, such as compliance with anti-bribery, anti-money
laundering and corruption laws, the use and protection of customer and other sensitive information, and actions
taken by regulators or others in response to such conduct. Social media channels can also cause rapid,
widespread reputational harm to our brand.

Our portfolio of brands and our reputation may also be harmed by actions taken by third parties that are outside
of our control. For example, any shortcoming of or controversy related to third-party providers, landlords or
property owners may be attributed to us, thus damaging our reputation and the value of the affected brand and
increasing the attractiveness of our competitors’ services. Also, business decisions or other actions or omissions
of our shareholders or management may adversely affect the value of our investments, result in litigation or
regulatory action against us, and otherwise damage our reputation and brands. Adverse developments with
respect to our industry may also, by association, negatively impact our reputation or result in greater regulatory
or legislative scrutiny or litigation against us.

The protection of our brand, including related trademarks, may require the expenditure of significant financial
and operational resources. Moreover, the steps we take to protect our portfolio of brands may not adequately
protect our rights or prevent third parties from infringing or misappropriating our trademarks. Even when we
detect infringement or misappropriation of our trademarks, we may not be able to enforce all such trademarks.
Any unauthorized use by third parties of any of our brands may adversely affect our brands. Furthermore, as we
continue to expand our business, especially internationally, there is a risk we may face claims of infringement or
other alleged violations of third-party intellectual property rights, which may restrict us from leveraging our
brands in a manner consistent with our business goals.

**_Failure to maintain and execute information technology strategies and ensure that our employees adapt to_**
**_changes in technology could materially and adversely affect our ability to remain competitive in the market._**

Our business relies heavily on information technology, including on solutions provided by third parties, to
deliver services that meet the needs of our customers. If we are unable to effectively execute and maintain our
information technology strategies or adopt new technologies and processes relevant to our service platform, our
ability to deliver high-quality services may be materially impaired. In addition, we make significant
investments in new systems and tools to achieve competitive advantages and efficiencies. For example, we are
in the process of rolling out Millenium, our new ERP system designed to digitize many of our services and lead
to operational improvements. Implementation of such investments in information technology could exceed
estimated budgets, and we may experience challenges that prevent new strategies or technologies from being
realized according to anticipated schedules. If we are unable to maintain current information technology and
processes, or encounter delays, or fail to exploit new technologies, the execution of our business plans may be
disrupted. Similarly, our employees require effective tools and techniques to perform functions integral to our
business. Our payroll and compensation technology systems are important to ensuring that key personnel are
compensated accurately and on a timely basis. Failure to pay professionals the compensation they are due in a
timely manner could result in higher attrition. Failure to successfully provide such tools and systems, or ensure
that employees have properly adopted them, could materially and adversely impact our ability to achieve
positive business outcomes.

**_Any failure by us to successfully execute on our strategy to achieve for operational efficiency successfully_**
**_could result in total costs and expenses that are greater than expected._**

We have an operating framework that includes a disciplined focus on operational efficiency. As part of this
framework, we have adopted several initiatives, including development of our operational models including
“Agency of the Future” and Millenium, our new ERP system in development, workflow processes and systems


-----

to improve client engagement and outcomes across our service lines. Our ability to continue to achieve the
anticipated cost savings. gains and other benefits from these initiatives within the expected time frame is subject
to many estimates and assumptions. These estimates and assumptions are subject to significant economic,
competitive and other uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control. In addition, we are vulnerable to
increased risks associated with implementing changes to our tools, processes and systems given our varied
service lines, the geographic regions in which we and our customers operate and the number of acquisitions that
we have completed in recent years. If these estimates and assumptions are incorrect, if we are unsuccessful at
implementing changes, if we experience delays, or if other unforeseen events occur, we may not achieve or
continue to achieve new operational efficiencies and as a result our business and results of operations could be
adversely affected.

**_We rely on key relationships with third-party providers to conduct our business._**

We rely on key relationships with third parties such as law firms, real estate brokers, administrative agencies,
notaries, postal services, technical contractors and our customer’s bank branches to conduct our business. If we
are unable to find and maintain reliable service providers, any failure by these third parties to adequately
perform certain services for us or the loss of these relationships could materially impair our business operations,
and reduce our cash flow, income and profitability. For example, the halting of notary activities in connection
with the first lockdown directly affected our brokerage activities. While our contracts with certain third parties
may provide for indemnification to cover damages resulting from failure to perform their obligations
satisfactorily, such indemnification may not fully cover our financial losses in attempting to mitigate their
failures or our losses to other parties or may not be received in a timely manner or at all.

**_We are subject to various litigation risks and may face financial liabilities and/or damage to our reputation as_**
**_a result of litigation._**

We are exposed to various litigation risks and from time to time are party to various legal proceedings that
involve claims for substantial amounts of money. We depend on our business relationships and our reputation
to attract and retain customers. As a result, allegations against us, irrespective of the ultimate outcome of such
allegations, may harm our professional reputation and as such materially damage our business and its prospects,
in addition to any financial impact.

As a licensed real estate broker and provider of commercial and residential real estate services, we, and our
licensed professionals and independent contractors, are subject to statutory due diligence, disclosure and
standard-of-care obligations. Failure to fulfill these obligations could subject us, our sales professionals or
independent contractors to litigation from parties who purchased, sold or leased properties that we brokered or
managed in the jurisdictions in which we operate.

We are subject to claims by participants in real estate sales and leasing transactions, including French
associations representing tenants, as well as building owners and companies for whom we provide management
services, who claim that we did not fulfill our obligations, or by customers for whom we provided appraisal and
valuation services and/or third parties who perceive themselves as having been negatively affected by our
appraisals and/or valuations. These consumer organizations representing tenants are able to organize class
actions in the real estate services market, which has been introduced by the French Hamon law, and file lawsuits
on behalf of tenants. For example, we are currently involved in claims against us for alleged losses brought on
behalf of lessees related to over charges for receiving notices to pay. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.” We
could be subject to claims following the acquisition of a business or subject to audits and/or fines from various
local real estate authorities or regulatory agencies if they determine that we are violating licensing laws or
failing to follow certain laws, rules and regulations.

In our residential property management business, we hire and supervise third-party contractors to provide
services for our managed properties. We may be subject to claims for defects, negligent performance of work or
other similar actions or omissions by third parties we do not control. Moreover, our customers may seek to hold
us accountable for the actions of contractors because of our role as property or facilities manager or project
manager, even if we have technically disclaimed liability as a contractual matter, in which case we may be
pressured to participate in a financial settlement for purposes of preserving the customer relationship.

We engage with subcontractors to provide a large number of building staff in facilities that we manage, and as a
result, we face the risk of potential claims from such staff, such subcontractors.


-----

We also face employment-related claims as an employer with respect to our corporate and other employees, for
which we would bear ultimate responsibility in the event of an adverse outcome in such matters. We also face
claims related to our franchisees, with respect to the termination of our franchise agreements and other claims
which may arise related to such agreements.

Adverse outcomes of property and facilities management disputes and related or other litigation could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects, particularly to
the extent we may be liable on our contracts, or if our liabilities exceed the amounts of the insurance coverage
procured and maintained by us. Further, we face the risk of claims of illness or injury relating to premise
liability given that we lease, manage and sell properties to our customers. Some of these litigation risks may be
mitigated by the commercial insurance policies we maintain. However, in the event of a substantial loss or
certain types of claims, our insurance coverage and/or self-insurance reserve levels might not be sufficient to
pay the full damages.

Additionally, in the event of grossly negligent or intentionally wrongful conduct, insurance policies that we may
have may not cover us at all. Further, the value of otherwise valid claims held under insurance policies could
become uncollectible in the event of the covering insurance company’s insolvency, although we seek to limit
this risk by placing our commercial insurance only with highly rated companies. Any of these events could
materially negatively impact our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Finally, we are also subject, from time to time, to tax audits and challenges from relevant tax authorities. In this
respect, two entities of the Foncia Group are currently undergoing tax audits run by the French tax authorities in
respect of fiscal years 2016 to 2018 and 2016 to 2019 respectively. If any such challenges are made and are not
resolved in our favor, they could result in a decrease of our tax losses as well as additional tax liabilities and
thus have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.

**_Adverse developments in the credit markets may harm our business, results of operations and financial_**
**_condition._**

Our business is sensitive to credit cost and availability as well as marketplace liquidity. Additionally, the
revenue in all of our businesses is dependent to some extent on the overall volume of activity and pricing in the
residential real estate market.

Disruptions in the credit markets may adversely affect our advisory services to investors, owners and tenants of
real estate in connection with the leasing, disposition and acquisition of property. If our customers are unable to
procure credit on favorable terms, there may be fewer completed leasing transactions, dispositions and
acquisitions of property. In addition, if purchasers of commercial real estate are not able to obtain favorable
financing, resulting in the lack of disposition and acquisition opportunities for our projects, our business may be
unable to generate incentive fees.

**_Interruption or failure of our information technology, communications systems or data services could impair_**
**_our ability to provide our services effectively, which could damage our reputation and materially harm our_**
**_operating results._**

Our business requires the continued operation of information technology and communication systems and
network infrastructure. Our ability to conduct our global business may be materially adversely affected by
disruptions to these systems or infrastructure. Our information technology and communications systems are
vulnerable to damage or disruption from fire, power loss, telecommunications failure, system malfunctions,
computer viruses, cyber attacks, natural disasters such as hurricanes, earthquakes and floods, acts of war or
terrorism, employee errors or malfeasance, or other events which are beyond our control. With respect to
cyberattacks and viruses, these pose growing threats to many companies, and we may be a target of such threats,
which could expose us to liability, reputational harm and significant remediation costs and cause material harm
to our business and financial results. In addition, the operation and maintenance of our systems and networks is,
in some cases, dependent on third-party technologies, systems and services providers for which there is no
certainty of uninterrupted availability. Any of these events could cause system interruption, delays and loss,
corruption or exposure of critical data or intellectual property or disruption of our ability to provide services to
or interact with our customers, contractors and vendors, and we may not be able to successfully implement
contingency plans that depend on communication or travel. We could also face difficulties in bringing the IT
systems of the companies that we acquire up to the standard of our standard security procedures and protections,
which could lead to interruptions or failures of our information systems.


-----

Furthermore, any such event could result in substantial recovery and remediation costs and liability to
customers, business partners and other third parties. We have business continuity and disaster recovery plans
and backup systems to reduce the potentially adverse effect of such events, but our disaster recovery planning
may not be sufficient and cannot account for all eventualities, and a catastrophic event that results in the
destruction or disruption of any of our data centers, our critical business or information technology systems
could severely affect our ability to conduct normal business operations, and as a result, our future operating
results could be materially adversely affected.

Our business relies heavily on the use of software and residential real estate data, some of which is purchased or
licensed from third-party providers for which there is no certainty of uninterrupted availability. A disruption of
our ability to access such software, including an inability to renew such licenses on the same or similar terms, or
provide data to our professionals and/or our customers, contractors and vendors or an inadvertent exposure of
proprietary data could damage our reputation and competitive position, and our operating results could be
adversely affected.

**_A material breach in security relating to our information systems could adversely affect us._**

In the ordinary course of our business, we collect and store sensitive data in our data centers and on our
networks, including our proprietary business information and intellectual property, our customers’ sensitive data
and personally identifiable information of our tenants, employees, contractors and vendors. The secure
processing, maintenance and transmission of this information is critical to our operations.

Security breaches and other disruptions of our information and technology networks could compromise our
information and intellectual property and expose us to liability, reputational harm and significant remediation
costs, which could cause material harm to our business and financial results. Unauthorized disclosure,
modification or loss of confidential, personally identifiable or sensitive data or other operational failures may
occur through a variety of methods. These include, but are not limited to, systems failures, in-house employee
negligence, fraud or misappropriation, or unauthorized access to or through our information systems, whether by
our in-house employees, vendors or third parties, or a cyber-attack by hackers, members of organized crime
and/or state-sponsored organizations. Information security risks have generally increased in recent years, in part
because of the proliferation of new technologies and the use of the internet, and the increased sophistication and
activity of organized crime, hackers, terrorists, activists, cybercriminals and other external parties, some of
which may be linked to terrorist organizations or hostile foreign governments. Cybersecurity attacks are
becoming more sophisticated and include malicious software, phishing and spear phishing attacks, wire fraud
and payment diversion, account and email takeover attacks, ransomware, attempts to gain unauthorized access
to data and other electronic security breaches. Cybersecurity attacks, including attacks that are not ultimately
successful, could lead to disruptions in our critical systems, unauthorized release of confidential or otherwise
protected information or corruption of our data, and could also substantially damage our reputation. We have
experienced cybersecurity attacks in the past, including ransomware attacks by cybercriminals, and we expect
we may experience additional attacks in the future. Cybersecurity attacks like the ones we have experienced in
the past could have a substantial impact on our reputation with our customers, and stakeholders, and may have a
material adverse effect on our business.

An incident involving disclosure, data modification, loss or security breach or a significant technical failure
could subject us to significant monetary damages or losses, litigation, negative publicity, regulatory enforcement
actions, and liability under our contracts, resulting in increased costs or loss of revenue. Any person who
circumvents our security measures could steal proprietary or confidential customer information or cause
interruptions in our operations that could cause us to be unable to provide our services or operate our business,
which could damage our reputation. We incur significant costs to protect against security breaches and other
cybersecurity attacks and may incur significant additional costs to address issues caused by any such breaches or
cybersecurity attacks. Our failure to prevent future security breaches or cybersecurity attacks, or wellpublicized security breaches affecting the internet in general, could significantly harm our reputation and
business and financial results.

**_Regulations related to a material breach in data security could adversely affect us._**

Certain laws, regulations and standards regarding data security affecting our customers impose requirements
regarding the security of information maintained by these customers, as well as notifications to persons whose
personal information is accessed by an unauthorized third party. Certain laws may also require us to protect the
security of our employees’ personal data. In particular, we are subject to the stringent requirements of the EU’s
General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”), violation of which carries substantial fines and grants individual


-----

data subjects the right to claim damages for rights violations. In addition, in connection with the processing of
personal data, we are also subject to French law No. 78-17 of January 6, 1978 on information technology, data
files and civil liberties as amended, which incorporates the provisions of the GDPR. A public authority, the
French Data Protection Authority (Commission Nationale de l’informatique et des Libertés) (“CNIL”), is
responsible for ensuring compliance with data protection regulations in France.

We cannot ensure that the confidentiality of such data and information will not be breached as a result of
cybersecurity attacks or otherwise, or that doubts may not arise regarding the security of the data and
information collected and managed by us. As a result of any continuing legislative initiatives and customer
demands, we may have to modify our operations with the goal of further improving data security. The cost of
compliance with these laws, regulations and standards is high and is likely to increase in the future. Any such
modifications may result in increased expenses and operating complexity, and we may be unable to increase the
rates we charge for our services sufficiently to offset these increases. Any failure on our part to comply with
these laws, regulations and standards can result in negative publicity and diversion of management time and
effort and may subject us to significant liabilities and other penalties.

If customer confidential information or personal data that we maintain is inappropriately disclosed due to an
information security breach, or if any person, including any of our employees, negligently disregards or
intentionally breaches our confidentiality policies or other controls or procedures with which we are responsible
for complying with respect to such data or otherwise mismanages or misappropriates that data, we may incur
substantial liabilities to our customers and be subject to fines or penalties imposed by governmental authorities.
Any incidents with respect to the handling of such information could subject us to litigation or indemnification
claims with our customers and other parties and harm our reputation. In addition, any breach or alleged breach
of our confidentiality agreements with our customers may result in termination of their engagements, resulting
in associated loss of revenue and increased costs and have a material adverse effect on our reputation and
business. For further discussion on the laws and regulations applicable to our businesses, see “Regulation.”

**_Our business may suffer if we cannot continue to license or enforce the intellectual property rights on which_**
**_our business depends or if we are subject to claims of intellectual property infringement._**

Our ability to compete effectively with other companies depends, in part, upon our ability to protect our
proprietary methodologies and other intellectual property, including the value of our brands. We rely upon a
combination of trade secrets, confidentiality, license and other contractual agreements and patent, copyright, and
trademark laws to protect our intellectual property rights. For example, certain of our business units rely on
proprietary software that we have developed internally or acquired, such as Millenium, or mobile apps
developed as part of our digital initiatives strategy. Our intellectual property rights may not prevent competitors
from independently developing services and solutions similar to ours. Further, the steps we take may not be
adequate to prevent or deter infringement or other misappropriation of our intellectual property by competitors,
former in-house employees or other third parties, which could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition or results of operations.

In addition, we cannot be sure that our services and solutions do not infringe on the intellectual property rights
of third parties. Third parties, including competitors, may assert intellectual property infringement,
misappropriation or invalidity claims against us that could be upheld.

Intellectual property litigation, which could result in substantial cost to and diversion of effort by us, may be
necessary to protect our intellectual property rights, including trade secrets or proprietary technology or for us to
defend against claimed infringement or misappropriation of the rights of others and to determine the scope and
validity of our or others’ intellectual property or proprietary rights. We may not prevail in any such litigation,
and if we are unsuccessful, we may be subject to monetary liability and injunctive or equitable relief, which may
prevent our use of others’ intellectual property or proprietary rights if we are not be able to obtain the necessary
licenses on reasonable terms or at all. Any failure by us to protect our trademarks and other intellectual property
rights may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

facilities, in amounts that we consider appropriate. Such policies are subject to certain limits and deductibles
and do not include business interruption coverage. We may not be covered by insurance in specific instances,
such as fire, explosions, natural disasters, water damage and terror attacks. While we seek to maintain

appropriate levels of insurance, not all claims are insurable, and we may experience major incidents of a nature
not covered by insurance. Furthermore, our insurance costs may increase over time in response to any negative
development in our claims history or due to material price increases in the insurance market in general.
Insurance coverage may not be available in the future at current costs or on commercially reasonable terms, and
