**_Compliance with laws and regulations_**

As a provider of residential and commercial real estate services, we are subject to a wide range of laws and
regulations in each of the countries in which we operate, as well as the regulations of the European Union. We
are subject to laws and regulations including those related to rental access and urban planning, rents we can
charge, data protection, tax reduction schemes for rental property investors and reforms to housing, planning
and digital technology. For example, the French government has introduced measures to protect individuals
buying or renting an apartment within a professionally managed co-ownership building. The Access to Housing
and Urban Renovation Law (“ALUR”), which was introduced in March 2014, imposed restrictions on the fees
agents can charge for selling or letting property and required two dedicated bank accounts for each jointly
owned property, thereby resulting in loss of interest income on customer accounts and a large administrative
burden. The ALUR law also required a significant amount of extra documentation before the pre-contract
(compromis de vente) can be signed, which increased the time between the initial offer and closing and thereby
delaying our revenue recognition. In addition, it required publication of commissions when payable by the
buyer and any resulting competition from low cost agents. Notwithstanding these requirements, we have
experienced certain positive impacts from the imposition of the ALUR law. For example, it required landlords
to register their buildings, which became a new fee-based service we began providing. Changes in, and
compliance with, such laws and regulations may entail significant costs for us and can have an impact on our
results of operations. For a description of certain material regulations applicable to our business, see
“Regulation.”

Failure to comply with applicable laws, regulations or rules, whether identified as a result of an investigation or
otherwise, could lead to adverse publicity, harm our reputation or divert management time and other resources.
In addition, non-compliance could result in disciplinary action, imposition of fines, the revocation of a license or
authorization or the need to take remedial action. In particular, the loss of a license or authorization could mean
that we are no longer able to carry out the business or activity for which we were previously authorized or
licensed and any remedial action that may need to be undertaken could result in a significant cost. Finally, such
laws, rules and regulations may subject us to more onerous conduct of business and administrative requirements,
limit the types of fees or services we can charge and provide or otherwise alter the current regulatory or tax
environment, each of which can have a significant impact on the manner in which we conduct our businesses.
See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our businesses, financial condition, results
_of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing_
_laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us,_
_or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.”_

**_Cost base and operational improvements_**

Our ability to actively manage our cost base by cost saving initiatives and enhancing operational efficiencies has
been a significant factor affecting our results of operations and financial condition in the period under review.
Our principal costs include staff costs and marketing and IT costs. For the year ended December 31, 2020, staff
costs accounted for 55.9% of revenue. Our business (excluding brokerage activities) has a largely fixed cost
base. Our fixed costs, which do not fluctuate with business volumes, consist primarily of salaries and wages
(excluding variable commissions, employee profit shares and bonus arrangements), rental costs, most of our
information technology (“IT”) costs, as well as other general costs. Our Brokerage business, which is more
exposed to real estate services market cycles in which our employees are paid based on commission, operates
primarily with variable costs, with approximately 26% of fixed costs for the year ended December 31, 2020.
Since variable costs tend to fluctuate with business volumes, we will need to react quickly in the future by
decreasing such costs if we forecast a potential downturn in business volumes or increase in such costs as the
market recovers. The management of our cost base is an important factor impacting our results of operations
and cash flow. We are able to initiate cost cutting measures when required, such as using temporary employees
and limiting travel, entertainment and office expenses and reducing variable compensation.

In addition, our management team sponsors a number of initiatives to improve efficiency and reduce fixed costs.
For example, we launched a pilot version of Millenium, our new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system in
March 2020 at one of our branches in France, and we expect for it to be completed at the end of 2021 or early
2022. We have invested significant resources in Millenium including a team of 80 developers and specialized
professionals in order to build this innovative and advanced real estate platform. Our financial condition and
results of operations are impacted by our ability to successfully implement Millenium and other initiatives to
improve our operational performance. We believe that the improved standardization and digitization Millenium
offers, will allow us to reduce administrative inefficiencies and achieve greater productivity. In parallel to the
deployment of Millenium, we have been designing a new organizational model called Agency of the Future


-----

which will be implemented following the roll-out of Millenium. Our vision for Agency of the Future sets out
four key goals (i) industrialize tasks with low added value; (ii) distinguish ourselves thanks to our expertise in
joint property management and rental management; (iii) have close proximity to our clients; (iv) reinforce our
attractiveness for staff. As a result of this new organization model, we expect to generate significant cost and
efficiency gains mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and
back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time
spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain
tasks previously done manually (such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges). We believe
Millenium and Agency of the Future will enable us to achieve greater organization among our businesses
allowing our employees to focus on customer satisfaction with the potential to lead to improved customer
retention. In the coming years, we plan to fully digitize all business of our businesses, internal processes and
our customer relationship management with Millenium. For the year ended December 31, 2020, capital
expenditures in connection with Millenium and Agency of the Future were €17 million. We anticipate capital
expenditures of €19 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 for the development and the deployment of
Millenium. By the end of 2022, we estimate approximately €15 million in saving and gains as a result of
efficiencies due to Millenium and Agency of the Future, with approximately €20 million non-recurring costs
related to those gains. We believe that, we will experience additional gains in the following years, as a result of
these projects. For more information, see “Business—Digital Transformation and IT Systems.”

**Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations**

**_Certain changes in accounting standards and accounting policies_**

_IFRS-16_

On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on
November 9, 2017, which has had a substantial impact on the financial statements of lessees of property and
high value equipment – requiring that leases be placed on-balance sheet by recognizing a ‘right-of-use’ asset
representing its right to use the underlying leased asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make
lease payments. In the income statement, this standard application results in an amortization and interest
expenses recognition. These changes become effective from January 1, 2019.

IFRS 16 has a substantial impact on the financial statements of lessees of property and high-value equipment,
requiring that leases be placed on balance sheet by recognizing a “right-of-use” asset, representing the lessee’s
right to use the underlying leased asset, and a lease liability, representing the lessee’s obligation to make lease
payments. In the income statement, the application of this standard results in amortization and recognition of
interest expense. The changes resulting from IFRS 16 became effective as from January 1, 2019.

In accordance with IAS 8, we applied IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach in the consolidated
financial statements of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, with no
restatement of comparative information for 2018. As a result, the financial information presented in this
offering memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 does not give effect to the application of
IFRS 16.

In 2020, in light of the changes in lease accounting under IFRS 16, we initiated a strategic project aimed at reexamining (and if necessary re-estimating) the terms of lease arrangements.

As a result of this change, the duration taken into account for the valuation of leases in France that were to be
tacitly renewed was revised to be increased to three years, which can be explained by the imperatives in terms of
continuity of the operations, which encourage the continuation of the initial lease, and our strategy based on
external growth.

_2019 Restatement_

In the consolidated financial statements of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer for the year ended December 31,
2020, the consolidated statement of financial position as at December 31, 2019 and the consolidated income
statement and cash flow statement for the year ended December 31, 2019 were restated to give effect to
application of the definitive decision of the IFRS IC and subsequent position statement of the ANC on
determining the lease terms of certain real estate leases.

This decision of the IFRS IC included interpretation guidelines for the determination of a lease term, in
particular with regard to French commercial leases.


-----

It includes a reminder that the lease term that when evaluating the debt associated with the lease is the period for
which it is enforceable, a lease no longer being enforceable when the lessee and the lessor each has the right to
terminate the lease without permission from the other party with no more than an insignificant penalty.

It also provides a clarification that in order to determine how long a lease is enforceable and whether a penalty is
insignificant under IFRS 16.B34, it is necessary to take into consideration the broader economics of the contract
and not just contractual termination payments. The notion of a penalty thus must include any economic
incentive to not terminate the contract.

In its decision, the IFRS IC also noted the need for consistency between the lease term for a lease for the
determination of the debt associated with the lease and the useful life of related non-removable leasehold
improvements.

Moreover, the French accounting standards setter (the Autorité des Normes Comptables or the “ANC”)
published on July 3, 2020 a new position statement related to the determination of the lease terms of commercial
leases known as “3-6-9 leases” (known as such because such leases are signed for at least nine years, with
unilateral termination possible by the tenant after three or six years). This new position statement replaced a
prior position statement dated February 16, 2018. In particular, in this update, the ANC concluded that the lease
term should reflect the term for which the tenant is reasonably certain to continue the lease and that, when the
legal length of the lease is nine years, this length is “generally nine years at the outset.”

In 2020, we initiated a strategic project to re-examine (and, if necessary, re-estimate) the lease terms of our real
property leases in light of the decision of the IFRS IC and the updated position statement of the ANC. As a
result of the completion of this project, the lease term that was taken into account for the evaluation of real
property leases in France that were to be tacitly renewed was revised upward to three years, based on
imperatives in terms of continuity of operations, which encourage the continuation of the initial lease, and our
particularly active and opportunistic real property strategy for the rationalization of our real property (including
in particular as a result of several restructurings due to our external growth). We had previously applied nine
months as a lease term in our 2019 financial statements when first applying IFRS 16 at January 1, 2019 (based
on the soonest possible surrender date, taking into account a legally required six-month notice period after the
end of the first quarter in the calendar year) and six months at December 31, 2019. In accordance with IAS 8,
the impacts related to these changes in lease terms and that directly result of the application of the IFRS IC
decision have been accounted for using the retrospective method. See note 3.2 to the Senior Secured Notes
Issuer’s consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020.

We refer to the restatements described above as the “2019 Restatement.” For ease of comparative review, we
present financial data reflecting the 2019 Restatement when comparing information as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2019 with information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_2018 Restatement_

In 2019, following additional analyses carried out in connection with the application of IFRS 15, initially
adopted in 2018, we changed our income statement presentation of revenue arising from fees earned on deeds of
sale. This led to a separate classification of revenue from contracts where we act as agent, as opposed to in
aggregate with revenue from contracts where we act as principal as was previously the case. Furthermore,
revenue from contracts where we act as agent is now presented net of the cost of fees in accordance with IFRS
15.

Since this does not allow a meaningful comparison of consolidated revenue (and the related external charges)
between the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018, the statement of profit and loss figures for the year
ended December 31, 2018 has been restated accordingly, leading to a negative impact of €14.9 million on
revenue as presented and a similar positive impact on “Purchases consumed and external charges.” This change
in presentation has no impact on recurring operating profit for 2018. In addition, net profit (loss) from
continuing operations attributable to non-controlling interests was adjusted to correct a minor presentation error.
See note 2.7 to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

We refer to the restatements described above as the “2018 Restatement.” For ease of comparative review, we
present financial data reflecting the 2018 Restatement when comparing information as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2018 with information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019.

**_Acquisitions and disposals_**

The timing of acquisitions and disposals may impact the comparability of our results on a year-over-year basis.
Our results include incremental revenues and expenses following the completion date of an acquisition. In
addition, there is generally an initial adverse impact on net income from an acquisition as a result of preacquisition due diligence expenditures, transaction/deal costs and post-acquisition integration costs, such as fees
from third-party advisors engaged to assist with onboarding and process alignment, retention and severance
expense, early lease termination costs, and other integration expenses. We have historically used strategic and
bolt-on acquisitions to increase our scale within existing capabilities and to expand our presence in new or
existing geographic regions globally. We believe that strategic acquisitions will increase revenue, provide cost
synergies and generate incremental income in the long term.

_Recent Developments_

On December 31, 2020, we completed our acquisition of Loft-One, one of the largest property administration
companies in the Southwest of France. We paid a temporary purchase price of €27.7 million, and we acquired
14,062 properties in rental management and 38,734 in condominium management. We believe that through this
acquisition, we are emerging as the leader in the local market.

On December 11, 2020, we completed our acquisition of OP Property Management (Office des Propriétaires), a
management property company based in Brussels. We paid a total purchase price of €14.5 million, and we
acquired four branches. We believe that this acquisition will further our goal of becoming a leader for real
estate services in Belgium.

Due to timing of these two acquisitions, we have not consolidated the results into our consolidated financial
statements for the year ended December 31, 2020. However, our payment for this acquisition is reflected in our
cash flow statement and their acquisition value appears as non-consolidated securities.

**Key Income Statement Line Items**

**_Revenue_**

Revenue results from sales of services within the scope of the ordinary operations of consolidated subsidiaries,
less revenue from intragroup transactions. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received
or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes and duties. In accordance with IFRS 15, we
recognize revenue when the amount thereof can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic
benefits will flow to us, and specific criteria are met by each of our businesses, as further described below.

_Joint Property Management business_

From a contractual and legal perspective, our Joint Property Management business is mostly conducted through
mandates, and fees are calculated on a flat-rate basis. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management
services provided by the jointly owned property association, and excludes incidental services. All such services
are treated as an overall performance obligation satisfied over time. In fact, these different services are
associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., management of the jointly owned property association.
Annual revenue from basic property management fees is therefore recognized on a percentage-of-completion
basis (over time) based on actual amounts billed (costs are in line with the billed amounts).


-----

Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for
each such service, for example, additional meetings and visits, rules and regulations of the jointly owned
property, physical and administrative management of claims, technical work and surveys, litigation and
disputes. Transfer Fees are also invoiced directly to a landlord selling its property. Since each additional
service represents a separate performance obligation, revenue is recognized when the service is performed.

_Lease Management and Renting business_

In the lease management line of our Lease Management and Renting business, we act as agent for ownerslessors and fulfil a certain number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These represent separate
service obligations. Accordingly, revenue for each of these obligations is recognized separately. Revenue from
services provided over time, such as routine management services and insurance is recognized on a percentageof-completion basis by reference to the frequency with which expenses are rebilled to the owners. Revenue
from one-off services is recognized when those services are provided.

In our lettings business, revenue is recognized at the time the inventory of the premises is conducted. We
collect fees from owners and from lessees.

_Brokerage business /Efficity_

Revenue in the transactions business is recognized upon signature of the notarized final sale agreement (acte
_authentique), which is the date on which control is presumed to have been transferred._

_Client accounts_

Interest income generated on client funds, limited to rental cash deposits, is booked in revenue.

_Assurimo_

Assurimo provides property insurance brokerage services. Revenue under comprehensive property insurance
and comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies is recognized over the term of the cover, since services in
this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis.

_Constatimmo_

Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for
lessees. Its revenue is recognized and measured when the related services are performed.

_Seiitra_

Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and developed the Powimo software, which it markets through its
software as a service (“SaaS”) solutions model. These property management tools offer the full suite of
functionalities needed to keep accounting records for client accounts and to manage suspense accounts, jointly
owned properties and rentals, as well as the budget of jointly owned property associations. Maintenance fees
are recognized on a straight-line, percentage-of-completion basis, since the corresponding services are provided
over time.

_Esset Management_

Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental
services) for B2B customers such as national and international insurance, real estate and financial institutions.
Once contracts are signed and invoices are issued, revenue recognition follows IFRS 15.

_Foncia Valorisation_

Foncia Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, block/unit
property sales) for institutional customers or wealthy families. Its revenue is recognized at the date the
notarized final sale agreement is signed and is based on a percentage of the sale price.


-----

_Leemo_

Leemo, a wholly owned subsidiary since 2017, is a listing service for properties for sale. It has developed a
digital platform for property companies where it lists new real estate projects by different developers as well as
certain older properties that are to be made available for sale to private and institutional investors.

It derives its revenue from two main sources:

    - fees on sale agreements: amounts billed to developers and partially retroceded to business
providers. Only the net margin is recognized in revenue; and

    - fees on bundles of services sold to developers without any retrocession requirements.

Revenue from fees on sale agreements is recognized when the notarized final sale agreement is signed.
Revenue from fees earned on bundles of services is recognized on a pro rata basis in the period.

**_Other operating income_**

Other operating income primarily comprises gains on client accounts, retrocessions of fees for the Assurance
Privilège product in Assurimo’s comprehensive homeowner’s insurance portfolio, and miscellaneous net
sub-letting income.

**_Purchases consumed and external charges_**

Purchases consumed and external charges comprises fees and services, cost of premises (in the year ended
December 31, 2018 only), travel, subcontracting, insurance and guarantees, advertising, IT purchases and other
costs, postage and telephone costs, supplies and documentation and other rental costs. This also comprised
charges related to external personnel (e.g., interim staff or staff on secondment).

**_Taxes other than on income_**

Taxes other than on income includes corporate property tax, tax on vehicles, corporate social solidarity
contribution and miscellaneous other taxes other than income tax. We also included certain taxes on
compensation in taxes other than on income (including transport tax, training levy, apprenticeship tax, tax on
wages, payroll taxes and contributions to AGEFIPH (the French association for the employment of disabled
people)).

**_Personnel costs_**

Personnel costs include wages and salaries, payroll taxes, other personnel costs, employee profit-sharing and
movements in post-employment benefits.

**_Other operating expenses_**

Other operating expenses include directors’ fees, losses on non-recoverable receivables, royalties and other
expenses.

**_Net additions to depreciation, amortization, impairment and provisions_**

Net additions to depreciation, amortization, impairment and provisions include amortization of intangible assets;
depreciation of property, plant and equipment; impairment of receivables; reversals of receivables impairment;
impairment of inventories net of reversals; and various additions and reversals to provisions we have taken.

**_Recurring operating profit (loss)_**

Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to our businesses, with the
exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses).” Recurring operating profit
(loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes
all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items. Costs relating to business
combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss).


-----

**_Non-recurring operating income (expenses)_**

Non-recurring operating income (expenses) includes income and expense items that, owing to their nature,
amount or frequency, cannot be considered as arising in the ordinary course of our operations and are therefore
not reported in recurring operating profit (loss). Non-recurring items are limited, unusual and/or irregular items
of a material amount and we classify these items into three main categories: (i) M&A non-recurring integrations
charges, (ii) restructuring/transformation non-recurring charges and (iii) corporate non-recurring charges.

These items include impacts of changes in the scope of consolidation, goodwill impairment, and amortization
and impairment charged against trademarks and Syndic+ software. If material, non-recurring items also include
the effects of certain unusual transactions such as capital gains and losses on disposals of non-current assets,
restructuring fees, fees relating to major claims and disputes, and any other income or expenses likely to affect
the comparability of recurring operating profit (loss) from one period to the next.

For transactions directly related to external growth and projects to transform or restructure the business
(particularly mergers and reorganizations), a detailed procedure is in place to identify, classify and validate any
transactions of a non-recurring nature. This procedure gives a precise indication of transactions that meet the
criteria to be recorded in this category.

**_Operating profit (loss)_**

Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to our businesses, irrespective of
whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions.

**_Cost of gross debt_**

The cost of gross debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings.

**_Cost of net debt_**

The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less financial income from cash
investments.

**_Other financial income and expenses_**

Other financial income and expenses includes foreign exchange gains (losses), net interest cost on pension and
other employee benefit obligations, capital gains (losses) on financial disposals less costs to sell, net impairment
of financial assets, gains (losses) on available-for-sale financial assets, net discounting costs and other
miscellaneous costs.

**_Income tax expense_**

Income tax expense for the year includes current and deferred income tax expense, which are recognized in the
statement of profit and loss except when they relate to items recognized in other comprehensive income.

We calculate our current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which our
earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted
at the reporting date in countries where our subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However,
management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are
subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax
authorities.

Income tax expense includes the amounts reported by French subsidiaries in respect of the CVAE tax assessed
on value added, since we consider this tax meets the definition of income tax set out in IAS 12 – Income Taxes.
When they have not been set against income tax, income tax credits that are not included in the calculation of
taxable profit and that are always refunded by the government are recorded as subsidies and reduce the expenses
to which they relate.

**_Share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies_**

Associates are entities over which we exercise significant influence. Significant influence is the power to
participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling


-----

those policies. A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the
arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the
relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control.

Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in our
consolidated financial statements. Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is
initially recognized at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for our interest in the profits, losses and other
comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture.

As of the year ended December 31, 2019, Pagardim was the only joint venture that we did not control and that
we accounted for by the equity method, based on our 50% interest. This entity is immaterial. No material
commitments were entered into with Pagardim and there are no material liabilities relating to this entity.

Revenue for the RRES business, including our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting
businesses, increased by €36.0 million, or 6.7%, from €535.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to
€571.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was mainly attributable to the increase in
revenue from our Joint Property Management business by €22.2 million, or 8.6%, from €258.9 million to €281.1
million and the increase in revenue from Lease Management and Renting by €13.4 million, or 5.0%, from
€270.3 million to €283.6 million. This increase was mainly driven by price effect in Joint Property
Management and in Lease Management, partially offset by customer turnover in Joint Property Management
and Lease Management, and a decline in market conditions for the rental activity in 2019.

Revenue for the Brokerage business (French network) increased by €11.3 million, or 9.5%, from €118 million
for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €129.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase
was primarily driven by higher organic Brokerage revenues as the result of strong market conditions in volume
and in pricing.

Revenue for the digital business segment increased by €12.8 million, or 56.6%, from €22.6 million for the year
ended December 31, 2018, to €35.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily
driven by increased revenue from Efficity of €8.9 million notably due to the recruitment of new agents.

Revenue for the other activities segment increased throughout the period under review by €0.4 million, or 0.4%,
from €98.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €99.0 million for the year ended December 31,
2019. This increase was primarily driven by higher revenue from Assurimo due to the increased number of
buildings that we managed, partially offset by lower revenue deriving from the B2B segment.

Revenue for our International business increased by €17.6 million, or 19.4%, from €91.0 million to
€108.6 million. This increase was primarily driven by increased revenues in Switzerland, which were largely
the result of a positive currency effect in Switzerland of €2.5 million.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our primary source of liquidity is cash flow from operations. Our cash needs relate primarily to capital and
other expenditures for meeting debt service requirements and funding our working capital requirements, which
are primarily costs related to our acquisitions. The components of our working capital are trade receivables and
deferred income, trade payables and prepaid expenses, tax and employee related working capital. We believe
that, based on our current cash flows, these sources of liquidity, together with existing available borrowings
under the New Revolving Credit Facility, will be sufficient to fund our operations, capital expenditure and debt
service for at least the next 12 months.

We are highly leveraged and have significant debt service obligations. As of the Issue Date, after giving effect
to the Transactions, we expect to have €2,099 million of indebtedness, comprising primarily of the Notes, the
New Term Loan Facility and lease liabilities. We will also be able to borrow up to €437.5 million under the
New Revolving Credit Facility. The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain
conditions described further under “Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.”

The Indenture governing the Notes offered hereby will contain, and the New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement
will contain, restrictive covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future opportunities and capital needs,
or pursue business opportunities and activities. In addition, the New Revolving Credit Facility also requires us
to comply with a leverage ratio, under certain circumstances, in order for us to continue to be able to draw funds
under the Revolving Credit Facility. We may from time to time seek to retire or repurchase our outstanding
debt through cash purchases, in open market purchases, privately negotiated transactions or otherwise. Such


-----

repurchases, if any, will depend on market conditions, our liquidity requirements, contractual restrictions and
other factors.

Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which in turn depends to some extent

impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as the other factors discussed in “—Key Factors Affecting Results of

from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable
us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

**Off-balance Sheet Commitments**

Under the provisions of the Hoguet law, property management companies must provide financial guarantees for
funds held in client accounts. In accordance with this law, we provide financial guarantees to clients equal to
the maximum amount of funds held on their account. These guarantees are presented under commitments
given. Commitments given for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 were €2.3 billion,
€1.9 billion and €2.1 billion, respectively, for these Professional Financial Guarantees and total commitments
for the same periods were €6.1 billion, €5.5 billion and €5.7 billion, respectively, including property lease
commitments, commitments under financing leases and pledges of certain collateral.

Financial guarantees received from guarantors such as guarantee funds, insurance companies and banks are
shown under commitments received. Total commitments received for the years ended December 31, 2020,
2019 and 2018 were €3.0 billion, €2.3 billion and €3.0 billion, respectively, including commitments under
property lease commitments, commitments under financing leases and pledges of certain collateral.

**Employee Pensions**

In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which we operate, we participate in, or
operate, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to
eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of our employees are
entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by us to the beneficiaries when the rights
allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds financed in compliance with the
applicable government requirements and regulations. These plans may be funded by investments in various
instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds.

**Client Accounts**

We conduct our property management business through mandates signed with customers, under which our
companies are responsible for holding client funds. By law, all Joint Property Management accounts are
segregated and each individual association must open a current account and a saving account for client funds.
These funds consist of guarantee deposits received, rent and expenses and capital and renovation funds. As an
agent, we undertake to hold client accounts and to recognize them in our statement of financial position using a
specific account for each activity, such as property sales, rentals and management.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

We are exposed to various market risks, including interest rate and foreign exchange rate risks. Our treasury
department is responsible for managing our exposure to market risk that arises in connection with operations
and financial activities, including interest rate, foreign exchange rate, credit and liquidity, and credit risk
management.

The following sections discuss our significant exposures to market risk. The following discussions do not
address other risks that we face in the normal course of business, including country risk and legal risk.

**_Interest rate risk_**

Our interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on our borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in
euros and are managed on a centralized basis. They are mainly indexed to three-month EURIBOR. The risk
management policy is set by our management team.

Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for our companies are centralized under a cash pooling
agreement and managed by our treasury department. Our treasury department selects investment vehicles for
cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework
set by the management policy, which prioritizes liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month
EURIBOR or is at fixed rates (term accounts).

**Critical Accounting Judgments**

The preparation of financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the
measurement and presentation of certain assets and liabilities and any disclosures provided in respect of
contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses
for the period.


-----

Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting
period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given
the circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities
that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Where applicable, a sensitivity analysis may be performed
if the estimates are material. Accordingly, actual results may differ from these estimates.

The estimates we make in preparing our consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern
assumption and relate primarily to the items described below.

_Measurements used in testing goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment for impairment_

The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and
property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and
determine the discount rates used.

As with any estimate, the assumptions used in these calculations are partly based on uncertain factors and may
therefore need to be adjusted in subsequent periods. The notes to the audited financial statements included
elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum set out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and
determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity
analyses were also performed and are described in the same notes.

_Measurement of leases_

IFRS 16 requires entities to use a significant degree of judgement as well as certain key estimates. These
involve determining:

    - whether an option to extend or terminate a lease is reasonably certain to be exercised;

    - the lease term;

    - the appropriate discount rate to be used to calculate future lease payments; and

    - the specific selling price of any lease components and non-lease components contained in the
contract.

The main assumptions we use to prepare the audited financial statements are described in the notes to the
audited financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

_Measurement of provisions_

We use the best estimate of our commitments and obligations to calculate the corresponding provisions.

_Measurement of employee benefits_

We operate both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated
using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future
increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs.

The notes to the audited financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum set out the
assumptions used to measure these obligations. We consider that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate
and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these
assumptions also change.

_Measurement of fair value (Level 1)_

We use fair value on a recurring basis in our statement of financial position to measure unlisted derivative
instruments and cash and cash equivalents.

_Measurement of recognized deferred tax assets and liabilities and tax expense_

Our tax position is based on our best estimate of future taxable earnings.


-----

_Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business_
_combination_

The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and
liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount
rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount.

_Assessment of criteria for identifying discontinued operations_

In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, we are required to
exercise judgement in determining whether an asset or group of assets meets the criteria to be classified as held
for sale. IFRS 5 criteria are also used to identify any assets to be classified as discontinued operations. These
assessments are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in light of changes in the relevant facts and
circumstances.

In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, we use our judgement to define
and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the
financial statements:

    - present a true and fair view of our financial position, financial performance and cash flows;

    - reflect the economic substance of transactions; and

    - are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects.

We are the European leader in the residential real estate services market, providing services to both individuals
(“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have recently
entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. We assist our residential and
commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service
offerings.

**Overview of addressable markets**

The property management business in France provides a wide range of services from core property management
services (lease management and joint property management) to providing ancillary services to property owners.

**_Lease management and joint property management_**

Property management companies’ core offering is composed of lease management services and joint property
management services.

The lease management business includes i) residential property management (gestion locative), i.e. services for
an apartment or a house, and ii) commercial property management, i.e. services for retail buildings, notably
shops and restaurants. It refers to the assistance on the day-to-day operations of the property typically related to
financial management, legal assistance, conflict handling, etc., for an individual residential unit (which may be a
joint property or condominium). On the lease management level, property management companies take care of
tenancy agreements, rent collection, account and reporting, tax and insurance claims, maintenance or legal
compliance. The property management providers are appointed by the owner of the individual unit(s), typically
a private landlord.

Joint property management refers to the management of joint property (copropriété), i.e. the management of
shared property of joint ownership associations, activities include financial management, structural support and
legal assistance. In the joint property management segment, the services provided include organization of
general assemblies, a pre-determined number of visits per year for inspection, coordination of maintenance
efforts and accounting, bill payment, and building fee collection. The property management provider assumes
the role of trustee (syndic) after appointment by the general assembly of joint owners. It is important to note
that lease management and joint property management activities can overlap with each other and fall under joint
property management for the joint property and lease management for the individual unit.

Property management companies provide residential real estate services to B2C and B2B clients. The business
model has different maturity levels in different geographies, for instance, B2B property management services
are far more developed in Germany than in France where this segment is still growing significantly, notably
following the COVID-19 pandemic.

_Main Customers_

Property management companies address a variety of customers that can be divided into three main groups
depending on the type of services provided to them. Typical lease management customers are private landlords
and family offices. Private landlords are private individuals with real estate portfolios varying in size. They
own the majority of residential units and a very small portion of office and retail buildings. Family offices are
individuals who own a real estate portfolio, mainly composed of apartments and to a lesser extent, office and
retail buildings.

Typical joint property management customers are joint ownership associations or their boards, representing
owners of a single property containing multiple units, such as apartments buildings.

Typical B2B clients are institutional investors that acquire and manage real estate portfolios such as Axa,
Allianz, BNP Paribas or Swiss Life. These portfolios can be composed of apartments, office or retail buildings.

**Market size**

The size of the property markets differs depending on the country as well as the size of the addressable markets
for property management companies. Property management companies’ penetration rates varies among the
markets (residential vs. commercial) and the different types of owners.

**_France_**

In France, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be €12.2 billion,
of which €5.3 billion (44%) was under external management.

**Brokerage and ancillary services**

**_Brokerage_**

_Brokerage refers to the management of sale or purchase transaction processes for customers, including property_
search services, estimations on rental income, advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities
and market analysis, buyer solvency assessments and other services.

**_Other real estate services_**

In addition to the core offering and brokerage, property management companies also provide other ancillary
services that may be broadly categorized as follows:

    - _Rental services, referring to the services aiming at minimizing the vacancy rates of the_
properties, such as finding new tenants, renegotiating tenancy agreements as well as property
letting, sale of properties or buyer advisory;

    - _Technical building consulting, referring to the financial, legal and technical services related to_
building projects as well as maximizing the property value through e.g. energy optimization,
and includes scrutiny technical advice and building process management, apartment
renovations or energy consultancy;

    - _Facility services, referring to the facilitation or direct delivery of supporting services for_
properties and tenants aimed at ensuring stable operations, and gathering different activities
such as janitor services, receptionists, canteen operation, cleaning, caretakers or gardeners;

    - _Property asset management, referring to the end-to-end assistance with the process of_
investing in properties including strategy, opportunity assessment, valuation and portfolio
development, and includes services such as portfolio strategy and optimization, valuation and
risk assessment or portfolio development; and

    - _Insurance advisory, referring to the (coordination of) providers of insurance services such as_
unpaid rent insurance, property insurance, liability insurance, and includes services such as
offering of unpaid rent insurance, insurance consultancy or preferential supplier offers.

**Key growth drivers in the lease management and joint property management businesses**

As of August 2019, the addressable market of our lease management and joint property management businesses
in France grew at an estimated 2% per annum between 2014 to 2019. In Germany and Switzerland, the
addressable market for our lease management and joint property management businesses grew at an estimated
1.5% to 3% per annum between 2014 and 2019. The joint property management market is driven by three
factors: pricing, building activities and outsourcing penetration for property management.

**France**

The property management market has seen an estimated annual growth rate of approximately 2%, from
€4.82 billion in 2014 to €5.32 billion in 2019. Within the property management market, residential lease
management grew at the fastest pace (growing from €1.49 billion in 2014 to €1.71 billion in 2019 with a CAGR
of 2.8%), followed by joint property management (growing from €1.71 billion in 2014 to €1.90 billion in 2019
with a CAGR of 2.1%) and commercial lease management (growing from €1.61 billion in 2014 to €1.72 billion
in 2019 with a CAGR of 1.3%).

Between 2019 and 2024, the property management market in France is expected to grow an estimated rate of
approximately 1 to 2% per annum, to reach €5.87 billion in 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19
pandemic). Continued growth is expected to be driven by the residential lease management segment and joint
property management segment, with commercial lease management following historical trends. The growth
outlook is expected to be driven by a larger number of addressable units and higher penetration of units owned
by private landlords as a result of regulatory changes which have made it more difficult for private landlords to
manage properties in-house. However, certain aspects of this expected growth may be decreased by
uncertainties regarding the full price effect of recent regulatory changes and new entrants.

**_Pricing_**

As of August 2019, prices for residential lease management are expected to grow between 1 to 2% per annum
between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic), although impact from recent and
future housing reform regulations remains unclear. Pricing for lease management is typically fixed as a
percentage of rent (ranging from 2 to 10%, and on average 6 to 8% of annual rent). While prices in terms of
percentages have remained stable, rent for residential real estate grew at 0.7% per annum from 2013 to 2019,
with a trend of increased acceleration in recent past (1.7% from 2018 to 2019).

Recent developments make it difficult to estimate possible pricing scenarios in the near future. For example,
rent limitation was re-enacted in Paris since July 2019, which set a 20% limit for premium over reference rent in
each district, is expected to curb the upward trend for rent significantly. Furthermore, the impact of any future
regulatory housing reforms is unclear. As shown by recent housing reforms, regulations can have significant
impacts on rent price. This is in addition to the ongoing uncertainty of the impact of the general economic
disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Prices for joint property management are expected to grow at 1 to 2% per annum between 2019 and 2024
(excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic), in line with inflation. Prices for joint property management
range from approximately €100 to €400/unit and depend on a variety of factors, including size of the portfolio,
included services, location and characteristics of the property. Prices have typically been increasing by 1 to 2%
per annum between 2014 and 2019, in line with inflation. This trend is expected to continue However, this does
not account for any disruptions that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19
pandemic.

Prices for Commercial Lease Management are expected to stay flat between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the
impact of the COVID-19 pandemic), reflecting the competitive pressure from tendering process. Rent levels in
the commercial segment vary significantly and pricing tends to be negotiated through a competitive tender
process where price points are determined on a global level, based on the characteristics and requirements of the
building(s) in the portfolio. In general, prices for commercial property management have remained rather stable
between 2014 and 2019.

**_Building activity_**

Building activities are expected to account for an estimated growth of 0.5 to 1% per annum between 2019 and
2024.

Expenditure for residential building activity grew at an estimated 3% per annum from 2017 to 2019, and is
expected to correct for recent boom years and decrease by 3% per annum from 2019 to 2021, thereby returning
to 2016 levels. However, despite decreases in total expenditure, residential stock is expected to continue to
grow towards 2022 at an estimated 1% annually. The share of addressable market for property management
businesses (excluding social housing and owner occupied units) is expected to remain stable in the same period.
Growth for joint properties is expected to be in line with overall residential building stock growth at
approximately 1% till 2022. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic
disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Based on the number of building permits, the total number of

the COVID-19 pandemic, which is expected to undermine the growth of the commercial segment.

**_Outsourcing penetration_**

Penetration of property management outsourcing is expected to grow for residential lease management, mainly
driven by an increase in private landlords engaging management services. The penetration rate (the degree to
which property owners outsource property management rather than conduct activities in-house) for residential
lease management varies significantly depending on the type of owners. Penetration within private landlords
and secondary and vacant homes is relatively low at approximate 30% and 10% respectively as of 2019,
whereas for institutional investors and commercial segment, the penetration rate is at approximately 90% as of
2019.

As a result of more complex regulations (including PINEL, ALUR, ELAN), there has been a higher tendency
among private landlords to outsource property management, as it has become increasingly difficult, time
consuming and risky to keep property management in-house. These developments are expected to continue to
cause some increases in penetration until 2024. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the
general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Penetration for institutional investors and for the commercial segment is expected to remain stable given already
elevated current levels. Secondary and vacant homes are often used for private or short-term purposes, thus
penetration is expected to remain low.

**Other countries**

Foncia has operations in Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg. Between 2019 to 2024, the
property management market is expected to grow at approximately 1.5 to 2% per annum in Switzerland and 2.5
to 3% per annum in Germany.

**_Switzerland_**

Historically, the property management market in Switzerland grew at an estimated 1.5 to 2% per annum, from
€1.00 billion in 2015 to €1.07 billion in 2019, and is expected to grow at a similar pace in the near future,
reaching €1.17 billion in 2024. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic
disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Main drivers for growth of the sector in Switzerland are expected to be building activity (which is expected to
grow at an estimated rate of 1.2% per annum between 2019 and 2024) and to a lesser extent outsourcing
penetration (which is expected to grow at an estimated rate of 0.6% per annum between 2019 and 2024). Unlike
in France, in Switzerland, the prices have been decreasing slightly between 2014 to 2019, driven by the decrease
in percentages charged on the rent, despite increasing rent levels. In the near future, pricing in terms of
percentage of rent is not expected to decrease at the same pace given the already low level. An additional
upside could potentially be realized through ancillary services. Overall, prices are not expected to have a
significant impact on the growth prospects for the property management market in Switzerland.

**_Germany_**

The property management market in Germany grew at an estimated rate of 3% per annum, from €3.24 billion in
2015 to €3.66 billion in 2019. In the near future, the market is expected to grow at approximately 2.5 to 3% per
annum between 2019 and 2024, largely in line with historical levels, reaching €4.18 billion in 2024. This
remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19
pandemic.

Price increases are expected to be the main growth driver (approximately 1.1% per annum between 2019 and
2024), with some contributions from building activity (approximately 0.7% per annum between 2019 and 2024)


-----

and to a lesser extent outsourcing penetration (approximately 0.3% per annum between 2019 and 2024). Prices
have increased across residential and commercial segments in the recent past between 2015 and 2019, driven by
mostly by increasing rent (especially for office spaces, driven by shortage). These trends are expected to
continue in the near future. Unlike in France or Switzerland, outsourcing activity in the German market has not
followed a clear trend and is not expected to do so in the short term.

In Belgium and Luxembourg, the company’s current operations are relatively small compared to other markets
limiting the impact of market growth trends on the overall business.

**Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the growth drivers**

Despite the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, the residential real estate services market had proven to be
resilient during 2020, supported by reassuring factors that continued stable and growing momentum.

In France, transactions slowed down during the first half of 2020 due to government confinement measures that
were in place between March and May 2020. All real estate agencies and notaries were closed and, as a
consequence, the steady growth of housing transactions halted during that period. In July 2020, the trailing 12
months sales volumes of existing properties came down to 983,000 units, compared to 1,075,000 units in
January 2020. In comparison, in January 2018, sales volumes stood at 972,000 units.

During the second half of the year, the transaction market recovered to reach one million units (over 12 months).
In November 2020, the trailing 12 months transactions level was at 1,020,000 units, which was a decrease of 5%
compared to the levels recorded in January 2020.

Through 2020, leasing activity was halted due to several sanitary measures, constraining tenants’ ability to
change their housing. During the first three quarters of 2020, according to INSEE, rent followed the same path
as house prices. In the second and third quarter of 2020, the quarterly increases were +0.7% and +0.5%,
respectively. The fourth quarter of 2020 saw a flattening of rent prices (at -0.1% quarter over quarter), however
rent levels remain higher than what was observed by the end of 2019.


Exhibit 14: Rent index evolution


_Source: INSEE_

Finally, a new housing trend has emerged from the various constraining measures. There has been a shift
among the urban population towards preferring greener areas as observed by Notaires de France. The
experience of confinement and the already crowded urban hubs have pushed increasing numbers of homeowners
and tenants to seek more rural properties, with gardens and greater interior space. This move from urban to
sub-urban areas has also been reinforced by the possibility of undertaking and maintaining professional
activities remotely. As a result, for real estate servicers, scale and the capillarity of their network became key to
take advantage of this new housing habit.

In summary, the residential segment has remained resilient through the COVID-19 pandemic while other
segments of the real estate services market, such as offices or retail, have been negatively impacted by the
proliferation of working from home practices or by the acceleration of e-commerce adoption due to
government-ordered closure of certain physical shops. This resilience and relative outperformance has led
intuitional investors to increase their exposure in residential assets, thus benefitting the B2B customer segment.

The French real estate services market is highly fragmented, with a few large players and a long tail of
independent small and local providers. The increasing barriers to entry with regulations and growing
technological requirements make it difficult for small players to remain competitive.

_The French brokerage market_

The French brokerage market is highly fragmented, with few large players and a long tail of very small
agencies. The main players can be divided into four main categories:

    - _Traditional real estate agency networks (physical) gather a network of several agencies. Most_
of them opt for franchising that enable them to develop quickly and inexpensively. Only six
networks exceed 500 locations in France (Century 21, Foncia, Guy Hoquet’Immobilier,
Laforêt Immobilier, Orpi and Stéphane Plaza Immobilier);

    - _Real estate agency networks (online), mainly carry out their activity online, enabling them to_
propose lower commission rates as they do not operate a network of physical agencies. The
seven predominant networks are IAD, Safti, Capifrance, Propriétés-Privées.com, OptimHome,
Efficity (a subsidiary of Foncia Group) and MegAgence;

    - _Independent online agencies offer fixed commissions and are challenging the codes of the real_
estate services market. Still few players (a dozen on the French market), these start-ups are
essentially present in Île-de-France and in some large cities (Lyon, Bordeaux, etc.);

    - _Specialized agents for the luxury segment coming from dominant specialized agencies_
distinguished by a significant international presence. Predominant examples are Barnes and
Emile Garcin.

The Swiss market is relatively fragmented, with a few large players and a long tail of small, local providers.

    - _Independent property management companies, including us, with core offering of property_
management services for both the commercial and residential segments, without a clear
separation. They also provide brokerage and other services such as facility management.
Other predominant examples of companies in this category are Privera and Averit;

    - _Institutionally owned property managers are large, nationwide companies, owned by_
institutional investors or real estate companies like Swiss Prime Site, SwissLife or Pensimo.
They often offer property management services to third parties, in addition to managing their
own portfolios, such as brokerage and other services (commercial letting or technical
consulting). Predominant examples are Wincasa, Livit and Regimo;

    - _Local associates of international real estate advisors are originally Swiss property_
management companies that have partnered with an international real estate advisor, having
often two local associates: one for French speaking Switzerland and one for German speaking
Switzerland. They usually also offer brokerage services and other services. Predominant
examples are Intercity and Real Estate AG;

    - _Small scale property management companies are small and local providers of property_
management, mainly targeting private investors and offering property management and coownership association services. They are typically family businesses or owner-operated
companies with less than 10 employees, with most of the business focused on a single
municipality or city. They represent almost 50% of the market. Predominant examples are
Geminwo and Martaler.

Immobilien Gruppe, Treureal and Tectareal;

    - _Full-service real estate advisors operate internationally as “one-stop-shop.” They secure_
stable income streams. They also provide other services (asset management or facility
management). Predominant examples are JLL, BNPP RE, CBRE and Cushman & Wakefield;

    - _Facility management-evolved companies, the core offering of which is facility management,_
moving gradually more into provision of property management to complement the low-margin
facility management business with broader services. Predominant examples are Strabag,
Apleona and Property First;

     - _Small-scale property management companies are small companies with “WEG-management”_
(acting according to the German Condominium Act (“Wohneigentumsgesetz” – WEG), which
constitutes the basis for all legal regulations involving individual freehold ownership incl. the
management of condominiums) as core business. They also provide property management
and gradually move more into property management of commercial space. They are typically
owner-operated, with an average of less than 10 employees with most of the business focused
around a municipality or a city. They represent more than 80% of the market. Predominant
examples are Jürgens Hausverwaltung GmbH and Kaldox Immobilien.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are the European leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market, providing services to both
individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have
recently entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. In addition, we have
established ourselves as a leader for real estate services in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and
Luxembourg by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative products uniquely suited to the needs of our
customers. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with
competitive and comprehensive service offerings. We provide end-to-end assistance, from managing individual
apartments and building areas jointly owned by apartment owners through our lease management and joint
property management business lines, respectively, to providing renting, brokerage and digital and ancillary
services such as insurance brokerage, technical diagnostic, and distribution and energy brokerage offerings
through our other business lines. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand
through a network of approximately 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses,
respectively, and 242 branches dedicated to both our RRES and Brokerage businesses, representing 84% of our
revenue in France for the year ended December 31, 2020. We operate an additional 101 branches under various
brands in Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our
French RRES business, Brokerage business, ancillary services, Digital services, B2B services and international
business generated 60%, 13%, 6%, 4%, 4% and 13% of our total revenue, respectively.

Our business lines include:

    - Residential Real Estate Services (“RRES”):

        - _Joint property management (our “JPM business”): In our Joint Property_
Management business, we are mandated by landlords to manage jointly owned
building areas and equipment and to ensure compliance with joint ownership
regulations. We are the French market leader in Joint Property Management,
managing over 1,463,402 dwellings in France for the year ended December 31, 2020.
We are generally hired by an apartment building homeowners’ board to provide
common services to all residents under contracts that are typically one year in length,
subject to renewal. Services in our Joint Property Management business include the
administrative, financial and technical management of the building, works
management, managing security staff and ensuring the maintenance of technical
equipment such as elevators, heating and safety systems. We also coordinate the
payment of common costs, transfer tasks, help brokers with the management of joint
decisions, offer cost management services such as efficiencies with respect to energy,
maintenance and heating costs, and provide asset appraisal services, as well as
around-the-clock maintenance assistance. These fee-based services in our Joint
Property Management business provide recurring and predictable revenue streams
with revenue of €65.9 million. Through our growth strategy, which includes both
acquisitions and organic growth initiatives, we have gone from managing 1,287,611
dwellings in France in 2018 to 1,463,402 dwellings in France as of December 31,
2020.

        - _Lease management and renting (our “LM&R business”): Through our Lease_
Management and Renting business, we manage properties on behalf of our ownerlessor customers (the lease management side of the Lease Management and Renting
business) and assist landlords and tenants throughout their rental process, including
the finding, screening and contracting of new tenants (the “renting” side of the Lease
Management and Renting business). In Lease Management, we assist landlords with
the day-to-day operations of the property, collect rent, offer financial reporting
services and advice and organize necessary maintenance for the properties. We
managed over 330,005 dwellings in France as of December 31, 2020, where we
provided recurring services for these landlords under contracts that are typically one
year in length. We also offer occupancy guarantee services to certain owner-lessors
to provide guaranteed rental income should their lessees fail to make their rental

“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of

We were founded in 1972 and have since established ourselves as the leading European RRES, with over 10,000

operations, digitization, our successful M&A track record and our IT and communications infrastructure. We
