The RRES market in the jurisdictions in which we operate remains largely fragmented. According to a
third-party report prepared in 2019 the French property management market was estimated to be worth
approximately €12 billion (excluding rental services and brokerage), of which approximately €5.3 billion was
under external management, along with an estimated €1.2 billion market for rental services. However, greater
regulation in France and the increasing need to invest in the digitization of services has made it more difficult
and time consuming for private landlords to keep property management in-house, leading to the increased
outsourcing and penetration rate of properties under external management in the residential property
management market. These trends towards increased regulation and digitization have also led to the growing
consolidation of the highly fragmented market, enabling us to capitalize on small bolt-on, strategic acquisitions
and increase our market positioning and scale. Our size provides us with a competitive advantage against
smaller and local competitors as we can industrialize processes to better leverage our cost base, replicate best
practices across our network to ensure consistent quality of service and adapt more easily to regulatory changes.
As a result, we made 61 acquisitions in the year ended December 31, 2020, both in our primary French market
and in other geographies, representing approximately 60,000 new Lease Management dwellings and
approximately 171,000 new Joint Property Management dwellings and approximately €111.0 million of
acquired revenues. We have a robust acquisition pipeline in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and
Luxembourg and a strong team of approximately 28 employees and 10 trainees dedicated to post acquisition
integration.

**Our Strengths**

**_Sector leadership focused on strongest economies in Western Europe providing competitive advantages_**

We have established ourselves as a leader for residential real estate services in France, Switzerland, Germany,
Belgium and Luxembourg by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative services uniquely suited to the
needs of our customers. As of August 2019, we were the number one player in the French real estate services
market, with approximately 13% market share, according to an international report provider. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, we managed approximately 1.8 million dwellings in France, which is approximately two
times the number of dwellings managed by our next closest competitor according to publically available
information for the year ended 2020. Outside of France, we hold leading positions in Switzerland and Germany
and have a strong presence in Belgium and Luxembourg. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we operated


-----

over 100 branches in these countries, which collectively accounted for 13% of our revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2020.

Our scale, operations and service offerings provide us with a clear competitive advantage. Our centralized
processes result in lower internal costs and enable improved customer service compared to our typically small,
individual-owned competitors. Our comprehensive range of innovative services, such as FONCIA 24/7 (our
assistance service for our joint property management customers), Prowen (our centralized energy service that
reduces client costs on gas and electricity), and Assurimo, (our real estate insurance service), differentiate us
from competitors. Our comprehensive network of over 500 branches covering all major French cities is one of
the largest offerings in the market and results in close proximity to our customers and the dwellings that we
manage; unique market positioning in negotiations with third-party repair and maintenance service suppliers
resulting in decreased costs; and financial resources that allow us to expand our customer portfolio through
acquisitions. We have been able to successfully enter markets through acquisitions and expanded our operating
geography, despite the regulatory and technological requirements that create barriers to participation in the real
estate services market. Our regional and national regulatory and real estate industry expertise and our leadership
team’s extensive experience in the real estate services industry are key to meeting and complying with such
requirements. Our strong reputation for quality and service and multi-branded strategy have also supported our
ability to grow in existing markets and enter new markets.

**_Loyal and diverse customer base and synergetic business model in a resilient market_**

Our large and diversified client base, integrated ecosystem of residential real estate services and high customer
retention rates drive a high level of recurring revenues (75% in the year ended December 31, 2020).

We have grown our diversified customer base to approximately 1.5 million dwellings in our French Joint
Property Management business and over 330,000 dwellings in our French Lease Management business as at
December 31, 2020. Through our synergetic business model, we are able to cross sell our services to our
diverse customer portfolio across our business lines, which in turn leads to further organic growth. For
example, our proven ability to cross-sell is highlighted by the high penetration rates of Assurimo, our
specialized property insurance brokerage unit (providing property insurance, homeowners’ insurance policies
and brokerage services) through which we currently provide insurance services to 61% of our French Joint
Property Management buildings. Similarly, we currently provide technical services to approximately 88% of
our Lease Management customers through our dedicated business, Constatimmo. We believe that we are well
positioned to target new customers, including B2B customers, given our knowledge regarding fulfilling
requirements for our B2C customers.

The addressable markets in which we operate are characterized by high outsourcing rates, with a high and stable
portion of joint property or condominium owners (85% in France) under external management, as of August
2019 using services like our Joint Property Management business. Property owners tend to rely on expert
services such as ours due to the volume of work and amount of legal and accounting know-how required to
directly interface with tenants and other counterparties. Moreover, landlords rarely switch leasing managers
during a tenancy, given the risks and costs involved in switching service providers and the limited potential
benefit. We believe that through the integrated ecosystem of high-quality services we consistently provide we
have established high customer retention rates, and long lasting customer relationships, certain of which last
more than 20 years. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we lost only 3.5% and 8.4% of customers from our
Joint Property Management and Lease Management businesses, respectively. Moreover, 36% of our customers
from our Joint Property Management business in France entered into contracts of three or more years and 24%
for two to three years for the year ended December 31, 2020. Due to our broad and diverse customer base, we
are not reliant on any particular customer.

According to an international report provider, the French property management market is estimated to be €12.2
billion in August 2019, of which €5.3 billion is captured by property management companies, with the rest
serviced in-house. The externally serviced property management market has grown by approximately 2%
annually between 2015 and 2019. This stable growth has been driven by population dynamics and the
construction of collective units. We continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow through acquisition of
customer portfolios, cross-selling of related services to our large client base and the addition of new revenue
opportunities for our existing services.

**_Strong and predictable cash flow generation_**

We have a track record of steady cash flow generation, driven by a high level of recurring revenues, which has
enabled us to establish a history of consistent deleveraging. Our trend of improving EBITDA conversion rates
has continued with a Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate, of approximately 76% for the year ended
December 31, 2020, compared to 71% for the year ended December 31, 2019. Despite our regular M&A
activity, our discretionary spend on acquisitions provides us with flexibility to manage our cash flow and reduce
our financial leverage. Further, our business requires limited maintenance capital expenditures, (accounting for
approximately 6% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020), and is characterized by limited working
capital requirements.

Our revenue increased at a CAGR of 5.4% and was €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 up
from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Our margin resilience is supported by an adaptable
cost structure for the more cyclical flow Brokerage business, as Brokerage salary costs include a significant
variable portion that is indexed on commissions. Our Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 26.9%, 26.8% and 22.3%
for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

Our recurring, stable revenue is in part due to our complementary business profiles across our branches,
experienced management and sales force teams, and fee-based services in connection with our Joint Property
Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses which accounted for 69% of our revenue in France
for the year ended December 31, 2020. In addition, our high proportion of recurring revenues (75% in 2020)
and balanced portfolio of services split between stock and flow businesses with limited correlation have
supported our resilience during adverse economic conditions, achieving a substantially stable performance in
2020 despite unprecedented government measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

**_Continuous investments in operational improvement through our innovative technology platforms reinforces_**
**_our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains_**

We continuously invest in cutting edge technology in order to offer the best multi-channel services to our
customers. Since 2017, we have upgraded a significant portion of our IT and communication infrastructure
including utilizing a mix of integrated and outsourced solutions, transitioning to a single telecom provider, and
streamlining our finance and human resources functions with Workday, which enabled us to quickly and
effectively transition to a work-from-home environment during the COVID-19 pandemic. We have also
leveraged our technological know-how combined with our knowledge of the real estate industry to design and
launch a go-live version of our new ERP system, Millenium, which we have piloted at one of our branches in
France in 2020. Millenium integrates all of our IT and resource planning functions into one database to better
meet our customers’ needs and address internal business challenges. Millenium increases the digitization of our
activities with the aim of helping customers by creating greater transparency and improving our operations with
standardized, digital processes to increase efficiency and to improve the speed at which we can serve our
customers. We believe our high levels of investment in IT for our corporate platform and customer interface
service such as over recent years give us a competitive edge in the current environment.

The digitization, standardization and automation offered by Millenium complement our already synergetic
business model and will allow us to more quickly leverage our customer database to identify cross-selling
opportunities leading to greater operating efficiencies and inter-business synergies. We believe that
Millenium’s compatibility with big data, AI and IoT, will allow us to explore new business opportunities and
provide access to a number of revenue-enhancing opportunities. For example, we are developing a new
operational model called “Agency of the Future” which will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real
estate services and aims at improving client satisfaction and reducing our customer churn rate, which we believe
will, in turn, lead to greater opportunities for organic growth. In addition, we believe that the gains of
Millenium and the development of Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in
2022. We have invested in, and will continue to invest in, technology to continually improve our internal
operations in order to provide our customers with product offerings that meet their needs and make us the
number one choice among residential real estate service providers.

**_Consolidation platform with proven track record of executing value accretive acquisitions to drive_**
**_incremental EBITDA growth_**

In addition to our organic growth, we maintain a successful, low-risk strategy of growth through small, bolt-on
acquisitions. We completed 220 acquisitions from January 2016 to December 2020, which represented
approximately €386.0 million of acquired revenues (including gross revenues for Leemo netted for commissions

to agents in our financial accounts). In the year ended December 31, 2020, we made 61 acquisitions in our

**_Highly experienced management team with proven execution capabilities and focus on growth and value_**

Our management team, led by our Chief Executive Officer, Philippe Salle, have significant experience in the

**Our Strategies**

**_Industry-leading technology to further reinforce our competitive advantage_**

We are committed to providing the best real estate services offerings to our customers by investing in industryleading IT and data platforms, which in turn supports our market share gains. Our most recent digital
innovation, Millenium, an in-house developed ERP system that is device-agnostic, cloud-based and driven by
artificial intelligence, will allow us to fully digitalize all of our businesses and establish a highly personalized
digital relationship with our customers. We believe that Millenium will also allow us to better, more efficiently
serve our customers, cross-sell across our platforms and therefore capture greater market share from existing
customers and generate business from new customers.

Our IT and data platforms are subject to a process of continuous improvement and innovation, which we support
with ongoing investments, such as the team of over 80 developers and specialized professional we hired to
create Millenium. We believe that our robust investments in our IT and data platforms provide us with a
significant competitive advantage, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic when businesses have been
required to transition to a work-from-home environment. Additionally, our ongoing and historical use of big
data, AI and IoT to create new business opportunities enables us to maintain a cutting edge development
program while minimizing the risks traditionally associated with experimentation. For example, we are in the
process of developing our new operational model, Agency of the Future, which we believe will generate
significant gains, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and
back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time
spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain
tasks that were previously done manually, such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges. Since 2018,
we have invested approximately €100 million into our IT projects, and we believe that the gains of Millenium
and Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in 2022.

We have developed, and continue to develop, innovative solutions based on emerging trends that are aimed at
providing our customers with the highest quality, optimal solutions for their real estate needs. We are constantly
looking for ways to improve our offerings and develop new solutions for our customers, which we expect to

**_Continue to drive organic growth and pursue targeted and opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions in core French_**

Our goal is to continue to deliver organic growth in France. We have been successful in achieving incremental

In addition, we have made, and intend to continue to make, bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market and

We have an M&A team that is dedicated to identifying growth opportunities. Our team deploys a disciplined
and systematic approach and focuses on opportunities that will enhance the offerings and services we provide in
France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg.

**_Continue to grow internationally_**

We have expanded, and plan to continue to expand, our geographic footprint in Europe, organically and through
targeted and opportunistic acquisitions. We intend to leverage our expertise and know-how as well as our
highly localized real estate providers to penetrate European markets where there is an unmet demand and an
opportunity for further expansion, as evidenced by factors such as population dynamics and the construction of
collective units, accompanied by increases in price and service level and a higher degree of outsourcing driven
by regulatory changes. We strategically pursue new markets while remaining committed to expanding in
France, Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg as these markets offer us proximity to existing
customers and expansion opportunities in countries where we have established brand recognition. We also plan
to enter European markets, where we believe local markets have strong fundamentals, such as the United
Kingdom, the Netherlands, Denmark, Scandinavian countries, Austria and various other Eastern European
countries where we aim to become the market leader. Our expertise and solutions are scalable from region to
region, and we believe that as we continue to expand, we can increase market share by deploying practices and
strategies that have proven to be successful in other markets.

**_Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) Leadership_**

We are committed to ESG matters and providing a safe and healthy environment for all of our customers and
employees. Our corporate social responsibility strategy is based on the following key commitments: supporting
sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the well-being of our customers and
our employees and ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. Our
ESG initiatives are also focused on protecting the environment while also ensuring that our operations have
minimal impact on the environment.

We also aim to work with our clients, contractors and suppliers to improve efficiency, conserve natural
resources and reduce waste and emissions. We focus on energy transition of buildings under management by
developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In 2021, we aim
to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects, partner
with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment and reduce our carbon footprint.

**History of the Group**

We were incorporated in 1972 and have since expanded our business with subsequent acquisitions of real estate
services businesses in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg and we are focused on
improving our technological capabilities in order to optimize our efficiency and overall business offering. From
January 2016 to December 2020, we have completed approximately 220 acquisitions, primarily within Joint
Property Management and Lease Management and Renting. Our external growth strategy and development of
ancillary service offerings has been a key driver to our historical growth. The following are the key milestones
in our corporate history following our foundation:

1973 - 1993 Development of an advanced computerization solution for rental management and
lettings and management of jointly owned properties, adapted to the expectations of
local real estate agents.

Launch of the first bolt-on acquisitions program aiming at expanding Foncia’s presence
in France.

2000 - 2006 International development of the group with the acquisitions of residential real estate
service companies in Switzerland, Germany and Belgium.

2013 Further development in Belgium with the acquisition of Trevi Group.

Acquisition of Tagerim’s property administration division (representing 17 agencies and
approximately 500 employees).

August 2014 Acquisition of Efficity.

July 2016 Funds advised and managed by Partners Group, leading a consortium including Caisse
de dépôt et placement du Québec (“CDPQ”) and CIC Capital Corporation, signed a
Share Purchase Agreement to acquire 100% of the shares of Foncia from Bridgepoint
and Eurazeo. Completion of the sale took place on September 7, 2016.

September 2016 Acquisition of Icade Property Management, which was folded into the Esset brand in
December 2019.

October 2018 Acquisition of Lodgis.

October 2018 Strengthening of our position in Germany with the acquisition of Bautra’s Property
Management business.

September 2019 Organization of the first general meeting of joint property owners online with Fuze.

March-May 2020 During the first pandemic lockdown and while the agencies were closed to the public,
our teams remained available to assist customers using digital tools and ensuring
business continuity.

June 2020 Announcement of the beginning of our digital transformation in the management of
jointly owned properties and rental management, to strengthen responsiveness,
transparency and expertise in the service.

September 2020 Creation of Foncia’s RRES premium division, to develop its premium offer for property
management activities in France.

December 2020 Acquisition of OP in Belgium and Luxembourg.

**Our Businesses**

We are the European leader in the RRES market, serving customers in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium
and Luxembourg. We maintain an integrated business model with operations across a wide range of businesses,
with recognized brand names in the countries in which we operate. Our unique business model provides for
cross-selling opportunities, which help us achieve recurring and predictable revenues and strong cash flows.

**_Residential Real Estate Services (France)_**

The residential real estate services in France, operating primarily under the Foncia brand, represented 60% of
our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020, and 61% of our total revenue generated in France for


-----

the year ended December 31, 2019. Revenue from this business primarily comprises (i) jointly owned property
management fees, (ii) rental management fees (including rent payment and occupancy guarantee fees), and (iii)
letting fees, which allow us to maintain stable revenues.

_Management of Jointly Owned Properties_

In our Joint Property Management business, we assist our customers in managing common building areas,
features and costs in their jointly owned properties by providing technical and accounting management. These
management services include (i) providing information and communicating on a regular basis with the joint
property owners, (ii) organizing and managing general meetings of joint property owners by preparing the
agenda, summons, minutes, etc., (iii) managing the upkeep of the joint property as a whole, (iv) controlling costs
by drawing up a budget, (v) obtaining bids from potential suppliers, (vi) providing a breakdown of joint property
charges, (vii) collecting funds and amounts due for the joint property accounts, (viii) providing bookkeeping
services, (ix) monitoring contract performance, and (x) providing mass procurement offers for joint property
owners and leveraging our large purchasing power to offer attractive prices to our customers on expenses such
as gas and other utilities. We also provide direct access to all Foncia services on a unique customer portal,
MyFoncia, and offer around-the-clock customer service.

From a contractual and legal perspective, our Joint Property Management business is conducted primarily
through mandates. We take the role of trustee (syndic) after appointment by the homeowners’ board or general
assembly of joint owners. We calculate fees on a flat-rate basis, which leads to relatively stable and recurring
revenue. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property
association, including (i) preparing, convening and organizing general meetings, (ii) managing the joint owners’
council or general assembly (iii) managing the financial operations, including bill payments and collection of
building fees, (iv) keeping the accounts of the jointly owned property association (v) managing the jointly
owned property in compliance with its rules and regulations and (vi) carrying out periodic visits and inspections
of the jointly owned property. We also receive additional incidental fees such as transfer fees when a landlord
selling a dwelling requires a book balance report called a “transfer report,” reminder fees, fees on
insurance-related claim management services, maintenance and repair commissions on third parties invoices and
additional post office charges. These variable fees comprise 23% of our total Joint Property Management fees
for the year ended December 31, 2020.

All such services are treated as an overall performance. These different services are associated with a single
performance obligation, i.e., the management of the jointly owned property association. Incidental services may
be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service.

As of December 31, 2020, we had 1,463,402 dwellings under our management of jointly owned properties,
generating a revenue of €290.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, representing 30% of our total
revenue for the same period.

_Lease Management and Renting_

Our Lease Management and Renting business is comprised of Lease Management and rental services.

On the Lease Management side of the business, we manage an owner’s-lessor’s rented apartment and provide
assistance on the day-to-day operations of the property, typically related to financial management, legal
assistance and handling conflicts. We are appointed by the owner of the individual unit, typically a private
landlord, and we act as agent for owners-lessors to fulfil a number of contractually defined obligations in this
regard. These key services primarily include: (i) routine management services such as rent reviews and
collection, annual adjustment invoice for expenses, and sending rent receipts and deposits to lessees, (ii) other
one-off management services, including preparation of the lease contract, inventory of premises, compilation of
documentation, management of claims, administrative filings and requests for subsidies, (iii) technical
management services, such as coordinating on-site repairs, mandatory technical surveys and preparation of
essential information documents for lessees, (iv) insurance against unpaid rent and (v) other insurance such as
for vacant premises or property damage.

Lease Management fees are comprised of a base fee for the contracted services described above and, in some
instances, other additional fees such as fees in connection with helping file tax forms or fees related to rent
payment guarantees. We offer rent payment guarantees (“Garantie de loyers impayés” or “rent payment
guarantee”) to certain residential landlords in France for whom we provide property management services and
an occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation” or “occupancy guarantee”) to a small number of lessors to


-----

protect against vacant properties for up to six months if we are unable to find a tenant for selected apartments in
new dwellings. In December 2020, approximately 66% of residential dwellings in France were covered by the
rent payment guarantee, and approximately 12% of rentals are covered by the occupancy guarantee. We believe
we have a strong ability to assess credit risk when offering these guarantees and undertake a detailed process to
select eligible tenants and dwellings. We refer to the new unpaid rents as a result of defaults under the
occupancy guarantee each month as “flow of unpaid rent,” and the total sum of unpaid rents per month as our
“stock of unpaid rent.”

In December 2020, €124.7 million of rent revenues were covered by the rent payment guarantee, for which we
experienced €3.5 million unpaid rent (for a 2020 average new monthly aggregate of unpaid rent of €3.3 million)
and the cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent was €27.7 million, including outstanding rent payments from
previous years. Once rent is reported as unpaid, any payments to landlords under these guarantees are recorded
in full as a provision on our balance sheet. By underwriting rent payment guarantees and occupancy guarantees
on our own balance sheet, we believe we offer a differentiating and competitive service to customers that
smaller competitors would not be able to deliver. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Rent payment and_
_occupancy guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Low demand for_
_housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income_
_produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial_
_condition or results of operations.”_

As of December 31, 2020, we had 330,005 dwellings under management in our Lease Management and Renting
business, generating a revenue of €283.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, representing 30% of
our total revenue for the same period (this includes Foncia Immo Neuf, CAI and Holiday Rental). Revenues are
driven by rent evolution, fees as a percent of rent (on units acquired), and add-on services and volumes are
driven by apartments under lease management and tenant mobility rates. We operate primarily in the residential
real estate services market, but manage certain commercial real estate properties through Esset. See “—Other
_Services (France).”_

Through our renting services, we aim to minimize the vacancy rates of the properties by helping landlords find a
suitable tenant and helping tenants find a property to rent. For landlords, we manage the sourcing, screening,
and contracting of new tenants, and provide services such as posting advertisements on various real estate
portals, showcasing their properties in Foncia branches and providing structured feedback on renting efforts.
For tenants, we assist lessees with leasing rental properties and we receive one-off placement fees for these
services. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we assisted with 59,288 rentals. Our services include access
to a large number of rental home insurance packages and fixture inventory programs offered by professionals
who are available on short notice.

**_Brokerage (France)_**

We completed over 13,763 transactions across France in the year ended December 31, 2020 and support our
customers with all aspects of their property sales or purchases. Once we receive a mandate, we follow the sale
through to completion. Our services include property viewings and search services, advice and assistance with
banking and administrative formalities, property appraisals, buyer solvency assessments, market analysis,
assistance complying with regulatory requirements, and drafting sale agreements. Our Brokerage business is
conducted primarily through mandates, exclusive or shared, and fees for such mandate in the event of a
transaction are calculated on a flat-rate basis. This rate usually comprises an average of 5.18% of the selling
price of the property. Revenue are recognized upon signature of the notarized final sale agreement (acte
_authentique). For further discussion on notary execution, see “Regulation.”_

Our Brokerage business provides ample opportunities for cross-selling services, such as property appraisals,
brokerage insurance, technical surveys, and inventories services provided by our other businesses. See “—Other
_Services (France).” Our Brokerage business in France generated a revenue of €125.0 million for the year ended_
December 31, 2020, representing 13% of our total revenue for the same period.

**Digital Transformation and IT Systems**

Digital transformation is at the heart of our operations and we believe it will improve the efficiency of our
operations and commercial development, while providing unique and differentiated services to customers. From


-----

inception, we have appreciated the importance of creating an efficient platform in order to better serve our
customers, and understand the dynamics of our market and improve our employees responsiveness and
efficiency. IT systems impact virtually all aspects of our business, including record keeping, customer
information processing and storage, data security, marketing and sales, compliance logistics, and practice and
performance management. Our IT strategy is driven by the dual goals of promoting growth of our business
while ensuring data security.

Our most recent digital innovation is Millenium, our new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system that we
developed in-house, and we launched a go-live version of it in March 2020 at one of our branches in France.
We have invested significant resources in Millenium, including a team of 80 developers and specialized
professionals in order to build this innovative and advanced real estate platform, and we aim to roll it out across
our branches in France in 2022.

Millenium includes numerous functionalities and unifies a number of our IT functions at our head office under
one centralized database. It is managed by an experienced team of information specialists. Business
applications for each of our activities have been developed with Millenium, including our Joint Property
Management business, Lease Management and Renting business, and Brokerage Business, as well as our
accounting department, support call center and web and mobile applications. Millenium is equipped with an
application interface program, which is a technology that allows for a direct access to other software solutions,
startups, and business partners. For example, Millenium is connected to Kyriba, an online platform for viewing
bank transaction in real time, which we use to manage our Joint Property Management cash transactions
involving approximately 116,000 bank accounts. Millenium also functions with Docapost, an online,
information technology company, which we utilize to collect and scan checks, and send and receive
approximately 8.8 million letters and invoices per year.

Millenium will provide, among other features, (i) increased digitization of activities, including the ability to use
online signatures and receive digital payments, (ii) greater transparency with our customers, as employee
progress on customer matters can be seen in real time and customer calls are tracked using tickets, (iii)
significant automation of the accounting activities, (iv) the ability to better leverage our customer database to
create inter-business synergies in compliance with European GDPR regulations, and (v) standardized processes
across our businesses and substantial efficiencies due to a high degree of automation. Millenium also includes
MyFoncia, a web and mobile app platform designed to improve customer experience through automation,
digitization, and improved productivity for our customers to use for all of their service needs.

In parallel to the deployment of Millenium, we are in the process of designing a new operational model called
Agency of the Future which will be implemented following the roll-out of Millenium in France in 2022.
Agency of the Future will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real estate services and aims to improve
client satisfaction, reducing our customer churn rate and, in turn, leading to greater opportunities for organic
growth. See “Summary—Our Strengths—Continuous investments in operational improvement through our
_innovative technology platforms reinforces our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains.”_

In the coming years, we plan to fully digitalize all business lines, internal processes, and our customer
relationship management. In addition, we aim to increase our use of big data, artificial intelligence and IoT and
continue to further automate our accounting. We believe that the improved standardization and digitization
Millenium offers, will allow us to reduce administrative inefficiencies and achieve greater productivity. In
addition, we believe that Millenium will enable us to achieve greater organization among our businesses
allowing our employees to focus on customer satisfaction with the potential to lead to improved customer
retention. It may also lead to new business opportunities, which could include big data or machine learning and
licensing opportunities.

**Corporate Social Responsibility**

We service the homes of more than 4.7 million people in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and, more
recently, Luxembourg. As a key local player, we are committed to sustainable housing improved well-being,
and better living for our customers, tenants, residents, communities, and other stakeholders in the residential real
estate sector. We achieve this through our corporate social responsibility strategy, which is based on three key
commitments: supporting sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the wellbeing of our customers in ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local
communities.


-----

From this mission stems the responsibility to provide solutions to environmental and social issues in our sector,
and to contribute to more sustainable lifestyles. We have developed a number of ESG initiatives that measure
and aim to improve on annual basis. For example, track our carbon footprint and aim to reduce it each year.
We also closely consider the impact that our clients, contractors and suppliers have on the environment and we
aim to work with those who seek to improve efficiency, conserve natural resources and reduce waste and
emissions. In addition, we focus on energy transition of buildings under management by developing services
and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In 2021, one of our goals related to
corporate social responsibility is to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead
such renovation projects and partner with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the
environment.

**_Sustainable Real Estate_**

The real estate sector is responsible for approximately 25% of greenhouse gas emissions in France and plays a
decisive role in the fight against climate change. The environmental impact of a building is influenced by three
factors, including: (i) the performance of the building itself; (ii) the management and the maintenance of its
equipment; and (iii) occupant behaviors. Our objective is to improve our impact on the environment and our
commitment is driven by these three factors. We are focused on promoting energy renovation, developing more
sustainable building management by measuring the energy consumption of our park and setting targets to
improve future performance, raising awareness, and supporting our customers in making better use of resources.

**_Our Commitments to Local Communities_**

We have over 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and 242
branches dedicated to both businesses throughout France and over 101 branches in Switzerland, Germany, and
Belgium and, by the nature of our activity, we aim to contribute to the economic development of the
communities in which we operate. We wish to assume and reaffirm our role as a partner and supporter of our
customers and other stakeholders at the local and national levels, and aim to accomplish this through a number
of measures. For example, by strengthening and enhancing our territorial anchoring, focusing on our
recruitment efforts, concentrating on our choice of and support from our suppliers and reinforcing our
commitment as a good corporate citizen. We also seek to develop a dialogue with our stakeholders and improve
our communication on topics of interest to our stakeholders.

**Well-being of our Customers and Employees**

We are aware of the rapid changes in lifestyles and ways of living in Europe, and we aim to actively contribute
to the improvement of the quality of life of our customers and our employees. This involves securing not only a
healthy living and working environment, but also a better understanding of the societal transformations at work
including developments in the digital space, new uses, and the development of associated responses. Finally,
we believe a commitment to quality of life also implies implementing concrete actions against discrimination,
particularly in terms of access to housing and the fight against absentee landlords.

**European Laws and Regulations**

**_Data Protection_**

We acquire and process personal data on customers and customers during the course of our activities and our
databases contain personal data of customers and customers. Our ability to obtain, retain and process such
personal data is governed by data protection and privacy regulations and guidance issued by, among others, the
European Union, national regulators and, where applicable, recommendations and best practices developed by
trade associations.

The EU General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (“GDPR”)) became effective as of
May 25, 2018. The GDPR provides a common framework for data protection and privacy and regulates the
Processing and transfer of Personal Data in the European Union. In the course of our activities, we may be
qualified as “Controllers,” or as “Processor,” as defined and governed by GDPR, depending on the services
provided and the service agreement entered into.

We established our compliance program with GDPR quite early and we comply with the GDPR obligations, and
rights for individuals whose Personal Data we Process (“Data Subjects”), including, among others:

    - accountability and transparency obligations, requiring us to demonstrate and record
compliance with the GDPR, including the maintenance of detailed records of Personal Data
Processing activities;

    - appointment of a data protection officer, subject to the satisfaction of certain criteria;

    - requirements to Process Personal Data lawfully, fairly, and in a transparent manner, to Process
Personal Data only to the extent necessary for the purposes required, maintain the accuracy of
Personal Data, limit the retention of Personal Data for no longer than is necessary, and
maintain appropriate technical and organizational security measures against unauthorized
Processing or accidental loss, destruction or damage to Personal Data;

    - an obligation to provide clear notice of Personal Data Processing activities to Data Subjects,
which must include, among other details: the identity of the Controller and the Processor; the
nature and purpose of the Processing activities; the legal basis applicable to each Processing
activity; the categories of Personal Data Processed, the recipients to whom the Personal Data
are disclosed; the rights of the Data Subjects; and details of any cross-border transfers of
Personal Data;

    - an obligation to include certain mandatory contractual terms in agreements with certain
service providers which Process Personal Data on our behalf;

    - restrictions on the export of Personal Data to recipients located in countries outside of the
European Economic Area;


-----

    - requirements to ensure, for each Processing activity, that either (i) there is a valid legal basis
in place; or (ii) an exemption or derogation applies;

    - obligations to consider data protection issues with respect to the development of any new
products or services which involve the Processing of Personal Data (“data protection by
design”), and to ensure that by default, the amount of Personal Data Processed is limited to
what is necessary in the context of the relevant Processing activity (“data protection by
default”);

    - a requirement to undertake a data protection impact assessment with respect to Processing
activities that are likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of relevant Data
Subjects;

    - obligations to comply with the data protection rights conferred on Data Subjects including, in
certain circumstances: a right of access to, and rectification of, Personal Data; a right to obtain
restriction of Processing; a right to object to Processing; a right to request that Personal Data
be transferred to another Controller; a right not to be subject to certain types of profiling or
automated decision-making; and a right to request erasing Personal Data; and

    - an obligation to notify Personal Data Breaches to Supervisory Authorities without undue delay
and no later than 72 hours after detection of the relevant Personal Data Breach, except where
the Personal Data Breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of
individuals, and an obligation to notify affected Data Subjects without undue delay, unless the
Personal Data Breach is unlikely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of the
affected Data Subjects.

The GDPR has therefore strengthened the individual rights of individuals over their personal data and imposes
strict requirements on companies processing personal data.

In addition, the GDPR introduces fines for serious breaches of up to the higher of 4% of annual worldwide
revenue or €20 million. The GDPR identifies a list of points to consider when determining the fine level to
impose (including the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement). Data Subjects also have a right to
compensation for financial or non-financial losses (e.g., distress) in certain circumstances. Data Subjects may
bring complaints via the courts, or via Supervisory Authorities, or both, and in some circumstances may have a
choice as to the EU Member State(s) in which they bring such claims.

We accomplished a review of our data polices with the aim of minimizing data collection and storage so that
only the appropriate amount of personal data required for any particular purpose is processed, and establishing
protocols to destroy unnecessary datasets and anonymize data wherever possible. In addition, we have put in
place and implemented rules, policies and procedures that we strive to maintain and improve, in order to ensure
compliance with GDPR. These rules, policies and procedures are twofold: internal and external. These rules,
policies and procedures, implemented at all levels of our business, apply to the processing of personal data, data
storage, retention, preservation, maintenance, protection and management of personal data within the course of
our business operations, as well as the transfer of personal data. Our legal team was intensely involved in the
implementation of such rules, policies and procedures and reviewed our activities and operations to implement a
legal framework that complies with the GDPR requirements.

We believe that we are compliant in all material respects with applicable data protection regulations and we
submitted all the relevant declarations to the national regulators, the CNIL (Commission Nationale de
_l’Informatique et des Libertés) in France and the BfDI (Der Bundesbeauftragte für den Datenschutz und die_
_Informationsfreiheit) in Germany and the APD (Autorité de protection des données) in Belgium. We have_
appointed a Data Protection Officer, who is registered with the relevant regulator and who is in charge of all
aspects of GDPR for the applicable country and, in particular, maintains data processing registers.

As used herein, “Personal Data” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, “Personal Data Breach” has the meaning
set out in the GDPR, and “Processing” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, and the terms “Process” and
“Processed” shall be construed accordingly.

**_Anti-money Laundering_**

As part of certain operations, we follow anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing standards set
forth in the applicable local laws implementing Directive (EU) 2005/60/EC on the prevention of the use of the
financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing. Our operations are also subject to
requirements of local anti-money laundering laws. On May 20, 2015, Directive (EU) 2015/849 on the
prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing,
amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012, and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC (the “4th AML Directive”) was
adopted by the European Parliament and the Council. The 4th AML Directive enhances the current customer
due diligence requirements and also imposes stricter sanctions with administrative fines of at least €5,000,000 or
10% of total annual turnover.

Directive (EU) 2018/843 (the “5th AML Directive”), amending the 4th AML Directive, was adopted by the
European Parliament and the Council on May 30, 2018 and since then Directive (EU) 2018/1673 (the “6th AML
Directive”) has been introduced and went into effect for EU Member States on December 3, 2020.

**France**

As a real estate business operating in France with a primary focus on residential real estate property
management and real estate property transaction brokerage, we are subject to the general application of the laws
and regulations provided below. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our
_businesses, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or_
_regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with_
_laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur_
_significant financial penalties.”_

**_Hoguet_**

The Hoguet law (Loi n°70-9 réglementant les conditions d’exercice des activités relatives à certaines opérations
portant sur les immeubles et les fonds de commerce) was introduced in January 1970 and aimed at setting the
legal framework for the profession of real estate agents in France and therefore applies to all of our employees
who act as real estate agents on our behalf. The Hoguet law requires the execution of specific administrative
formalities to be a professional real estate agent including:

    - holding a professional card (“carte professionnelle”) issued by the president of the territorial
chamber of commerce and industry, which is subject to professional aptitude and morality
conditions and is renewable every 3 years;

    - having a financial guarantee from a bank or professional organization for funds held in
customer accounts and retaining professional liability insurance.

In accordance with this law, we provide financial guarantees to customers equal to the maximum amount of
funds held in their account. The customer’s deposit must be held in a third-party account and be guaranteed by
a third party financial guarantor, such as Société de caution mutuelle des professions immobilières et foncières
(SOCAF). This body guarantees reimbursement of any funds deposited with them for purchase. The name of
the financial guarantor must be displayed in the agents office.

Professional real estate agents must have a written mandate authorizing them to negotiate or enter into contracts
on behalf of the owner or the property lessor. This mandate must therefore be finalized before any act of
mediation or negotiation begins. This mandate must indicate the level of the fees or commission (honoraires)
that will be payable and just who will pay it, the buyer or the seller. We maintain a register of such agreements
with each agreement numbered and recorded in accordance with the Hoguet Law.

Once the mandate is signed, the real estate agent is entitled to a commission in the event of the sale or lease of
the property, subject to the mandate. The real estate agent’s right to commission is subject to multiple
conditions and no sum of money may be demanded or remitted to the real estate agent before the transaction
(i.e. sale, rental, etc.) is concluded and recorded in an act containing the commitment of the parties. The
collection of a sum of money in violation of the Hoguet law is an offense punishable by up to two years’
imprisonment and a maximum fine of €30,000.


-----

**_ALUR_**

The ALUR law (Loi n°2014-366 pour l’accès au logement et un urbanisme rénové) was introduced in
March, 2014 and aimed at improving access to housing and providing increased protection to tenants in the
housing market within large cities and urban areas of France. The introduction of the ALUR law has had a
number of effects in the way we conduct our operations across our core service offerings, including:

    - _Joint property management: The_ ALUR law imposes a mandatory obligation on us as joint
property managers to register each joint property we manage with the national matriculation
register if not yet registered and also requires us to create two dedicated bank accounts for
each joint property we manage. The law also introduces model joint property agreements that
are applicable in our joint property management service.

    - _Rental management and lettings: The ALUR law regulates which fees can and cannot be_
charged to tenants and how fees should be shared between tenants and landlords. Depending
on the property’s location, it imposes a limit on the renting commission paid by tenants to an
amount that must not exceed between €11-€15 per square meter. In addition to this fee cap,
tenants can no longer be charged penalties for breaches to rental agreements or for rent
payment notices. The law also introduced restrictions on the yearly rental escalations for
residential properties in Paris. It also standardized certain administrative requirements for
rental contracts through means such as model contracts and rental declaration forms for
residential lettings.

**_ELAN_**

The ELAN law (Loi n°2018-1021 _portant évolution du logement, de l’aménagement et du numérique) was_
introduced in November 2018 and aimed to build more housing, simplify standards, protect the most fragile
tenants and to introduce digital transitions in the service of tenants. The law created a new lease called a
“mobility lease,” which is a non-renewable lease between one to ten months for certain categories of tenants,
such as students and trainees, with flexible termination terms that allow the termination of a lease by the tenant
upon the provision of only one months’ notice. Within municipalities of more than 50,000 inhabitants, where
there is an imbalance between the supply and demand of housing, the law also imposes an obligation on
landlords to set their rent within a range defined by the authorities each year. The introduction of the ELAN law
has had a number of effects in the way we conduct our operations across our core service offerings, as it created
an incentive for short-term rentals which may reduce the predictability of our revenue.

**_PINEL_**

The PINEL plan refers to multiple laws introduced since 2014, which aimed to design and promote the
construction of new build properties in designated areas. The PINEL plan provided income tax deductions to
private individuals who invested in these new build properties, provided the properties were put up for rent for
at least six years. This plan has had a direct impact on fees that property managers can charge for their services.
For example, it restricts the freedom of the landlord and tenant to contract with regards to expenses which
cannot be recovered from tenants. Non-recoverable expenses include structural repairs and repairs under article
606 of the French Civil Code, taxes such as the “Territorial Economic Contribution” where the landlord is
personally liable for payment and the management fees of the landlord linked to rents management. As a result,
landlords are no longer able to recover fees from tenants for certain expenses for major repairs, regional
economic contribution taxes and fees related to rental management.

The PINEL plan also introduced rules governing commercial leases including rules limiting the ability of a
landlord to impose rental increases and granting tenants a right of first refusal in the event of the sale of leased
commercial property. The plan provides for the mandatory use of national indexes provided by the national
statistics bureau of France (INSEE) for the calculation of revised rents for commercial activity premises and is
applicable during the life of the lease.

**_Eviction Laws and the Winter Truce_**

_Eviction Laws_

On July 9, 1991 a new law (Loi n° 91-650 du 9 juillet 1991 portant réforme des procédures civiles d’exécution)
introduced the eviction regime into the law of civil enforcement proceedings. This law introduces, in article


-----

L411-1 of the Code of Civil Enforcement Procedures (code de procédure civile), the condition that an eviction
can only take place by virtue of a court decision where the occupiers were notified. A tenant can be evicted for
failure to pay the rent when due and also for breaches of lease agreements. In the event that the tenant fails to
pay rent, the landlord is required to follow various mandatory steps, including filing of a payment instruction
notice (Commandement de payer). This notice sets a time limit for a tenant to pay the outstanding rental and
must delivered by a bailiff (huissier de justice). The time limits provided by this notice are two months for a
residential lease and one month for a commercial lease. If the tenant fails to pay the rental arears within the
stipulated time, the landlord can apply to the court for the cancellation of the lease. Upon the determination of
the court proceedings, the court will often provide for an installment payment of the rent arrears and stipulate
that the tenant voluntarily move out within a period of two months. The bailiff and the police will forcibly
remove the tenant if the tenant fails to move out within this period.

_Winter Truce_

The winter truce is the period during which any tenant eviction measure is suspended. This rule was introduced
on July 9, 1991 (Loi n° 91-650 du 9 juillet 1991 portant réforme des procédures civiles d’exécution). The
regime provides that a landlord can begin proceedings during the winter truce to seek to evict tenants who do
not pay rent, or who refuse to leave after receiving the contractual notice period. However, eviction requires a
court order from a judge, which can be appealed by the tenant. Once a final judgment is made, the landlord is
able to give an eviction order to the tenant with a minimum notice period of at least two months for the tenant to
vacate the leased premises (the length of this period will depend on the court order). Notwithstanding the
foregoing, the eviction of the tenant cannot take place during the winter truce, which is in effect between
November 1 and March 1 of the following year.

In 2014, the ALUR law expanded the winter truce period to five full months, from November 1 to March 31 of
the following year. This period was extended to July 10 as an exceptional measure for 2020 only, as part of the
emergency measures taken by the French government in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

**_Management of Rents Deposits_**

In France, the parties are free to enter into any agreed terms regarding rental deposits. The terms of the deposit
should explain what the deposit is expected to cover. For example, the rental deposit terms can provide that the
rent, repairs, service charge, dilapidations and rates are covered. These terms could also be widely drafted to
cover any liabilities owed by the tenant at the end of the tenancy. The amount of the deposit is, in part,
regulated by the law which provides that the maximum amount of the deposit for unfurnished properties will be
one month, with no maximum for furnished properties.

The rent deposit paid at the beginning of the tenancy must be refunded at the end of the rental period. The
landlord or their representative has one month to refund the security deposit if the final inventory is consistent
with the initial inventory and if there is no outstanding rent or tax to be paid. This period may be extended to
two months if there are differences between the initial and final inventories. The time frame to refund the
deposit begins on the day the tenant returns the keys for the premises (in person or by registered letter with
acknowledgement of receipt).

In the event the security deposit is not refunded, the outgoing tenant must send a formal demand to the landlord
by registered letter with acknowledgement of receipt. If, despite this action being taken, the landlord refuses to
refund the security deposit, the tenant can refer the case to the regional mediation commission (Commission
_Départementale de Conciliation). If this mediation process proves unsuccessful, the tenant can then go before_
the small-claims court (juge de proximité) if the value of the claim is less than €4,000, or the district court
(tribunal d’instance). If the amount of the security deposit exceeds €4,000, the tenant must send an assignation,
which will be prepared and delivered by a bailiff to the landlord.

Notes Issuer and allows the chief executive officer to communicate with the top 200 managers of the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer on the overall financial and operational situation of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer on a
monthly basis. The Leaders Committee meets once each year and allows for the top management of the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer to keep an efficient and relevant information flow within the various operational entities of
the Senior Secured Notes Issuer.
