###### Capitalization of non-deducted financial expenses 
 Deferred tax assets were recognised in the period in respect of carry-forwards of interest from the tax consolidation group within the scope of the EU Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD I), of which €3.9 million in respect of financial expenses not deducted in 2020 and €3.9 million in respect of financial expenses not deducted in 2019. These deferred taxes were recognised against the taxable temporary difference relating to the Foncia trademark for €354.7 million.
 Tax loss carry-forwards 
 Tax loss carry-forwards within the tax consolidation group at 31 December 2020 are as follows (after utilisation in the current period):

 • Loss arising on tax consolidation: €12.9 million. This tax loss has been recognised in full in view of the high probability that sufficient future taxable profit will exist against which it can be utilised. 

 • Proprietary tax losses of consolidated companies (arising prior to joining the tax consolidation group): €29.2 million, of which €28.9 million not recognised due to the improbability that sufficient future taxable earnings will be available against which the losses could be utilised (of which Foncia Holding for €8.9 million, IDHA for €4.8 million, Syndic+ for €2.8 million and Bourgeois Immobilier for €2.7 million).
 At 31 December 2020, deferred tax assets recognised in respect of tax loss carry-forwards chiefly concern tax consolidation arrangements (€3.3 million), proprietary tax losses of companies in the tax consolidation group (€0.1 million), Efficity (€0.9 million) and Yxime (€1.1 million). 
 Deferred tax on temporary differences 

 Deferred taxes on temporary differences mainly arise on provisions for employee profit-sharing and paid leave, acquisition-related fees, and the tax treatment of translation adjustments. 

 Deferred tax on other adjustments 

 Changes in deferred taxes on other adjustments are mainly attributable to changes in the scope of consolidation (€8.1 million) and reflect the cancellation of existing business goodwill in the individual statement of financial position of companies consolidated for the first time during the period.

###### Bank borrowings 

 The Group carried out several operations on its revolving credit facility (RCF) in 2020: 

 • On 19 and 24 March 2020, the Group drew a total of €190 million on its facility (to secure the Group’s cash resources in the context of the Covid crisis).
 • In June 2020, it repaid the €190 million drawn, which was partially refinanced by two additional drawdowns: €60 million on 19 June 2020 and €30 million on 24 June 2020. These two drawdowns totalling €90 million were also repaid in September 2020.
 • Three additional drawdowns, amounting to €60 million (21 September 2020), €60 million (21 October 2020) and €100 million (23 November 2020) were made and later repaid, on 21 October, 23 November and 23 December 2020, respectively.
 • In all at 31 December 2020, the Group had utilised a total of €120 million of the revolving credit facility, including €20 million drawn on 18 December 2020 and €100 million on 23 December 2020. These two drawdowns will be repaid in January 2021.

 It should also be noted that the full 2018 CICE prefinancing credit was refunded in 2020 in an amount of €8.2 million.

 Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €8 million chiefly result from borrowings and debt taken on from Gérance de Passy (€3.3 million) and Foncia IAG (€1.5 million). Debt relating to Bourgeois Immobilier was repaid in the period in an amount of €1.1 million.

 To mitigate the economic and financial consequences of the Covid-19 crisis, Efficity contracted a government-backed one-year cash loan for €1.4 million. This loan was repaid ahead of maturity in December 2020.

 Liabilities relating to put options on non-controlling interests

 As described in the “Highlights of the year” section, on 25 February 2020 the Group exercised its call option on the Trévi group, acquiring 8% of the shares it did not already own in the group for a total purchase consideration of €2.7 million. The full amount of the liability relating to the put option granted to non-controlling interests was therefore reversed.

 Shareholder loan

 Interest on the shareholder loan is capitalised at a rate of 11.7%. The Group repaid €16 million of its shareholder loan on 13 November 2020. 

 Update on the financial liabilities recognised in respect of the preferred shares issued within the scope of the Leemo/Primonial transaction:

 As described in the “Highlights of the year” section, the €7 million financial liability was reset to zero against income amounting to €7 million recorded in non-recurring operating items (see Note 2.4).

###### The actuarial estimate of provisions for retirement benefits and long-service awards was based on the report drawn up by Mercer and Eactuary, the firms mandated to estimate post-employment benefit obligations for the entire Group. A provision is set aside for all outstanding obligations, estimated based on rights accrued and salary projections, taking into account mortality rates, employee turnover and a discount. 
 For France, the increase in provisions for retirement benefits is mainly attributable to the service cost totalling €1.4 million, reflecting the increase in the net obligation resulting from the contributions of Foncia personnel in 2020. 
 These actuarial gains are recognised in other comprehensive income within consolidated equity net of tax. 
 The increase in obligations in respect of long-service awards can be chiefly explained by the service cost in 2020 (€0.7 million) and by the measurement of employee benefit obligations taken on as a result of the acquisitions of Yxime and Gérance de Passy (€0.2 million). The take-up rate for long-service awards was maintained at 100%.
 Obligations in respect of long-service awards are included within other long-term benefits in accordance with IAS 19. Any related actuarial gains and losses are taken to profit or loss in the period.
 In Switzerland, the increase in the net benefit obligation in the period is essentially due to the service cost of CHF 4.5 million (€4.2 million) as well as net actuarial losses amounting to CHF 0.4 million (€0.3 million).

###### Provisions for other disputes 
 In France, this caption relates mainly to the provision for disputes with franchisees amounting to €0.5 million, and to the provision for the Corum dispute amounting to €0.6 million. Outside France, this caption chiefly concerns Switzerland (€1.8 million), where the miscellaneous long-standing risks are monitored by the local management team.

 ▪ Update on the dispute with franchisees

 By way of a reminder, in 2014 franchisees had brought proceedings against the Foncia Group after receiving notice that their contracts would not be renewed. They accused the Group of wrongful termination and various breaches of the franchise agreements. Of the 21 initial lawsuits, the Group either settled (most sensitive disputes), or won (before the lower court or on appeal) the cases. Only seven lawsuits are still in progress following the appeal to the French Supreme Court (Cour de cassation). In January 2020, an initial decision was handed down in favour of Foncia Franchise by the court of appeal to which the case was referred after the Supreme Court appeal, in which that court dismissed all of the franchisee’s claims (including those that had been successful in the first instance). However, the franchisee has re-filed an appeal to the French Supreme Court. Hearings are pending before the referral court of appeal for the six other lawsuits (hearings scheduled for between January and April 2021 unless postponed due to Covid-19). Six decisions are pending from the court of appeal, and one from the French Supreme Court.

 ▪ Update on the Corum dispute

 After having terminated its distribution agreement with Primaliance, Corum, a property manager, brought proceedings against Primaliance for trademark infringement for continuing to list the real estate investment trust (SCPI) Corum Origin on its website, www.primaliance.com. The dispute is in progress before the courts. The Group maintained its €0.8 million provision in this respect and did not transfer it to Primaliance when the latter was sold to Bienprévoir.fr. Following some procedural issues in 2019 and 2020, the case is still ongoing and a date for the oral arguments is pending.

###### This caption mainly comprises a contingency provision recognised in relation to a tax dispute concerning VAT arising in connection with the acquisition of Esset Management in 2016 for a total amount of €0.3 million at 31 December 2020. This provision was adjusted in the year and an amount of €0.3 million was written back and recorded within non-recurring items. 
 Provisions for rent payment guarantees 
 The technical increase in these provisions in the period chiefly results from the extension of the “winter truce” (tenant protection period during winter months applicable in France) to July 2020, which automatically increased the average age of past-due amounts owed by current tenants and made it impossible for the Group to bring proceedings against those tenants. New bad debts arising in the period remained broadly stable. 
 It should be recalled that the amount of the provision set aside by the Group increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated). 
 Provisions for employee disputes 
 In France, the provision remained stable in 2020 at €3.6 million, and concerned 101 lawsuits at end-December 2020 compared to 98 lawsuits at 31 December 2019. Out of the 101 lawsuits, 100 are in progress and 25 relate to amounts in excess of €0.1 million. 

 The increase in the period is mainly attributable to Germany, where provisions were recognised for a total of €1 million in respect of restructuring in progress (notably at Präzisa for €0.5 million and Foncia Deutschland for €0.3 million).

###### Earn-out liabilities 
 An earn-out clause was set up in first-half 2018 with the founders and key managers of Efficity. The additional consideration payable is calculated based on the value creation generated by the business (EBITDA multiple). 
 VAT 
 Input and therefore output VAT (see Note 4.7) increased sharply in 2020, owing to the fact that certain internal transactions were not settled in the year. These positions will be reset in 2021 once the corresponding intra-group invoices have been paid. 
 Outstanding purchase consideration payable 
 At 31 December 2020, outstanding purchase consideration payable chiefly concerns Esset Management for €12 million (Yxime), Foncia Haut de France for €4.1 million (Sigla) and Foncia Toulouse for €2.9 million (Loft One).
 Deferred income 
 This caption mainly concerns Assurimo for €16.5 million. In this insurance brokerage business, client premiums are mainly billed at the end of the year and relate to the following year, which is when they are paid. By way of reminder, revenue is recognised on a straight-line basis in accordance with IFRS 15, which explains the significant amount recorded in this caption. 

 Group and equity-accounted companies 

 This line includes miscellaneous amounts payable on current accounts to sellers of companies not yet consolidated. At 31 December 2020, the largest item was carried on Assurimo’s books for €2.8 million and related to the Serenity One acquisition.

###### Accounting for client accounts is a separate and autonomous form of accounting. At 31 December 2019, the balance of client accounts and “Article 55” transaction accounts therefore represents all of the transactions carried out for each client account. This balance totalled €554 million, reported under assets and liabilities in the statement of financial position at 31 December 2020. 
 France’s ALUR law requires the use of separate accounts (opened in the name of the joint owners) for jointly owned properties comprising more than 15 main lots as from 1 April 2015. Accordingly, these separate accounts are not reflected in the statement of financial position. The ordinance dated 31 October 2019 now requires separate accounts to be established for all jointly owned properties by 31 December 2020 at the latest. All accounts have been opened, including some just before the end of the year. Consequently, the transfers to certain accounts have not yet been made.
 Note that the statement of financial position does not include any amount for Germany or Belgium, which only use separate accounts.

###### 4.17.1. Interest rate derivatives 
 On 3 September 2020, the Group entered into an interest rate cap agreement under the following terms and conditions:

 • Notional amount: €660 million 
 • Maturity: 12 months 
 • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor 
 • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1% 
 • Hedging period: 12 months from 3 September 2020 to 3 September 2021 

 The premium paid for this instrument totalled €39,000. In view of current interbank rates (negative 3-month Euribor), the fair value of this instrument was zero at 31 December 2020.

 4.17.2. Foreign exchange derivatives
 As from 29 June 2018, the Group no longer has any financial instruments hedging its foreign exchange risk.

###### In 2020, the Property management business in France represents almost 60% of the Group’s total revenue. Revenue for the business was up €8.5 million (1.5%) in the period and reflects the following conflicting impacts: 

 (i) the impact of acquisitions carried out in the year;

 (ii) the negative impact of the health crisis on the rental management business (essentially affecting amounts
 collected under commercial leases and incidental fees) as a direct result of the lockdown measures introduced in the second and fourth quarters of 2020), and on incidental fees earned on jointly owned properties (fees on transfer duties, reminders, renovation work and vacancies). 

 Revenue for the Transactions business fell by €4.3 million, due mainly to the impact of the consecutive lockdowns introduced in view of the health crisis, with business volumes slowing sharply in April and May (first lockdown) and then again in November (branches closed) compared to the same period in 2019.
 Despite the impact of the health crisis, the Digital business posted significant revenue growth of €7.5 million on the back of a good performance from Efficity.

###### NOTE 8. FINANCIAL RISK EXPOSURE

 Interest rate risk
 The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralised basis. They are mainly indexed to 3-month Euribor. The risk management policy is set by management. 

 Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for the Group’s companies are centralised under a cash pooling agreement and managed by the Group’s Treasury department. 

 The Group’s Treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritises liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month Euribor or is at fixed rates (term accounts).

 At 31 December 2020, interest rate risks can be broken down by management outlook as follows, taking into account interest rate maturities applied to the asset/liability financing position:

Given that no repayments have been made and that no repayment plan has been set for the foreseeable future, this loan is now considered as a monetary item and as part of the net investment in Foncia Switzerland as quasi-equity, in accordance with IAS 21 – The Effects of Changes in Foreign Exchange Rates. Since this date, foreign exchange gains and losses arising on the loan have been included in other comprehensive income (equity) under foreign currency translation reserves.

 NOTE 10. LITIGATION AND CONTINGENT LIABILITIES
 Update on the UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) dispute 
 On 1 October 2014, UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) brought proceedings against Foncia Groupe before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance (regional court) seeking damages for losses allegedly suffered by lessees of Foncia-managed properties who were unduly charged for receiving notices to pay (avis d’échéance). 
 More specifically, UFC is seeking payment from Foncia Groupe of an amount of €2.30 per month and per lessee over a period of five years and estimates the number of lessees concerned at 318,400, bringing the total damages to €44 million. 
 In its defence, the Group argues that the French law of 6 July 1989 on residential lease agreements, upon which basis UFC filed its claim, made no provision for class actions at the time of the alleged offence; that no law existed preventing lessees being charged for receiving notices to pay; and that this was therefore a lawful practice. 
 Oral arguments were exchanged before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance in March 2018. The decision handed down in May 2018 dismissed UFC’s claims on the grounds that they fell outside the scope of a class action. UFC has appealed the decision and the hearings before the court of appeal have been postponed to 11 March 2021. The Group considers that no provision needs to be accrued in this respect in its financial statements at 31 December 2020.

concern, and using the going concern basis of accounting, unless it expects to liquidate the Company or
to cease operations.

**Responsibilities of the Statutory Auditors relating to the audit of the consolidated**
**financial statements**

Our role is to issue a report on the consolidated financial statements. Our objective is to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free of
material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that
an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material
misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material
if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic
decisions taken by users on the basis of these consolidated financial statements.

As specified in article L.823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code, our audit does not include assurance
on the viability or quality of the Company’s management.

As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the
Statutory Auditors exercise professional judgement throughout the audit.

They also:

  - identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the consolidated financial statements,

whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures in response to those risks,
and obtain audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for their
opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than
for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions,
misrepresentations, or the override of internal control;

  - obtain an understanding of the internal control procedures relevant to the audit in order to

design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of
expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control;

  - evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting

estimates made by management and the related disclosures in the notes to the consolidated
financial statements;

###### NOTE 1. GENERAL PRESENTATION

 Information concerning the Foncia Management Group
 Foncia Management is a French simplified joint stock company (société par actions simplifiée) with a sole shareholder, subject to all regulations governing commercial companies in France, and in particular the provisions of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce). Its registered office is located at 13 avenue Lebrun, 92160 Antony, France.

 Description of Group businesses
 Founded in 1972, the Foncia Group is Europe’s leading provider of residential property services, and had over 10,000 employees at 31 December 2019. The Group operates in France, Switzerland, Germany and Belgium, assisting its clients at every stage of their property journey with a comprehensive residential service offering. From choosing a first rental property to purchasing a home to live in, building up an estate or supplementing their income, the Foncia Group provides end-to-end assistance to its clients throughout their real estate projects. 
 The Group’s core business is residential property management, in which it enjoys strong leadership in France thanks to a network of over 500 branches across the country. Its main activities in this sector are: 

  Management of jointly owned properties: Foncia is the French market leader, managing over 45,000 properties each year. The Group assists its clients in managing their jointly owned properties (management of security and maintenance staff, payment of common costs, management of joint decisions, coordination of payments from co-owners). It also offers its clients cost management (reduction of energy, maintenance and heating costs) and asset appraisal services, as well as round-the-clock assistance. Thanks to a major external growth (acquisitions) strategy, this business is currently enjoying fast-paced expansion. 

  Rental management and lettings: Managing over 350,000 properties each year across France, Foncia assists its owner-lessor customers in appraising their property and securing their rental income. Rent payment guarantee services provide owner-lessors with guaranteed rental income should their lessees fail to make their rental payments.

 The Group also assists lessees, with over 70,000 new rentals each year and 15,000 seasonal rentals. 

 The Group has also diversified into the following businesses: 

  Property transaction intermediation: 

 With over 15,000 properties available across France, the Group supports its clients with their purchase or sale plans:
  Property search services  Advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities  Property appraisals, buyer solvency assessments, technical due diligence, etc.

  Additional complementary services such as: 
  Specialised property insurance brokerage (Assurimo)  Technical due diligence and inventories (Constatimmo)  Wealth management and consulting services for commercial and office properties (Esset Management)  Business-specific IT services (Seiitra)   Marketing of properties by blocks or lots (Foncia Valorisation)  Technical homeowner maintenance

###### Acquisition of an additional stake in BimData.io (MovetoBim)
 On 9 July 2019, the Group acquired an additional stake in BimData.io (MovetoBim) through a capital increase subscribed by its subsidiary Immophilae in an amount of €0.3 million. The Group’s interest in BimData.io is now 19.25%. 
 Given the difficulty in compiling and sharing pertinent information, MovetoBIM, a start-up based in Lyon (France) has revisited asset management using Building Information Modelling (BIM) technology, offering asset managers a fully digital, collaborative alternative solution. Since the end of 2015, the company has made available its online tools leveraging BIM technology, a new benchmark in building design.

 Change in accounting presentation for Leemo revenue
 Following the additional analyses carried out by the Group in connection with the first-time application of IFRS 15, in 2019 the Group decided to change its accounting presentation of revenue arising from fees earned on deeds of sale. This led to the reclassification of the contracts concerned as contracts where it acts as agent, as opposed to contracts where it acts as principal as was previously the case. Due to this change in accounting presentation, the Group now shows billed amounts net of the costs of fee retrocessions in order to present only those fees attributable to the Group. 
 Since this does not allow a meaningful comparison of consolidated revenue (and the related external charges) between 2019 and 2018, the statement of profit and loss figures for 2018 have been restated accordingly, leading to a negative impact of €14.9 million on revenue as presented. This change in presentation has no impact on recurring operating profit for 2018.  
 It should be recalled that in accordance with IFRS 15, when a third party is involved in providing a separate service, the Group must determine whether it acts on its own behalf (i.e., as principal) or on behalf of another party (i.e., as agent). The Group therefore has to determine whether it controls the specified service before it is provided to the end customer, (for example, when it controls the way in which the third party provides the service). The agent/principal distinction is explicitly based on the notion of control. Based on an analysis of the substance of the contractual relationship between Leemo and business providers/developers, and in particular Leemo’s lack of flexibility in setting its prices, the Group has decided that Leemo acts as agent. 

 NOTE 3. ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND METHODS

 General principles used to prepare the financial statements
 The accounting policies described in these notes have been applied consistently to all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, with the exception of the standards adopted as described in Note 3.2.2, effective as of 1 January 2019, which include IFRS 16 c Leases.
 The consolidated financial statements are prepared on a historical cost basis, except for assets held for sale and related liabilities, measured in accordance with IFRS 5, and certain financial instruments carried at fair value or amortised cost in accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9. 
 The consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management at 31 December 2019 were adopted by the Supervisory Board at its meeting of 23 April 2020 and will be submitted to shareholders for approval at the General Meeting on 29 June 2020. 
 They are presented in thousands of euros and amounts are rounded up or down to the nearest thousand unless otherwise specified. Consequently, the sum of these amounts may differ slightly from the total amounts reported.

###### Accounting standards

 3.2.1. Basis of preparation of financial information
 Pursuant to Regulation (EC) No. 1606/2002 of 19 July 2002 as amended by Regulation (EC) No. 297/2008 of 11 March 2008, the 2019 consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the international financial reporting standards (IFRS) and interpretations issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at 1 January 2019. The full text of the standards adopted by the European Union can be consulted on the European Commission’s website: 
 https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting_en
 Where there is no specific guidance from IFRS standards or IFRIC interpretations, the Group refers to other IFRS standards dealing with similar issues or to the Conceptual Framework, in accordance with IAS 8 – Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors. 
 At the end of the reporting period, there was no difference between the IFRS used to prepare these financial statements and the standards adopted by the IASB and applicable for the period presented.
 The accounting policies and bases of measurement applied to prepare these consolidated financial statements are described in Note 3.4 below. 
 The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of Foncia Management, the entities it controls (subsidiaries) and the entities which are accounted for by the equity method. The financial statements of the Group’s subsidiaries are prepared over the same period as those of the parent company, i.e., 1 January to 31 December 2019, using consistent accounting policies.

 3.2.2. Changes in accounting standards
 Main IFRS standards, amendments and interpretations in force within the European Union and mandatorily applicable since 1 January 2019
 The accounting policies and bases of measurement used by the Group to prepare its consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 are identical to those used by the Group at 31 December 2018, except as described below.

   - IFRS 16 – Leases

###### This new standard entered into force on 1 January 2019 and introduces fundamental changes to lease accounting. IFRS 16 replaces IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations.
 It no longer distinguishes between operating leases and finance leases. Accordingly, entities are required to recognise all lease obligations in their statement of financial position in line with the approach applicable to finance leases under IAS 17. More specifically, on entering into a lease contract, IFRS 16 requires recognition in the statement of financial position of a liability representing the present value of future fixed lease payments, against a right-of-use asset depreciated over the term of the lease (these rights and obligations were previously reported in off-balance sheet commitments for operating leases).
 The Group has chosen to apply IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach, i.e., with no restatement of comparative information. Under this approach, a liability is recognised at the transition date for the present value of any residual lease payments, against a right-of-use asset adjusted for the amount of any lease payments made at or before the lease commencement date. 


-----

###### All impacts resulting from the first-time application of IFRS 16 were recognised against opening equity at 1 January 2019. The Group does not have any major lease contracts in which it acts as lessor, with the exception of certain intragroup leases, the accounting for which was not significantly impacted by IFRS 16. 
 The amount of the lease liability is largely dependent on the assumptions used to determine the lease term and, to a lesser extent, the discount rate. 
  Under IFRS 16, the discount rate for each lease is to be determined by reference to the lessee’s incremental
 borrowing rate. In practice, given how the Group is organised financially, i.e., held or guaranteed almost exclusively by the three French holding companies, the Group adopted an incremental borrowing rate of 3.25% for all of its lease contracts (excluding vehicle leases), reflecting the Group’s own borrowing rate. This rate corresponds to the sum of the risk-free rate and the Group’s credit spread over the initial term of the syndicated loan (i.e., without considering the term). 

 The value of the vehicle fleet in France is estimated based on the interest rate implicit in the leases, as supplied by Arval, i.e., 2.56%. 
  Barring exceptional cases, the lease term reflects the firm term of the lease, plus or minus the period covered by
 any extension or early termination options. For property leases in France and in particular automatically renewable property leases, the Group has adopted the legally defensible term of the lease, which reflects the nearest date at which the lease can be terminated without incurring any penalties, taking into account a six-month notice period starting at the end of the calendar quarter (i.e., a maximum nine-month term). The lease term is therefore nine months at the date of first-time application of IFRS 16 and six months at the date of preparation of the 2019 financial statements.

 It should be noted that following its meeting of 26 November 2019, the IFRS Interpretations Committee (IFRS IC) confirmed its position regarding the lease term and useful life of non-removable leasehold improvements. IFRS IC confirms that the economics of a lease contract rather than just its legal form should be used to determine the enforceable term of a lease. Owing to the late publication of this decision and the time needed to analyse and modify the corresponding estimates, this decision will be applied by the Group in 2020 (the legal approach was maintained to determine the term of property leases). 
 The following other main assumptions and practical expedients were used by the Group: 
  Leases formerly classified as finance leases under IAS 17 continue to be accounted for as finance leases. To simplify, the residual useful life of these leases is calculated in the same way as under IAS 17. 
  The practical expedient exempting leases with a residual term of less than 12 months from the scope of IFRS 16 has not been adopted by the Group.

  Restoration costs 

 - Property leases: restoration costs are not calculated for property leases. As they are frequently negotiated with the lessor at the end of the lease, the costs cannot be reliably estimated. 

 - Vehicle fleet: In France, the Group adopted an average cost of €700 per vehicle (cost plus 20% for private vehicles on which VAT cannot be recovered) in measuring the right-of-use asset corresponding to the residual value guarantee. This average cost was calculated based on a market estimate and taking into account the historical cost actually incurred when changing the automotive fleet at the beginning of 2019.
  Variable lease payments or services related to the lease are not included when calculating the amount of the right-of-use asset or lease liability. 
  Deferred tax was recognised on the difference between the right-of-use asset and the lease liability falling within the scope of IFRS 16, in a similar way to that previously recognised for finance leases.
  The useful lives of non-removable leasehold improvements have not been aligned with the useful lives of the related right-of-use assets

###### Use of management estimates in applying the Group’s accounting standards
 The preparation of financial statements requires the Group to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets and liabilities and any disclosures provided in respect of contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. 
 Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Where applicable, a sensitivity analysis may be performed if the estimates are material. Accordingly, actual results may differ from these estimates. 
 The estimates made by the Group in preparing its consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below. 
  Measurements used in testing goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment for impairment
 The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. 
 As with any estimate, the assumptions used in these calculations are partly based on uncertain factors and may therefore need to be adjusted in subsequent periods. Note 4.1.3 sets out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same note. 
  Measurement of leases
 IFRS 16 requires entities to use a significant degree of judgement as well as certain key estimates. These involve determining: 
  whether an option to extend or terminate a lease is reasonably certain to be exercised;   the lease term;  the appropriate discount rate to be used to calculate future lease payments;   the specific selling price of any lease components and non-lease components contained in the contract.

 The main assumptions used by the Group to prepare its 2019 financial statements are described in Note 3.2.2.
  Measurement of provisions

 The Group used the best estimate of its commitments and obligations to calculate the corresponding provisions.
  Measurement of employee benefits 

 The Group operates both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. 

 Note 4.13 sets out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. The Group considers that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. 


-----

######  Measurement of fair value (Level 1)

 The Group uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure unlisted derivative instruments and cash and cash equivalents (see Notes 3.4.17 and 4.18). 

  Measurement of recognised deferred tax assets and liabilities and tax expense
 The Group’s tax position (see Notes 4.9 and 5.11) is based on its best estimate of future taxable earnings.
  Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business
 combination

 The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount. 

  Assessment of criteria for identifying discontinued operations
 In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, the Group is required to exercise judgement in determining whether an asset or group of assets meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale. IFRS 5 criteria are also used to identify any assets to be classified as discontinued operations. These assessments are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in light of changes in the relevant facts and circumstances.
 In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, the Group uses its judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements:

  present a true and fair view of the Foncia Group’s financial position, financial performance and cash flows;

  reflect the economic substance of transactions;

  are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects.
 Detailed disclosures in this regard are provided in the notes to the consolidated financial statements.

 Basis of measurement

 3.4.1. Basis of consolidation 
 Details of the main consolidated companies at 31 December 2019 are provided in Note 13 “Scope of consolidation”.
 Controlled entities 
 Companies directly or indirectly controlled by the Group are fully consolidated. Control exists when the Group is exposed, or is entitled, to variable returns from its involvement with the entity in question and has the ability to affect those returns through its power over the entity. Control is analysed whenever facts and circumstances indicate that one or more of the inputs used to assess control has changed.
 A subsidiary is consolidated as from the date control is acquired, which is usually upon signature of the share transfer and disposal agreements (see “Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period” below). Consolidation ceases when control is relinquished. 
 Any interest in the subsidiary that is not directly or indirectly attributable to the Group is recognised within non-controlling interests. Profits and losses and each component of other comprehensive income relating to subsidiaries are allocated to owners of the parent and non-controlling interests, even if this results in non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. 


-----

###### Changes in the percentage interest held in subsidiaries that do not lead to a change in control are treated as equity transactions, since the transactions take place between owners acting in their capacity as owners. The impact of these transactions is shown in equity net of tax and does not therefore impact consolidated profit or loss. These transactions are also shown in the statement of cash flows under cash flows relating to investing activities.
 Investments in equity-accounted companies (associates and joint ventures) 
 Associates are entities over which the Group exercises significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling those policies.
 A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. 
 Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in the Group’s consolidated financial statements. 
 Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognised at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for the Group’s interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture. 
 IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments is applied to determine whether investments in associates or joint ventures need to be tested for impairment. Where necessary, the total carrying amount of the investment (including goodwill) is tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets. 
 Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period 
 Non-consolidated investments are classified as available-for-sale securities and mainly consist of shares in property management companies that will subsequently be consolidated.
 Before acquiring shares in a property management company, the Group agrees to acquire the shares and pays 10% of the estimated price to the seller. This part payment is included in “Downpayments on acquisitions of securities” within non-current financial assets. The remaining 90% is booked in “Off-balance sheet commitments” (see Note 9). 
 Upon signing the share transfer or disposal agreement, the Group pays an additional 70% of the estimated price to the seller. The provisional purchase price is then included in equity investments, and the part payment already recognised is also reclassified to this caption. The acquired company is then consolidated. 

 Following a review of the acquired company’s financial statements, the Group pays the remaining balance and adjusts the purchase price of the shares. 

 Non-consolidated investments 
 Companies with the following characteristics are not included in the scope of consolidation:

  they are in the process of being wound up or are dormant;

  their business is not strategic for the Group.
 In accordance with IFRS 9, non-consolidated investments are carried at fair value. There are no material obligations or liabilities relating to these entities.


-----

###### 3.4.2. Elimination of intragroup transactions
 All intragroup transactions and balances as well as any income, expenses, gains and losses resulting from intragroup transactions and included in the carrying amount of assets are eliminated on consolidation.
 When a Group entity carries out a transaction with a joint venture or associate, the related gains and losses are recognised in the Group’s consolidated financial statements only to the extent of the interests held by third parties in the joint venture or associate.

 3.4.3. Foreign currency translation
 Presentation currency
 The consolidated financial statements are presented in euros, which is the Group’s presentation currency.
 Functional currency and translation of the financial statements of foreign companies
 A consolidated entity’s functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates. In most cases, the functional currency is the local currency. However, certain entities must adopt a functional currency other than their local currency when that currency represents the currency of the major transactions carried out by the entity and accurately reflects its economic environment. 
 The financial statements of foreign entities whose functional currency is different from the presentation currency of the Group’s consolidated financial statements are translated using the “closing rate” method, as follows: 

  assets and liabilities are translated at the closing exchange rate; 

  statement of profit and loss and cash flow items are converted at the average exchange rate for the period.

 The resulting currency translation differences are recognised directly in other comprehensive income within equity under “Translation adjustments”. 
 Goodwill relating to foreign entities whose functional currency is not the euro are treated as assets acquired or liabilities assumed and therefore translated at the exchange rate prevailing at the end of the reporting period. 

 As the Group does most of its business in the eurozone, only its Swiss subsidiaries prepare financial statements in a currency other than the euro.

###### Foreign currency transactions
 Foreign currency transactions are translated into euros at the exchange rates prevailing at the transaction date or at the hedged rate. At the end of the reporting period, monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency are translated at the closing exchange rate, with the resulting gains and losses included in foreign exchange gains and losses under other financial income and expenses in the statement of profit and loss. 
 Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are measured at historical cost are translated at the exchange rate at the transaction date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are stated at fair value are translated at the exchange rate at the date on which fair value was determined. 
 Loans granted to a foreign operation for which settlement is neither planned nor likely to occur in the foreseeable future are, in substance, part of the Group’s net investment in that foreign operation. Translation adjustments arising on monetary items that are part of a net investment in a foreign operation are recognised directly in other comprehensive income (equity) under “Foreign currency translation reserves”, and taken to profit or loss when the net investment is sold.

 3.4.4. Business combinations and goodwill
 The Group uses the purchase method to account for its acquisitions of subsidiaries. The fair value of the consideration transferred reflects the fair value of the assets given, equity instruments issued and liabilities assumed or incurred by the acquirer at the date of exchange. Costs directly attributable to the business combination are expensed in the period in which they were incurred.
 On the first-time consolidation of a subsidiary or equity investment, the Group measures all identifiable items acquired at their acquisition-date fair value. The items are measured in the currency of the acquired company. In the event of deferred settlements, the future amounts payable are discounted to present value at the settlement date. The discount rate used is the same as that used to estimate the value of the assets.
 Fair value adjustments to assets and liabilities resulting from business combinations accounted for on a provisional basis (i.e., because the independent appraisals or ongoing additional analyses are incomplete) are recognised as retrospective adjustments to goodwill if they occur within 12 months of the acquisition (measurement period) and if they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. Adjustments made after the measurement period are taken directly to profit or loss, unless they are made to correct an error, including in relation to deferred tax assets which, if recognised more than 12 months after the acquisition date, generate tax income.
 Goodwill arising on acquisitions of associates and joint ventures is included in the carrying amount of “Investments in equity-accounted companies”. 
 Goodwill
 The residual difference representing the excess of the fair value of the consideration transferred plus any non-controlling interests in the acquired company over the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is recognised in the consolidated statement of financial position as goodwill.
 For each business combination, the Group may choose to account for non-controlling interests: 

   - either at acquisition-date fair value, resulting in the recognition of goodwill on the non-controlling interests
###### (“full goodwill” method);

   - or based on the share of net identifiable assets of the acquired entity measured at fair value, in which case
###### goodwill is only recognised on the portion attributable to owners of the parent (“partial goodwill” method).


-----

###### Goodwill is not amortised but is tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that it may be impaired. The impairment testing approach is described in Note 3.4.8 “Impairment of assets” below. Impairment recognised against goodwill may not be reversed.
 Bargain purchases
 When the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed of the acquired company exceeds the purchase price plus the amount of any non-controlling interests in the acquired company, the negative goodwill is taken immediately to profit or loss in the period of the acquisition, after verifying the procedure for identifying and measuring the various items included in its calculation.
 Transactions involving non-controlling interests
 Changes in non-controlling interests that do not result in gain or loss of control are recognised in equity. In particular, when additional shares are acquired in an entity already controlled by the Group, the difference between the purchase price of the shares and the additional share of consolidated equity acquired is recognised in equity attributable to owners of the parent. The consolidated carrying amount of the subsidiary’s identifiable assets and liabilities (including goodwill) remains unchanged.
 Contingent consideration and/or earn-out
 Contingent consideration or earn-outs relating to a business combination are measured at their acquisition-date fair value, even if it deemed unlikely they will be paid. After the acquisition date, changes in the estimated fair value of contingent consideration/earn-outs result in an adjustment to goodwill only if they are made within the 12 months following the acquisition date (measurement period) and if they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. In all other cases, any such changes are taken to profit or loss, unless the consideration transferred is an equity instrument. 
 The revised IFRS 3 gives certain indications as regards the accounting for contingent payment arrangements with employees or selling shareholders. These arrangements may be part of the business combination or may be considered as separate from the acquisition agreement for the target entity.
 In certain acquisitions, earn-out payments were considered part of the consideration for post-acquisition services rendered and are therefore expensed in the periods concerned and in future periods.
 Business combinations achieved in stages (step acquisitions)
 In a business combination achieved in stages, the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company is remeasured at fair value through profit or loss on the date control was obtained. Goodwill at the date control is obtained is calculated as the fair value of consideration transferred (i.e., price paid) plus the fair value of the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company.

 3.4.5. Intangible assets
 Intangible assets are identifiable non-monetary assets with no physical substance. 
 In accordance with IAS 38, intangible assets that are acquired separately are initially measured at cost when the future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. Subsequent expenditure on intangible assets is included as part of the cost of those assets only if it increases the future economic benefits associated with the assets concerned. Other costs are expensed as incurred.
 Intangible assets acquired as part of a business combination that can be reliably measured, are controlled by the Group, and are separable or arise from legal or contractual rights are recognised at fair value separately from goodwill.


-----

###### Intangible assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Intangible assets with a finite useful life (software and licences) are amortised on a straight-line basis over their expected useful lives: 

   - Client relationships: 18-21 years

   - Software programs: 1-10 years

   - Other intangible assets: 5 years

###### Intangible assets with an indefinite useful life are not amortised. They are included with other assets within cash-generating units (CGUs) and tested for impairment using the discounted cash flow method at least once a year and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. 
 When the recoverable amount of these assets calculated based on criteria prevailing at the acquisition date falls below their carrying amount, an impairment provision is recorded. 

 Trademarks
 Identifiable trademarks are measured using a multi-criteria approach that takes into consideration both their reputation and profitability. 
 The Group classified its main “Foncia” trademark, along with the “Lodgis” and “Trévi” trademarks in Belgium and the “Domicim” and “Brolliet” trademarks in Switzerland, as indefinite-lived intangible assets. 

 Business software programs
 Software acquired is carried at cost (purchase price plus ancillary expenses). When allocating the purchase price, certain software programs may also be measured using the replacement cost approach.

 Business goodwill and client relationships
 Client relationships include the list of mandates held by the Group’s companies. A mandate is an instrument by which a person (the principal) gives another person (the agent) the power to carry out or enter into one or more legal actions or agreements, in the principal’s name. France’s Hoguet law requires professional property agents to hold a written mandate in order to put properties up for sale or to let, and to manage jointly owned property.
 Client relationships are measured based on the excess earnings method.


-----

###### Other intangible assets
 Other intangible assets mainly comprise the cost of acquiring new business.

 Leasehold rights 
 In light of the legal characteristics of commercial leases in France, leasehold rights (droits au bail) are considered to have an indefinite useful life and are not amortised. They were previously shown within intangible assets and are now included within right-of-use assets (see Note 3.2.2). The residual value of right-of-use assets is reviewed at least once a year. Assets for which the underlying leases have been terminated are systematically retired.  

 3.4.6. Property, plant and equipment
 Property, plant and equipment are measured at their historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses.
 The cost of an item of property, plant and equipment comprises its purchase price, including customs duties and non-recoverable taxes, and any costs directly incurred to bring the asset to working condition for its intended use. Any trade discounts and rebates are deducted from the purchase price.
 Subsequent expenditure is included in the carrying amount of property, plant and equipment or is recognised as a separate component where appropriate, if it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. All other maintenance and repair costs are expensed as incurred, except for costs incurred to increase productivity or extend the useful life of an asset, which are capitalised. 
 Property, plant and equipment are depreciated using the components approach over their estimated useful lives, taking into account any residual value. Straight-line depreciation is considered the method that best reflects the pattern in which the assets’ economic benefits are consumed by the Group: 

   - Buildings: 20-50 years

   - Fixtures and fittings: 8-10 years

   - IT equipment: 4 years

   - Vehicle fleet: 5 years

   - Furniture: 10 years

   - Office equipment: 4 years

###### The residual values and useful lives of property, plant and equipment are reviewed at the end of each reporting period and adjusted where necessary. The carrying amounts of property, plant and equipment are tested for impairment when there is evidence that they may be impaired. 
 Gains and losses on asset disposals are calculated as the difference between the sale proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset concerned.

 3.4.7. Leases
 Pursuant to IFRS 16 – Leases, on entering into a contract, the Group analyses the contractual provisions to determine whether it has the characteristics of a lease. 
 It verifies whether the lease transfers in substance the right to control the use of an asset for a specified period of time in exchange for consideration. If these characteristics exist, as soon as the asset is made available the Group recognises:

  a right-of-use asset, which represents its right to use the leased asset over the lease term; 

  a lease liability which represents its obligation to make lease payments


-----

###### The Group applies the same method to account for all leases in which it acts as lessee, and has chosen not to use the practical expedients set out in IFRS 16 exempting short-term leases (i.e., leases with terms of 12 months or less) or leases of low-value underlying assets from the scope of the standard.
 The amount of the right-of-use asset comprises:

  the amount of the associated lease liability;

  plus: 
  any lease payments made at or before the commencement date,
  any initial direct costs incurred to obtain the lease, 
  any estimated restoration costs to be incurred by the Group;

  less any lease incentives received. 
 Right-of-use assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated depreciation and any accumulated impairment losses. They are depreciated over the lease term or the useful life of the leased asset for accounting purposes, whichever is shorter. 
 The lease liability represents the present value of: 

  fixed lease payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentives receivable; 

  variable lease payments that depend on an index or a rate, initially measured using the index or rate at the commencement date;

  amounts expected to be payable by the Group under residual value guarantees; 

  the exercise price of a purchase option if the Group is reasonably certain to exercise that option;

  penalties required for terminating the lease. 
 Lease liabilities are subsequently measured by increasing the carrying amount to reflect interest on the lease liability (using the effective interest rate method) and by reducing the carrying amount to reflect the lease payments made. 
 To determine the lease term, the Group analyses the contractual provisions of the lease, as illustrated below:


-----

###### The Group remeasures the lease liability (and adjusts the corresponding right-of-use asset accordingly), when: 

  there is a change in the lease term or a change in the assessment of an option to purchase the underlying asset, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate; 

  there is a change in future lease payments resulting from a change in an index or rate, or a change in the amounts expected to be payable under a residual value guarantee, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using the initial discount rate; 

  there is a change in the lease contract (lease modification) that is not accounted for as a separate lease, in which case the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate. 
 When the Group incurs an obligation to restore the asset to the condition specified in the lease contract, the related costs are included as part of the cost of the right-of-use asset and the corresponding lease liability is increased accordingly. 
 IFRS 16 offers a practical expedient to lessees whereby they may choose not to separate non-lease components from lease components, and instead account for each lease component and any associated non-lease components as a single lease component. The Group did not apply this practical expedient in its 2019 financial statements. 

 3.4.8. Impairment of assets

 Impairment of assets with finite useful lives
 Property, plant and equipment and intangible assets with finite useful lives are tested for impairment whenever there is evidence that they may be impaired. Impairment recognised in profit or loss against property, plant and equipment and intangible assets may be reversed.

 Impairment of assets with indefinite useful lives
 Goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that they may be impaired. 
 Cash-generating units
 For the purposes of these impairment tests, non-current assets that cannot be tested individually for impairment as they do not generate cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets, are grouped into cash-generating units (CGUs).
 Impairment tests are carried out on each CGU or group of CGUs at the lowest level at which goodwill is monitored by the Group.
 A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets for internal management purposes. 
 The CGUs identified by the Group correspond to its major development and investment strategies. The Group has defined the following three cash-generating units:

   - Property Management France CGU, which includes the management of jointly owned properties, rental
###### management, lettings, the transactions business and client mandates.

   - Property Management International CGU, which includes the property management and transactions
###### businesses in Germany, Switzerland and Belgium.


-----

   - Services CGU, which includes Constatimmo (brokerage for technical surveys), Assurimo (insurance
###### brokerage), Efficity (property appraisals website), FPM and Esset Management (BtoB property management), Prowen (brokerage specialised in energy purchases), Seiitra (property management software development), Techway (technical maintenance), Leemo (property platform), and Lodgis (furnished rentals).
 The Group decides whether or not to recognise an impairment loss by comparing the carrying amount of the assets and liabilities in a CGU or group of CGUs with their recoverable amount.
 Impairment indicators 
 External indicators of impairment include changes in the general economic and financial environment, downtrends in local economic environments and changes in economic performance. These are analysed by the Group to determine whether the assets concerned should be tested for impairment more frequently. 

 Method used to determine the recoverable amount
 An impairment loss is recognised in the statement of profit and loss when the carrying amount of an asset or CGU exceeds its recoverable amount. 
 The recoverable amount of an asset or CGU is the higher of: 

   - its fair value less the costs of disposal, representing the amount at which the Group could sell the asset (after
###### selling costs) in an arm’s length transaction between market participants at the measurement date; and

   - its value in use, representing the present value of the future cash flows expected to be derived from the
###### continuing use and ultimate sale of an asset or CGU based on the most probable assumptions adopted by management.

 Fair value net of the costs of disposal is calculated based on available information used to establish the best estimate of the selling price net of costs to sell in an arm’s length transaction between fully informed, consenting parties. 

 Value in use of CGUs or groups of CGUs is determined based on post-tax cash flows resulting from business plans and a terminal value calculated by extrapolating data for the last year of the business plan.

 The assumptions used are based on the budgets and business plans prepared by management for each business. These budgets are the latest budgets approved by the Supervisory Board at the date of preparation of the financial statements. 
 Other assumptions affecting the calculation of the recoverable amount include the growth rate, operating margin, the discount rate and the tax rate (see Note 4.1).
 The discount rate used to discount post-tax cash flows to their present value reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset or CGU. Where there is no specific discount rate for the assets tested, the average cost of capital is used. The discount rates are post-tax rates and are applied to post-tax cash flows. The recoverable amount calculated using post-tax discount rates is equal to that which would have been obtained using pre-tax rates applied to pre-tax cash flows, as required by IAS 36. 

 Recognition of impairment losses
 If the carrying amount of the CGU exceeds its recoverable amount, the related assets are written down to the recoverable amount. The impairment loss is first allocated to goodwill and then to the carrying amount of the other assets of the CGU, in proportion to their carrying amount. This must not result in the carrying amount of an individual asset falling below the higher of its fair value, value in use and zero. Impairment losses are recognised in other operating expenses and may not be reversed. 


-----

###### Reversal of impairment losses
 Impairment losses recognised against goodwill cannot be reversed. Impairment losses recognised against assets other than goodwill may only be reversed if there is evidence that the impairment loss may have decreased or may no longer exist. The amount reversed is then based on revised estimates of the asset’s recoverable amount. 
 The increased carrying amount of an asset attributable to the reversal of an impairment loss should not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined had no impairment loss been recognised for the asset. 

 3.4.9. Trade and other receivables
 Trade and other receivables are initially carried at fair value and subsequently measured at amortised cost, less any impairment losses recorded in the statement of profit and loss.

 3.4.10. Financial instruments
 The measurement and recognition of financial assets and liabilities is defined by IFRS 9 – Financial instruments.

 Financial assets
 Financial assets include loans and receivables, liquid assets, financial assets relating to financing, other financial assets, derivative instruments with a positive fair value and cash and cash equivalents. 
 IFRS 9 applies a single analytical framework to all financial assets in order to determine the classification and basis of measurement to be used for accounting purposes. More specifically: 

  Financial assets at amortised cost

 Financial assets that will be recovered through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) are generally carried at amortised cost. 

 Financial assets at amortised cost include operating financial assets, other loans and receivables and trade receivables. They are initially recognised at fair value and subsequently carried at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest rate method. In accordance with IFRS 9, financial assets at amortised cost are written down by the amount of any expected credit losses. The impairment loss is recorded either in recurring operating profit or in other financial income and expenses.
  Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income reclassifiable to profit or loss

 Financial assets that will be recovered both through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) and through sales of those assets are generally carried at fair value through other comprehensive income.

 Changes in the fair value of these assets are recognised directly in other comprehensive income, with the exception of interest income and dividends, which are included in other financial income and expenses. Changes in fair value are reclassified to profit or loss when the assets are sold. 
  Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss 

 This category includes investments in non-consolidated companies and equity instruments that the Group has irrevocably elected to classify in this category. When these investments are sold, the unrealised gains and losses previously carried in other comprehensive income will not be reclassified to profit or loss; only dividends will be taken to profit or loss. 

 Fair value corresponds to the market price for listed securities or to the estimated fair value for unlisted securities, as determined according to the financial criteria most appropriate to the particular situation of each investment. Equity investments for which prices are not quoted on an active market and for which fair


-----

###### value cannot be reliably measured are carried by the Group at historical cost less any accumulated impairment losses. 
  Assets at fair value through profit or loss

 All other debt and equity instruments are carried at fair value through profit or loss. These include marketable securities with an underlying term of more than three months, other financial assets held for trading and purchased for sale in the near term, and financial instruments with a positive fair value that are not eligible for hedge accounting. 

 These assets are measured at fair value, with changes in fair value taken to financial income and expenses.
 At the acquisition date, the Group determines the classification of financial assets into one of the IFRS 9 categories based on the characteristics of the instrument and the business model for managing the assets.
