###### Financial liabilities
 Financial liabilities include borrowings, other financing and overdraft facilities, and derivative instruments with a negative fair value. 
 With the exception of trading liabilities and derivative instruments representing liabilities carried at fair value, borrowings and other financial liabilities are initially recognised at fair value less transaction costs, and subsequently at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest method. 
 The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts the estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life of the financial instrument or, as appropriate, through a shorter period, to the net carrying amount of the financial asset or liability.
 Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments. These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature. 


-----

###### Derivative instruments
 The Group uses derivative instruments to hedge interest rate risks on floating-rate borrowings and foreign exchange risks. 
 In accordance with IFRS, hedge accounting may be applied to a hedging transaction provided that:

   - the hedge is documented (entity’s objectives, hedging strategy, identification of the components of the
###### hedging relationship, etc.);

   - the hedge is highly effective in offsetting changes in fair value or cash flows attributable to the hedged risk.
###### A hedge is highly effective if it meets all of the following hedge effectiveness criteria:

 - there is an economic relationship between the hedged item and the hedging instrument,

 - the credit risk is not of a magnitude that it dominates the value changes that result from the economic relationship,

 - the hedge ratio is the same as that resulting from the quantity of the hedged item that the Group actually hedges and the quantity of the hedging instrument that the Group actually uses to hedge that quantity of hedged item;

   - effectiveness can be measured reliably and is calculated in the context of continuing operations.

###### For the periods presented, no interest rate or foreign currency derivatives used by the Group are classified as hedging instruments. 

 In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, derivative instruments are measured on the statement of financial position at fair value. Changes in the fair value of instruments not eligible for hedge accounting are recognised in profit or loss under other financial income and expenses.

 3.4.11. Cash and cash equivalents
 Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at bank and on hand, as well as short-term highly-liquid deposits with an initial maturity of three months or less and subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. 
 Short-term investments are measured at market value at the end of each reporting period, with any changes in market value taken to financial income and expenses. 
 Investments in listed equities, investments with an initial maturity of over three months and no early exit option and restricted (i.e., blocked) bank accounts are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and classified as current or non-current financial assets. 
 Bank overdraft facilities are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and included in current financial liabilities. Changes in the fair value of these instruments are recorded in profit or loss. 
 For the purposes of the consolidated statement of cash flows, net cash and cash equivalents include the items defined above, net of short-term bank overdrafts. 


-----

###### 3.4.12. Client accounts 
 The Group conducts its property management business through mandates signed with clients, under which the companies are responsible for holding client funds. These funds consist of guarantee deposits received, rent and expenses, joint ownership working capital and renovation funds, and funds received in connection with the transactions business. As an agent, the Group undertakes to hold client accounts and to recognise them in its statement of financial position using a specific account for each activity (property sales, rentals and management).

 3.4.13. Current and non-current provisions
 A provision is recognised when, at the end of the reporting period, the Group has a legal or constructive obligation to a third party resulting from a past event that is likely to give rise to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits and can be measured reliably.

 Provisions may also be recognised for contingent liabilities arising on business combinations. In this case, they are initially recognised at fair value at the acquisition date. 

 When the Group expects partial or full repayment of the provision, for example owing to an insurance policy, the repayment is booked as a separate asset but only if such repayment is virtually certain. 

 When the effect of the time value of money is material, the amount of the provision reflects the present value of the expenditure expected to be required to settle the obligations, as calculated using a pre-tax discount rate reflecting current market assessments of the time value of money and, where applicable, the risks specific to the liability.

 Since provisions are calculated based on estimated future contingencies and expenses, they are measured taking into account the assumptions deemed most probable at the reporting date. Items giving rise to provisions (trade and employee disputes, etc.) are reviewed regularly to allow for any adjustments. 

 Provisions include amounts accrued in respect of business, employee-related and/or tax (excluding income tax) risks and disputes arising in the ordinary course of operations, as described below:

  Employee-related provisions (disputes, lay-offs, etc.)
 At the end of each reporting period, a provision is recognised and adjusted in line with the risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Human Resources department on a case-by-case basis.

  Provisions for rent payment guarantees
 A rent payment guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. Foncia bears the cost of any unpaid rent and advances to owners. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery.

 Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts (deriving from the del credere agreement) and are accounted for as follows:

   - the related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are
###### deducted from rents in the same way as basic fees;

   - once rent is reported as unpaid, a provision is recorded, calculated in accordance with IAS 37.

###### The amount of the provision set aside by the Group increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated). 


-----

######  Provision for occupancy guarantees
 An occupancy guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. 
 The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent. The maximum term of claims is 180 days. 

  Provision for URSSAF social security audits
 This concerns in-progress and completed URSSAF social security audits. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the related risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Payroll department on a case-by-case basis.

  Provisions for risks on client accounts
 Provisions for risks on client accounts are designed to cover the non-collection risk on lost client accounts in debit, as well as other risks on client accounts. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the risk exposure on client accounts, as assessed by the Group’s Client Operations department on a case-by-case basis. 

  Provisions for third party and professional liability
 These provisions are recorded based on information provided by senior managers in charge of monitoring claims against their firm. The Audit, Legal and Accounting departments have the final decision in terms of whether or not to record a provision. If the claim is reported and covered by the liability insurance, the maximum provision will reflect the amount of the deductible (€15,000 as of 1 January 2014) or the amount of the estimated risk, whichever is lower. If the claim is not reported, the senior manager concerned sets the amount to be provisioned. 

  Provisions for other disputes
 These provisions are intended to cover disputes, litigation and other foreseeable contingencies in connection with the Group’s businesses, along with miscellaneous contingencies and expenses.

The free share plan therefore meets the definition of a “cash-settled” plan set out in IFRS 2. Consequently, the service cost is recognised on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the rights, with a direct offsetting entry to employee-related liabilities.

 Pensions and other post-employment benefits

  Short-term benefits 
 Short-term benefits include paid annual leave, paid sick leave, bonuses and other benefits (other than contract termination benefits), expected to be settled wholly before 12 months after the end of the annual reporting period during which the employee services are rendered. Short-term benefits are expensed in the period in which the corresponding services are rendered by the employee. Any amounts not paid at the end of the reporting period are carried in current liabilities.

  Post-employment benefits
 In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which the Group operates, Foncia participates in, or operates, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. 

 Virtually all of the Group’s employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by the Foncia Group to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds financed in compliance with the applicable government requirements and regulations. These plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds.
 Post-employment benefits are measured and recognised by the Group in accordance with IAS 19 – Employee Benefits, as described below.

   - Defined contribution plans

###### Defined contribution plans and multi-employer plans are expensed as incurred in the statement of profit and loss based on contributions.

   - Defined benefit plans

###### The cost of defined benefit plans is measured on an actuarial basis. The related obligations are calculated by independent actuaries using the projected unit credit method, based on the agreements in effect in each company.
 Obligations are determined by reference to assumptions that are revised each year and relate for example to length of service, life expectancy, salary inflation and employee turnover, and also take into account macroeconomic assumptions for the various countries in which the Group does business (e.g., discount rate and inflation rate).
 The assumptions used for 2019 are detailed in Note 4.13. 


-----

###### A provision is recognised in the statement of financial position for the difference between the related projected benefit obligation (actuarial liability) and any plan assets as measured at fair value, and includes past service costs and actuarial gains and losses.
 If plan assets exceed the projected benefit obligation recognised, a non-current asset is recorded for the amount of the plans in the consolidated statement of financial position. A funding surplus (net defined benefit asset) is only recognised in the statement of financial position if its represents future economic benefits that will actually be available to the Group. When the calculation of the net benefit obligation gives rise to an asset for the Group, the amount recognised as an asset cannot exceed the present value of any economic benefits available in the form of refunds from the plan or future reductions in contributions to the plan. 
 Expenses under defined benefit plans comprise three components, accounted for as described below:

 - Service cost is recognised under personnel costs within operating profit. It includes service cost for the period, past service cost resulting from plan amendments or curtailments, which are recognised in full in profit or loss for the period in which they arose, and gains and losses arising on plan settlements.

 - Interest cost is recognised in other financial income and expenses and reflects the impact of discounting the obligations, net of the expected return on plan assets as measured using the discount rate applied to calculate those obligations.

 - Remeasurements of the net liability (or net asset) are included in other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss, and do not impact the statement of profit and loss. They essentially comprise actuarial gains and losses, i.e., changes in the benefit obligation and in plan assets attributable to changes in assumptions and experience adjustments. Experience adjustments represent the difference between the expected impact of certain actuarial assumptions applied to previous measurements of the obligation and actual experience.

  Other long-term benefits
 Other long-term benefits are measured in accordance with IAS 19. The estimated cost of these benefits is recognised within non-current liabilities over the employees’ qualifying years of service. Actuarial gains and losses and past service costs attributable to amendments to an existing plan or the introduction of a new plan are taken immediately to profit or loss.
 In France, the collective bargaining agreement for the real estate industry stipulates that all active employees who so request are entitled to one month’s salary at every anniversary date: after 20, 30, 35 and 40 years of professional experience. Professional experience is considered overall and not as experience solely within the Group. However, the Group is only liable for the amount proportionate to the employee’s seniority in the Group.
 The Group’s obligation under long-service awards is assessed each year by an independent expert. 
 The assumptions used for 2019 are detailed in Note 4.13. 

 3.4.15. Deferred taxes
 Deferred taxes are recognised on temporary differences between the carrying amount of assets and liabilities and their value for tax purposes, using the tax rates expected to apply in the period in which the asset is realised and the liability settled, on the basis of tax laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date.
 Deferred tax does not arise on: 

   - the initial recognition of goodwill;

   - the initial recognition of an asset in a transaction that is not a business combination and affects neither the
###### accounting profit (loss) nor taxable profit (loss); 


-----

   - temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, to the extent that it is probable they will not
###### reverse in the foreseeable future. 

 Tax on items recognised directly in equity or in other comprehensive income is recognised in equity or in other comprehensive income, respectively, and not in the statement of profit and loss. 
 Deferred tax assets arising on temporary differences (after offsetting against deferred tax liabilities) or on tax losses and tax credits carried forward are only recognised to the extent that it is probable they will reverse and that the Group will generate future taxable earnings against which they can be utilised.
 The following are taken into account when assessing the Group’s ability to recover these assets: 

   - forecasts of future taxable earnings;

   - taxable earnings in previous years.

###### Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to offset current tax assets and liabilities, and if they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority on the same taxable entity.

 3.4.16. Trade payables and other current liabilities
 Trade payables and other current liabilities are liabilities to be settled or renegotiated within the ordinary operating cycle or within 12 months following the end of the reporting period. Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments (see Note 3.4.10). 
 These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature. The value of items that will be paid over the long term is discounted.

 3.4.17. Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities at fair value
 The fair value of all financial assets and liabilities is determined at the end of the reporting period, either for accounting purposes or for disclosure in the notes to the financial statements. 
 Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. 
 IFRS 13 sets out a three-level hierarchy for determining fair value:

   - Level 1: quoted (unadjusted) prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.

   - Level 2: inputs other than quoted market prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or
###### liability, either directly (i.e., prices) or indirectly (i.e., price-based inputs).

   - Level 3: inputs relating to the asset or liability which are not based on observable market data (unobservable
###### inputs).

 The Group primarily uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure derivative instruments, cash and cash equivalents, available-for-sale financial assets, cash management financial assets and identifiable assets and liabilities acquired as part of a business combination. 
 The fair values of financial assets and liabilities are disclosed in Note 4.19. 


-----

###### 3.4.18. Assets classified as held for sale, businesses sold or in the process of sale and discontinued
 operations
 IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations sets forth the accounting requirements applicable to assets held for sale, along with the presentation and disclosure requirements for discontinued operations.
 IFRS 5 requires assets held for sale to be presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of financial position for the lower of their carrying amount and their fair value less costs to sell, provided that they meet the definition of assets held for sale set out in the standard. 
 When the Group is engaged in a sale process resulting in the loss of control of a subsidiary, the entire assets and liabilities of that subsidiary are classified as held for sale when their carrying amount will be principally recovered through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use, regardless of whether or not the Group retains a residual interest in the subsidiary after the sale. For this to be the case, the asset (or disposal group) must be available for immediate sale in its present condition and the sale must be highly probable.
 The assets and liabilities concerned are reclassified in assets held for sale and liabilities related to assets held for sale, and no offsetting is permitted.
 Businesses sold or in the process of sale are presented on a separate line in the statement of profit and loss for the periods presented, which shows post-tax profit or loss attributable to discontinued operations and the post-tax gain or loss on the disposal or the measurement to fair value less costs to sell of the assets or disposal groups comprising the business sold or in the process of sale.
 A business sold or in the process of sale discontinued operation is defined as a component of an entity that represents a separate major line of business and meets the criteria for classification as an asset held for sale or has been sold by the Group.
 Similarly, cash flows attributable to businesses sold or in the process of sale are presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of cash flows for the periods presented.
 Under IFRS 5, profits or losses related to discontinued operations are also to be shown on a separate line of the consolidated statement of profit and loss, retrospectively for all periods presented. A discontinued operation can be defined as a component of an entity that either has been disposed of or is classified as held for sale and:

  represents a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; 

  is part of a single coordinated plan to dispose of a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; or

  is a subsidiary acquired exclusively with a view to resale.

 3.4.19. Presentation of the statement of profit and loss
 As permitted under IAS 1 – Presentation of Financial Statements, the Group has chosen to present operating expenses by nature.
 “Recurring operating profit (loss)”, “Operating profit (loss)”, “Cost of gross debt” and “Cost of net debt” in the statement of profit and loss and gains and losses recognised directly in equity are presented in accordance with the criteria set out in ANC Recommendation No. 2013-03 issued by the French accounting standards-setter (Autorité des Normes Comptables).

###### 3.4.20. Revenue
 Revenue for the Group results from sales of services within the scope of the ordinary operations of consolidated subsidiaries, less revenue from intragroup transactions. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes and duties. 
 In accordance with IFRS 15, the Group recognises revenue when the amount thereof can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to the Group, and specific criteria are met by each of the Group’s businesses.

  Jointly owned property management business

 From a contractual and legal perspective, the Group’s jointly owned property management business is mostly conducted through mandates, and fees are calculated on a flat-rate basis. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, and excludes incidental services such as:
  preparing, convening and organising General Meetings; 

  managing the joint owners’ council;

  managing the financial operations and keeping the accounts of the jointly owned property association; 

  managing the jointly owned property in compliance with its rules and regulations; 

  carrying out periodic visits and inspections of the jointly owned property.

 All such services are treated as an overall performance obligation satisfied over time. In fact, these different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., management of the jointly owned property association. Annual revenue from basic property management fees is therefore recognised on a percentage-of-completion basis (over time) based on actual amounts billed (costs are in line with the billed amounts). 

 Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service, for example, additional meetings and visits, rules and regulations of the jointly owned property, physical and administrative management of claims, technical work and surveys, litigation and disputes. Since each additional service represents a separate performance obligation, revenue is recognised when the service is performed. 

  Rental management business 

 In its rental management business, the Group acts as agent for owners-lessors and fulfils a certain number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These mainly concern: 

  routine management services, for example, rent reviews and collection, annual adjustment invoice for expenses, sending of rent receipts to lessees, and deposits;

  other one-off management services, including preparation of the lease contract, inventory of premises, compilation of documentation, management of claims, administrative filings, and requests for subsidies;

  technical management services, such as on-site repairs, mandatory technical surveys, and preparation of essential information documents for lessees;

  insurance against unpaid rent; 

  other insurance such as for vacant premises or property damage.

 These represent separate service obligations. Accordingly, revenue for each of these obligations is recognised separately. Revenue from services provided over time, such as routine management services and insurance (falling outside the scope of IFRS 4) is recognised on a percentage-of-completion basis by reference to the frequency with which expenses are rebilled to the owners. Revenue from one-off services is recognised when those services are provided. 


-----

######  Lettings 

 Revenue is recognised at the time the inventory of the premises is conducted. The Group collects fees from owners and from lessees. 

  Transactions business/Efficity

 Revenue on the transactions business is recognised upon signature of the notarised final sale agreement (acte authentique), which is the date on which control is presumed to have been transferred. 

  Client accounts

 Interest income generated on client funds is booked in revenue.

  Assurimo

 Assurismo provides property insurance brokerage services. Revenue under comprehensive property insurance and comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies is recognised over the term of the cover, since services in this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis. 

  Constatimmo

 Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for lessees. Its revenue is recognised and measured when the related services are performed. 

  Seiitra

 Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and developed the Thetrawin software, which it markets through the sale of software licenses. These property management tools offer the full suite of functionalities needed to keep accounting records for client accounts and to manage suspense accounts, jointly owned properties and rentals, as well as the budget of jointly owned property associations. Maintenance fees are recognised on a straight-line, percentage-of-completion basis, since the corresponding services are provided over time. 

  Esset Management

 Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental services) for institutions. The accounting principles applied are the same as those explained above for the private property management business. 

  Foncia Valorisation

 Foncia Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, block/unit property sales) for institutional clients or wealthy families. Its revenue is recognised at the date the notarised final sale agreement is signed and is based on a percentage of the sale price. 

  Leeemo

 Leemo, a wholly-owned Group subsidiary since 2017, is a listing service for properties for sale. It has developed a digital platform for property companies where it lists new real estate projects by different developers as well as certain older properties that are to be made available for sale to private and institutional investors. 

 It derives its revenue from two main sources: 
  fees on sale agreements: amounts billed to developers and partially retroceded to business providers. Only the net margin is recognised in revenue.
  fees on bundles of services sold to developers without any retrocession requirements. 


-----

###### Revenue from fees on sale agreements is recognised when the notarised final sale agreement is signed. Revenue from fees earned on bundles of services is recognised on a pro rata basis in the period. 

 3.4.21. Recurring operating profit (loss)
 Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses)”.
 Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items.  Costs relating to business combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss).

 3.4.22. Non-recurring operating income (expenses)
 This caption includes income and expense items that, owing to their nature, amount or frequency, cannot be considered as arising in the ordinary course of the Group’s operations and are therefore not reported in recurring operating profit (loss). Non-recurring items are limited, unusual and/or irregular items of a material amount. 
 They include impacts of changes in the scope of consolidation, goodwill impairment, and amortisation and impairment charged against trademarks and software. If material, non-recurring items also include the effects of certain unusual transactions such as capital gains and losses on disposals of non-current assets, restructuring fees, fees relating to major claims and disputes, and any other income or expenses likely to affect the comparability of recurring operating profit (loss) from one period to the next.
 It should be noted that for transactions directly related to external growth and projects to transform or restructure the business (particularly mergers and reorganisations), a detailed procedure is in place to identify, classify and validate any transactions of a non-recurring nature. This procedure gives a precise indication of transactions that meet the criteria to be recorded in this category. 

 3.4.23. Operating profit (loss)
 Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions.

 3.4.24. Cost of net debt
 The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less financial income from cash investments.

 3.4.25. Income tax
 Income tax expense for the year includes current and deferred income tax expense, which are recognised in the statement of profit and loss except when they relate to items recognised in other comprehensive income. 
 The Group calculates its current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which its earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where the Group’s subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities.
 Income tax expense includes the amounts reported by French subsidiaries in respect of the CVAE tax assessed on value added, since the Group considers this tax meets the definition of income tax set out in IAS 12 – Income Taxes. 


-----

###### When they have not been set against income tax, income tax credits that are not included in the calculation of taxable profit and that are always refunded by the State are recorded as subsidies and reduce the expenses to which they relate.

 3.4.26. Earnings (loss) per share
 Earnings (loss) per share corresponds to profit (loss) attributable to holders of ordinary shares divided by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the reporting period (excluding treasury shares).
 Operating segments The Group is not concerned by IFRS 8 – Operating Segments. Revenue is broken down by business in Note 5.1. 

 3.4.27. Statement of cash flows
 Consolidated cash and cash equivalents, changes in which are displayed in the statement of cash flows, are defined as the net balance of cash and cash equivalents, current bank overdraft facilities and bank credit balances repayable on demand that form an integral part of the cash management strategy.
 Changes in cash from operating activities are calculated based on operating profit (loss) adjusted for transactions with no cash impact.

###### 4.1.2. 2019 impairment tests
 The assumptions used in the tests and the approach applied are described below. 
 Impacts of IFRS 16 on the impairment testing approach 
 IFRS 16 introduces significant changes to the inputs used in impairment tests, including the net amount tested, debt and valuation multiples. It therefore requires entities to reconsider their testing approach. In this regard, several different approaches have been proposed by the regulators to assist entities in their transition to IFRS 16. 
 The first, which complies with IAS 36, involves increasing the carrying amount of the CGU by the amount of the right-of-use asset, without taking into account the IFRS 16 lease liability. This approach represents a change of practice and introduces a degree of complexity into the calculation of value in use, since (i) cash flows relating solely to fixed lease payments or similar are excluded from the calculation insofar as they constitute the new lease liability, (ii) the cash outflows required to renew the right-of-use assets are to be estimated (future reinvestment flows affecting both the series of annual projections and the terminal value), and (iii) the discount rate is to be adjusted (estimated impact on the WACC of the new cost of capital/cost of debt ratio).
 The second approach is similar to the one described above and involves eliminating the lease liability from the carrying amount of the CGU and from the value in use. This approach leads to similar difficulties as those seen above. 
 The third solution is to maintain the pre-IFRS 16 approach in terms of projecting future cash flows. Although the carrying amount of the CGU changes (increase in the value of the right-of-use asset net of the lease liability), the calculation of value in use is not affected: 

 - projected cash outflows relating to lease payments remain unchanged for both the annual forecasts and for the terminal value; 

 - the discount rate is determined by reference to pre-IFRS 16 inputs (no change in the cost of debt and the debt-to-equity ratio).

 As the practical complexity of the first two approaches could undermine the reliability of the calculations (insufficient hindsight regarding the adjustment of certain cash flow inputs), the Group chose to use the third approach for its impairment tests in 2019. 
 Calculation of the carrying amount of CGUs at 31 December 2019 
 Estimating the carrying amount of each CGU includes determining the value of the assets that may be directly attributed or reasonably allocated to the CGU and that will generate cash flows included in the calculation of value in use.

 Calculation of the recoverable amount of CGUs at 31 December 2019
 In accordance with the Group’s impairment testing approach (see Note 3.4.7), and in the absence of observable fair values in an organised market, the recoverable amount of CGUs corresponds to their value in use, which is defined as the sum of their net cash flows based on the latest forecasts for each CGU, determined using:

  a business plan prepared by management based on growth and profitability assumptions, taking into account past performance, forecast changes in the economic environment, and expected market trends;

  a terminal value calculated by capitalising normative cash flows obtained by extrapolating cash flows from the final year of the business plan, with a stable growth rate or a growth rate increasing steadily over the long term;

  expected cash flows discounted at a rate determined by reference to the weighted average cost of capital (WACC).
 The financial forecasts used in the impairment tests carried out at 31 December 2019 were prepared by management and cover a period of six years. They provide a consolidated view as well as a breakdown by CGU.

 It should be noted that all holding company expenses not allocated in the consolidated business plan were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU. Corporate functions are managed at individual country-level for the Property Management International CGU and are considered not material for the Services CGU. 

 The discount rate used is the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), calculated based on a sample of comparable European companies. A WACC was estimated for each foreign country, with the impacts of IFRS 16 eliminated
##### among the sample companies in order to obtain a pre-IFRS 16 segment financial structure. A WACC was then
###### calculated for the entire Foncia Group based on a weighting of each country’s contribution to total EBITDA. On this basis, a single weighted discount rate of 7.4% was used for all of the Group’s CGUs.

###### Trademarks 

 At the date on which Foncia Management acquired a controlling interest in Foncia Holding (September 2016), the Foncia Group and Domicim trademarks were recognised at an amount of €414.2 million based on their valuations. The Group also estimated the value of the Brolliet trademark at CHF €13.7 million (i.e., €12.5 million at 31 December 2019). 

 Changes in the scope of consolidation reflect the derecognition of the Foncia Pierre Gestion trademark, which had been valued at €6 million during the purchase price accounting for Foncia Management. 
 Concessions, patents and software 

 Concessions, patents and software include the systems measured in connection with the purchase price accounting for Foncia Management at €10.4 million, as well as the management software used by Lodgis representing €1.7 million. The Syndic+ software had been written down in full at end-June 2019 in an amount of €4.3 million (impairment recognised within non-recurring expenses). 

 Investments in the period amounting to €2 million mainly concern the Swiss entities for €1.2 million (DBS Immobilier and Gribi). 

 Other changes amounting to €32.7 million chiefly concern (i) the capitalisation of intangible assets in progress, including €17.6 million for the Seiitra network in respect of upgraded Thetrawin (Powimo project) and regulatory (Thetrawin Legacy) modules, and (ii) Foncia Groupe for €5.6 million in respect of miscellaneous ongoing IT projects.
 Business goodwill/client relationships 

 At the time of Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting, the fair value of the Foncia Group’s client relationships was estimated at €460.8 million, breaking down between the Group’s three CGUs as follows: (i) Property Management France (excluding the transactions business): €396.2 million, (ii) Property Management International (Germany, Switzerland, Belgium): €2.2 million, and (iii) Services: €62.5 million.

 Following the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Brolliet group in September 2016, client relationships were valued at CHF 7.5 million (€6.9 million at 31 December 2019).

 Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €5.8 million reflect the derecognition of Foncia Pierre Gestion client relationships. Similarly, the Foncia Primaliance client relationship was reclassified within assets held for sale in an amount of €3 million. 

 Investments totalling €1.3 million primarily relate to acquisitions of business goodwill within the scope of external growth transactions carried out in the period.

###### Other intangible assets 

 Other intangible assets essentially comprise the cost of acquiring new business. The €5 million increase in this item during the period reflects the capitalisation of the costs of acquiring new mandates, rebilled to other firms in the network. Decreases totalling €1.5 million relate to the retirement of these costs for lots that were not secured in the period. 
 Intangible assets in progress 

 Intangible assets in progress include various Group projects that can be capitalised. At 31 December 2019, the main contributors to this item are Foncia Groupe for €22.5 million in relation to IT projects, Foncia Stark for €17 million in relation to the development of the Millenium software, and Seiitra for €2 million in relation to the Powimo project.
 Advances and downpayments  The net €0.7 million increase in advances and downpayments reflects external growth investments in business goodwill.

###### Most leases relate to Group business premises. These contracts are managed using a dynamic approach directly in line with the operating performance of the Group’s branch network and its real estate strategy. In France, around 808 property leases were included in this caption, of which more than 44% are automatically renewable. At 1 January 2019, the most important such leases relate to the head office at Antony, Esset Management’s premises at Aubervilliers, and the Boulevard Haussmann and Boulevard de Courcelles premises in Paris. Changes in the period can be explained as follows: 
  Changes in the scope of consolidation concern property leases taken on from the various companies acquired
 in the period, notably Sigla (€3.8 million), Bourgeois Immobilier (€1.9 million) and OTIM (€1.3 million). 
  Reductions in the lease term mainly relate to the derecognition of Esset Management’s Aubervilliers lease
 for €8.7 million (the company moved its premises to Courbevoie at the end of the year) and to the early derecognition of the Foncia Paris Rive Droite lease at 6-8 boulevard Haussmann in Paris for €4 million. 
  New leases for €32.9 million concern a total of 53 new contracts. However, the six main leases account for
 almost 64% of right-of-use assets. These include the lease of the Rue Raymond Losserand premises in Paris for €7.5 million and the lease of Esset Management’s new premises in Courbevoie for €6.7 million. 

 For the vehicle fleet in France, the first-time application of IFRS 16 resulted in the reclassification of CIC lease contracts measured at €2.6 million under IAS 17 and the measurement of 188 Arval contracts for €1.7 million at 1 January 2019. New leases concern 860 new vehicles delivered by Arval in 2019, which had a €5 million impact on lease liabilities and right-of-use assets. Reductions in the lease term relate to the derecognition of 570 CIC vehicle leases, with only two vehicles under CIC leases still on the road at 31 December 2019.

###### Deferred tax liabilities mainly arise from the recognition of intangible assets within the scope of the purchase price accounting for Foncia Management in September 2016. Changes in the year primarily reflect the 28.92% income tax rate used to determine deferred taxes under the liability method (compared to a rate of 25.83% previously). 

 Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €2.9 million reflect the derecognition of deferred tax liabilities on the Foncia Pierre Gestion trademark and client relationships. 

 Other non-monetary changes representing a negative amount of €3.3 million concern: 

 (i) deferred tax liabilities recognised by Lodgis for €1 million following the finalisation of the purchase price accounting process and the recognition of a trademark and software for a total of €4 million; 

 (ii) the reclassification of tax representing a negative amount of €1.6 million, recorded against deferred taxes on other adjustments. 

 Changes in deferred taxes on other adjustments attributable to changes in the scope of consolidation for €6.9 million reflect the cancellation of existing business goodwill in the individual statement of financial position of companies consolidated for the first time during the period. 

 Deferred taxes on temporary differences mainly arise on acquisition-related fees, provisions for employee profit-sharing and paid leave, and the tax treatment of translation adjustments.

###### As described in the “Highlights of the year” section, the Group carried out various transactions in the year involving its syndicated credit facility: 

  On 3 May 2019, it arranged a new senior facility B tranche for €178 million, intended to refinance the full amount drawn under the revolving credit facility, the authorised overdraft as well as the debt restructuring fees.
  On 31 July 2019, it arranged an additional new senior facility B tranche for €110 million in order to refinance the full amount of the second-lien loan. 

 The applicable terms and conditions for these new tranches are closely aligned with those of the term loan B. The characteristics of the Group’s main financing facilities are set out below in Note 4.12.3. 

 The fees for these two operations represented €3.1 million and €0.8 million, respectively, and will be recognised over the residual term of the debt by adjusting financial expenses using the effective interest rate method. 
  The Group also extended the amount available for drawdown under its revolving credit facility by €70 million, bringing the total amount of the facility (including the authorised overdraft) to €220 million. The fees for this operation represented €650,000. At 31 December 2019, the revolving credit facility had been repaid in full. 
 It should also be noted that the 2015 CICE prefinancing credit was refunded in 2019 in an amount of €7.8 million.
 Following the Group’s 22 May 2019 acquisition of the 55% stake in the Initiative et Partenaire sub-group that it did not already own, the €3.2 million liability representing the minority put was reversed against consolidated equity. Similarly, the earn-out on FIPM shares was cleared in February 2019 for €3 million. 
 Update on the financial liabilities recognised in respect of the preferred shares issued within the scope of the Leemo/Primonial transaction
 By way of reminder, at 31 December 2018 these preferred shares were classified within financial liabilities by default and included within net debt for €7 million, since the basis on which the shares issued within the scope of the aforementioned transaction could be converted did not represent a fixed basis. 

 At the end of each reporting period, the Group is required to assess the convertibility of these preferred shares in 2021, which depends on changes in the respective contributions of the Foncia Group and Primonial to Leemo’s net revenue. An analysis of each group’s contribution could allow either (i) Primonial to increase its interest in Leemo to a maximum of 48,457 shares (49% of the share capital), or (ii) the Foncia Group to collect up to €2 million in cash compensation. 

 Based on 2019 revenue, the situation favours the Foncia Group. However, a conservative approach was adopted when preparing the 2019 financial statements and no receivable was recognised.

###### The actuarial estimate of provisions for retirement benefits and long-service awards was based on the report drawn up by Mercer, the firm mandated to estimate post-employment benefit obligations for the entire Group. A provision is set aside for all outstanding obligations, estimated based on rights accrued and salary projections, taking into account mortality rates, employee turnover and a discount assumption. 
 For France, the increase in provisions for retirement benefits is mainly attributable to the service cost totalling €1.3 million, reflecting the increase in the net obligation resulting from the contributions of Foncia personnel in 2019. 
 Net actuarial gains of €0.5 million reflect:

 (i) an increase of €0.8 million in the obligation attributable to new beneficiaries resulting from companies acquired in 2018; 

 (ii) a decrease of €0.3 million related to the revised turnover table based on actual employee turnover rates in
 the 2013-2018 period. It should be specified that in accordance with IAS 19, this table only reflects natural attrition and therefore excludes lay-offs and terminations by mutual agreement (rupture conventionnelle). 

 These actuarial gains are recognised in consolidated equity net of tax.

 The increase in long-service awards essentially results from actuarial gains of €1 million. These actuarial gains are attributable to various factors, including: 

 (i) €0.7 million related to experience adjustments (owing mainly to new beneficiaries resulting from companies acquired in 2018); 

 (ii) €0.4 million related to the revised turnover table, which takes into account forced departures.

 The take-up rate for long-service awards has been set at 100%, as in 2018.

 Obligations in respect of long-service awards are included within other long-term benefits in accordance with IAS 19. In this respect, any actuarial gains and losses are to be taken to profit or loss in the period. Since these actuarial gains and losses result from exceptional events, they were included in non-recurring operating items.

###### Changes in provisions for other disputes 
 The significant decrease in provisions for other disputes follows the reversal of provisions for Orpi and franchisee disputes, with an impact of €1.6 million and €0.8 million, respectively, on non-recurring operating items. 

  Update on the dispute with franchisees

 As a reminder, in 2014-2015 former franchisees had brought proceedings against the Foncia Group after receiving notice that their contracts would not be renewed. They accused the Group of wrongful termination and various breaches of the franchise agreements. Of the 21 initial lawsuits representing an aggregate €19.3 million, disputes with only seven franchisees were still ongoing at the reporting date, representing €4.5 million. At 31 December 2019, the provision set aside in respect of these disputes was reduced to €0.5 million. In January 2020, an initial decision was handed down in favour of Foncia Franchise, in which the court dismissed all of the franchisee’s claims (including those that had been successful in first instance). The six other disputes will be heard by the same court between end-May and end-June 2020. 

  Update on the ORPI dispute 

 A preliminary agreement was negotiated with ORPI providing for the payment of €0.5 million in compensation to settle the dispute between four Foncia entities and ORPI. The related provision was written back in full at 31 December 2019. 
 Changes in provisions for employee disputes 

 Provisions for employee disputes concerned 98 lawsuits compared to 108 lawsuits at 31 December 2018. Out of the 98 lawsuits, 27 are in progress and relate to amounts in excess of €100,000. In all, the claims represent approximately €13.3 million. The resolution of employee disputes in the period resulted in expenses of €0.8 million and a write-back of €1.6 million from the provision. 
 Changes in provisions for URSSAF social security audits 

 This caption includes provisions for URSSAF audits that had been measured in the opening statement of financial position after a risk was identified on benefits in kind for €0.9 million. Since a portion of the reassessment risk has exceeded the statute of limitations, the Group partially wrote back this provision, with the resulting €0.5 million reversal recorded in non-recurring operating items.

###### Client accounts and “Article 55” transaction (Hoguet law) accounts
 Accounting for client accounts is a separate and autonomous form of accounting. At 31 December 2019, the balance of client accounts and “Article 55” transaction accounts therefore represents all of the transactions carried out for each client account. This balance totalled €530.9 million, reported under assets and liabilities in the statement of financial position at 31 December 2019. 
 France’s ALUR law requires the use of separate accounts for jointly owned properties comprising more than 15 main lots as from 1 April 2015. Accordingly, Foncia decided not to present separate accounts for its joint ownership association management activities in its statement of financial position. The ordinance dated 31 October 2019 now requires separate accounts to be established for all jointly owned properties by 31 December 2020 at the latest. As a result, funds held in respect of jointly owned properties are expected to decrease sharply in 2020. 
 The statement of financial position does not include any amount for Germany or Belgium, which only use separate accounts.

###### In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, which set out the rules for measuring and recognising financial instruments, instruments with a positive fair value are recognised in assets and those with a negative fair value are recognised in liabilities. Fair values of financial instruments are provided by the financial institutions with which the transactions are carried out.

 4.18.1. Interest rate derivatives 
 Further to its refinancing on 7 September 2016, the Group entered into an interest rate cap agreement on 7 December 2016 under the terms and conditions set out below: 

 • Notional amount: €527.9 million 
 • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor 
 • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1% 
 • Hedging period: 7 December 2016 to 6 December 2019. This hedge was no longer in force at 31 December 2019. 
 On 19 October 2017, the Group also entered into an additional deferred interest rate cap agreement under the following terms and conditions: 

 • Notional amount: €400 million 
 • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor 
 • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1.5% 
 • Hedging period: 7 December 2019 to 6 December 2020 
 The historic premiums paid in respect of these two cap agreements totalled €915,000.
 On 24 May 2019, the Group entered into an additional interest rate cap agreement under the following terms and conditions:

 • Notional amount: €70 million (7 June 2019 to 9 September 2019), then €200 million (9 September 2019 to 7 September 2020)
 • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor 
 • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1.25% 
 • Hedging period: 7 June 2019 to 7 September 2020  
 The premium paid in respect of this cap agreement in 2019 totalled €5,000.
 Given the prevailing negative interbank interest rate environment, these derivative instruments have a fair value of zero in the 2019 financial statements.

###### Current income tax expense excluding the tax consolidation group essentially concerns Foncia Pierre Gestion for €1.2 million and Foncia Brette for €0.5 million. Current income tax expense for foreign companies relates mainly to Switzerland for €1.1 million and Belgium for €0.9 million.
 A provision for tax contingencies was set aside by Esset Management on 18 December 2019 after the company received notification from the French tax authorities of a tax reassessment related mainly to unjustified expenses. This provision has been reclassified within current income tax expense in accordance with IAS 12. 
 Deferred tax income recognised in the year mainly relates to the decrease in the deferred tax rate in France, from 28.92% in 2018 to 25.83% in 2019. 
 Tax loss carry-forwards 
 Tax loss carry-forwards within the tax consolidation group at 31 December 2019 are as follows (after utilisation in the current period):

 • Loss arising on tax consolidation: €16.6 million. This tax loss has been recognised in full in view of the high probability that sufficient future taxable profit will exist against which it can be utilised. 

 • Proprietary tax losses of consolidated companies: €20.7 million, of which €20 million were not recognised, mainly relating to Foncia Holding (€8.9 million), IDHA (€4.8 million) and Syndic+ (€2.8 million).
 New deductibility rules for financial expenses in France 
 New rules applicable to reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2019 redefine the applicable framework for deductible financial expenses in France. The new rules are designed to implement Article 4 of the EU Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD) into French law. Financial expenses were previously deductible at a single rate of 75% (“rabot” rule). This single rate has been replaced by a new approach introducing a cap to be calculated for each company or each tax consolidation group, as applicable. 
 Although the tax group is thinly capitalised on the basis of debt-to-equity rules, its debt-to-equity ratio is lower than that of the consolidated group. Accordingly, it deducted financial expenses at the statutory rate of 30% of its taxable EBITDA. By demonstrating its “financial independence” and therefore its eligibility for the safeguard clause, the tax consolidation group was granted an additional right to deduction representing up to 75% of net non-deducted expenses. 
 Impact of the decrease in the income tax rate on deferred tax liabilities 
 In line with the phased reduction in income tax in France through to 2022 (2020 budget), the Group cut its deferred tax rate for French entities to 25.83% from 28.92% previously. In accordance with IAS 12, adjustments related to this change in the tax rate are accounted for in a symmetrical manner and mainly included in profit or loss (when they relate to items themselves recognised in profit or loss). Taking into account a target tax rate for deferred tax bases resulted in a reduction of €15.8 million in net deferred tax liabilities and led to a corresponding increase in profit under the liability method.
 This significant decrease is attributable to a change in management’s assessment of projected cuts in this tax rate, finally agreed in 2018 after various postponements that had cast doubt on its introduction, and to the long-term timeframe for disposing of intangible assets.

###### NOTE 8. FINANCIAL RISK EXPOSURE

 Interest rate risk
 The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralised basis. They are mainly indexed to 3-month Euribor. The risk management policy is set by management. 

 Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for the Group’s companies are centralised under a cash pooling agreement and managed by the Group’s Treasury department. 

 The Group’s Treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritises liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month Euribor or is at fixed rates (term accounts).

###### NOTE 10. LITIGATION AND CONTINGENT LIABILITIES
 Update on the UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) dispute 
 On 1 October 2014, UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) brought proceedings against Foncia Groupe before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance (regional court) seeking damages for losses allegedly suffered by lessees of Foncia-managed properties who were unduly charged for receiving notices to pay (avis d’échéance). 
 More specifically, UFC is seeking payment from Foncia Groupe of an amount of €2.30 per month and per lessee over a period of five years and estimates the number of lessees concerned at 318,400, bringing the total damages to €44 million. 
 In its defence, the Group argues that the French law of 6 July 1989 on residential lease agreements, upon which basis UFC filed its claim, made no provision for class actions at the time of the alleged offence; that no law existed preventing lessees being charged for receiving notices to pay; and that this was therefore a lawful practice. 
 Oral arguments were exchanged before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance in March 2018. The decision handed down in May 2018 dismissed UFC’s claims on the grounds that they fell outside the scope of a class action. 
 UFC has appealed the decision and the hearings before the Court of Appeal are scheduled for 23 April 2020.
 The Group considers that no provision needs to be accrued in this respect in its financial statements at 31 December 2019. 
 NOTE 11. SUBSEQUENT EVENTS

 Signing of a preliminary agreement to sell Foncia Primaliance shares
 Following the 1 August 2019 signing of an agreement in principle with a major asset manager in France, the Group signed the preliminary agreement for the sale of Foncia Primaliance shares on 6 March 2020. 

 Covid-19 epidemic
 Context 
 The unprecedented public health crisis caused by the Covid-19 epidemic that has spread across the globe is affecting economies and businesses around the world and having significant impacts on all industries and geographic areas. Governments have taken steps to address the crisis. 

 The impacts of the epidemic include: 

  direct and immediate impacts on certain business activities owing to the fall in demand for certain services;
  widespread impacts such as the temporary closure of premises, disruptions in the supply chain, the unavailability of human resources and the potential liquidity difficulties of certain debtors;
  more generally, a downturn in the economy as a whole, with considerable uncertainty as to the length and severity of the disruption.


-----

###### Consequences of the impacts of the Covid-19 epidemic on the financial statements at 31 December 2019 
 Based on the situation at 31 December 2019 (i.e., limited cases of the virus and the lack of any global health warning by the World Health Organization (WHO) at that date), the Group considers that the consequences of the public health and economic crisis caused by Covid-19 relate to the 2020 financial period and do not confirm a situation existing prior to 31 December 2019, insofar as the events create a situation that did not exist at 31 December 2019 and which does not compromise the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern (the most important measures of the business continuity plan put in place by management are presented below). Accordingly, the amounts reported at 31 December 2019 may not be adjusted. 
 Consequences of the impacts of the Covid-19 epidemic on the Group’s businesses in 2020
 In accordance with the decisions taken by the government in order to comply with social distancing recommendations, all Foncia Group premises (branches and head offices) are closed to the public until further notice, as well as to employees (barring exceptional cases). Real estate agents can no longer travel to sign mandates, make visits or meet with notaries.

 The general lockdown measures imposed on the French population have effectively frozen the property market and the transactions business is virtually at a standstill. Physical visits of properties are forbidden during the lockdown period and those that had been scheduled were cancelled. The rental market is also affected by the crisis, as the removal industry along with the utility vehicle rental business are severely disrupted, effectively blocking the departure and arrival of lessees. 

 The rental management market can continue to function normally from a purely administrative perspective. There is little movement in rental properties. However, there is a significant risk that fees on unpaid rent will be collected later than expected, even though rent must still be paid by law. 

 The jointly owned property management business remains and will remain fairly sheltered from the crisis, although it may generate an increased workload from an administrative, legal and commercial perspective. The chain of continuity for services continues to function, despite delays regarding joint ownership property charges. However, the Group expects a fall in revenue from incidental fees such as for transfers or renovation work. It should be noted that several ordinances have been issued by the French government to protect and support companies operating in the real estate sector. One of these ordinances concerns the guaranteed continuity of mandates for jointly owned property associations, even if they expire in the period from 12 March to 31 December 2020. 

 Without compromising the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern, direct impacts are expected and have already been observed in 2020 on revenue, margins and operating cash flows relating to the transactions and lettings businesses and, to a lesser extent, to the French and international jointly owned property business. 
 Business continuity plan

  Human resources and organisation 

 The different procedures put in place to address this unprecedented environment are designed to protect the health of employees but also to ensure that a minimum and critical level of business can continue, subject to changes in government regulations: 

 • Homeworking has been introduced for all employees whose work can be performed from home and who have the necessary tools available. 

 • More specifically, in its property management and transactions network, an exceptional travel certificate has been granted to managers so that they can carry out minimum duties alongside senior executives. An exceptional, occasional travel certificate subject to restrictions has also been issued to critical employees dealing, for example, with incoming correspondence, cash inflows and payments, and handovers. 

 • For employees facing increasingly difficult working conditions such as lettings negotiators, developers or real estate consultants, short-time working arrangements have been put in place. 


-----

###### Each department is currently finalising its own organisational and communications guidelines for these exceptional circumstances using various procedures.

  Financing 
 Out of prudence, the Group made two drawdowns on its revolving credit facility on 16 and 19 March 2020 for a total of €190 million in order to secure its liquidity. Certain due dates for payments under major leases have been pushed back in order to protect cash levels, particularly in the transactions business. 

  External growth strategy

 Wherever possible, the Group has pushed back corporate sale agreements due to be signed during the lockdown period to 1 June 2020 at the earliest.

**Opinion**

In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us pursuant to your articles of association, we have
audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management for the year ended
31 December 2018.

In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and
liabilities and of the financial position of the Group at 31 December 2018 and of the results of its
operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as
adopted by the European Union.

**Basis for opinion**

**_Audit framework_**

We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe
that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our
opinion.

Our responsibilities under these standards are further described in the “Responsibilities of the
Statutory Auditors relating to the audit of the consolidated financial statements” section of our report.

**_Independence_**

We conducted our audit engagement in compliance with the independence rules applicable to us, for
the period from 1 January 2018 to the date of our report, and, in particular, we did not provide any
non-audit services prohibited by the French Code of Ethics (Code de déontologie) for Statutory
Auditors.

**Emphasis of matter**

Without qualifying our opinion, we draw your attention to the matter set out in Note 3.2.2 – Changes
in the accounting standards, to the consolidated financial statements concerning the entry into force of
IFRS 9 and IFRS 15, which are mandatorily applicable as of 1 January 2018.

**Justification of assessments**

In accordance with the requirements of articles L.823-9 and R.823-7 of the French Commercial Code
(Code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the following
assessments that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant in our audit of the
consolidated financial statements.

These matters were addressed as part of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole,
and therefore contributed to the opinion we formed as expressed above. We do not provide a separate
opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements.

The Group tests goodwill and assets with indefinite useful lives for impairment on an annual basis, in
accordance with the methods presented in Notes 3.4.7 – Impairment losses on goodwill, intangible
assets and property, plant and equipment and 4.1.3 – Assumptions used in the 2018 impairment tests,
to the consolidated financial statements. We examined the methods used by the Group to test for
impairment, together with the cash flow forecasts and assumptions relied upon for that purpose. We
further verified that the notes provide appropriate disclosures. As part of our assessments, we also
ensured that the estimates used were reasonable.

**Specific verifications**

As required by legal and regulatory provisions and in accordance with professional standards
applicable in France, we have also verified the information pertaining to the Group presented in the
Chairman’s management report.

We have no matters to report as to its fair presentation and its consistency with the consolidated
financial statements.

to cease operations.

**Responsibilities of the Statutory Auditors relating to the audit of the consolidated**
**financial statements**

Our role is to issue a report on the consolidated financial statements. Our objective is to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free of
material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that
an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material
misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material
if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic
decisions taken by users on the basis of these consolidated financial statements.

As specified in article L.823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code, our audit does not include assurance
on the viability or quality of the Company’s management.

As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the
Statutory Auditors exercise professional judgement throughout the audit.

They also:

  - identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the consolidated financial statements,

whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures in response to those risks,
and obtain audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for their
opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than
for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions,
misrepresentations, or the override of internal control;

  - obtain an understanding of the internal control procedures relevant to the audit in order to

design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of
expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control;

  - evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting

estimates made by management and the related disclosures in the notes to the consolidated
financial statements;

  - assess the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and,

based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or
conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going
concern. This assessment is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the audit
report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a
going concern. If the Statutory Auditors conclude that a material uncertainty exists, they are

###### NOTE 1. GENERAL PRESENTATION

 Information concerning the Foncia Management Group
 Foncia Management is a French simplified joint stock company (société par actions simplifiée) with a sole shareholder, subject to all regulations governing commercial companies in France, and in particular the provisions of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce). Its registered office is located at 13 avenue Lebrun, 92160 Antony, France.

 Description of Group businesses
 Foncia Groupe is a European leader in residential property services. It assists its clients at all stages of the property life cycle, with a comprehensive, integrated service offering that includes management of jointly owned properties, round-the-clock assistance, rental management, rentals, sales, purchases, holiday lettings, appraisals, insurance, technical surveys and energy brokerage. 
 Foncia operates in France, Germany, Belgium and Switzerland.

 Information presented
 Statutory 2017 consolidated financial statements
 The Foncia Management Group (the “Group”) comprising Foncia Management and its subsidiaries, was created on 7 September 2016 further to the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Foncia Holding group. The Group prepared its consolidated financial statements for the first time for the period ended 31 December 2017. 
 These financial statements covered: 

   - 20 months of operations for Foncia Management, from its creation in May 2016 to 31 December 2017;

   - 16 months of operations for the Foncia Holding group, from its acquisition by Foncia Management on
###### 7 September 2016 to 31 December 2017. 
 Since this does not allow a meaningful comparison with results of operations for an equivalent 12-month period, profit and loss data for the period ended 31 December 2017 are not used as comparative data. They are included for information purposes under “2017 (presented)”. 
 Pro forma 2017 consolidated financial statements

 The pro forma 2017 results of operations include 12 months of operations for Foncia Management and the Foncia Holding group. The main accounting policies applied are the same as those applied to prepare the statutory consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management. 
 However, the Group applied IFRS 15 on revenue recognition and IFRS 9 on financial instruments for the first time in 2018. Accordingly, the first-time application impacts have been separated out for 2017 to enable a meaningful comparison. 
 The consolidated results of operations for the period ended 31 December 2017 have been restated to reflect the application of these standards as if they had been applied from 1 January 2017. These restated figures appear throughout as “2017 (restated pro forma)”. 
 2018 consolidated financial statements
 The 2018 consolidated financial statements reflect the statutory financial statements and do not contain any pro forma restatements. They have been prepared in accordance with international accounting standards and


-----

###### interpretations (IAS/IFRS) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at 1 January 2018. Consequently, they include the impacts of the first-time application of IFRS 15 and IFRS 9.
