 Efficity
 In April 2018, the outstanding balance of the initial earn-out negotiated at the time of the Efficity acquisition in 2015 was allocated to its historic founders and managers in an amount of €4.5 million (€5.2 million had already been paid in 2017). 
 To secure the founders’ and managers’ loyalty and their commitment to Efficity’s future development, the Group entered into a new agreement with them using a specific legal structure based on the creation of an intermediate holding company (Foncia Saturne) controlling Efficity’s entire share capital.
 The Group offered the aforementioned founders and key managers the possibility of reinvesting part of the proceeds from this earn-out in the holding company’s capital increase carried out for a total of €7 million (the historic founders invested €3 million, while the Group contributed €4 million). This reinvestment gives the founders the opportunity to realise a potential capital gain at the end of a four-year period, depending on future trends in the company’s operating performance. 


-----

###### In light of the terms and conditions of the transaction driven by the Group’s interests, the acquisition was accounted for as an extension of the initial earn-out clause. The value of the initial earn-out was therefore recalculated (to the extent of the €3 million reinvested by the founders) at the date the new agreement was signed. 

 ➢ Since the partner-founders are exposed to the risk that they may lose the capital invested if the “bad leaver”
 clause applies, non-recurring income of €3 million was recognized in the period. This income reflects the remeasurement of the initial earn-out liability (from €4.5 million to €1.5 million). 
 ➢ Efficity continues to be fully consolidated, since the Group intends to retain sole control of the entity upon
 completion of the transaction. 

 Leemo/Primonial partial asset contribution
 Overview of the transaction
 The Primonial and Foncia groups set up Leemo, a joint venture, to pool their respective skills and resources in terms of listing new and existing properties via their digital platform. 
 On 30 November 2018, Primonial acquired a 40% equity interest in Leemo (the percentage interest is subject to change depending on certain criteria owing to the preferred shares issued in consideration of the contribution – see below) through a partial asset contribution consisting of Primonial’s entire, stand-alone sales brokerage division for new and existing properties. A 10-year shareholders’ agreement was signed with the Primonial group.
 Consideration for the contribution 
 Based on an estimated value of €7 million for the division, consideration for the contribution consisted of 33,624 preferred shares each with a par value of €1, bringing Leemo’s share capital to 84,059 shares. The resulting contribution premium was €6,966,376. The contribution consisted mainly of intangible assets, which were measured by mutual agreement at €7 million. 
 Conversion of preferred shares 
 Besides carrying the same rights as ordinary shares, preferred shares may also be automatically converted into ordinary shares in 2021 in a proportion based on the “outperformance” achieved, as assessed according to changes in the respective contributions of the Primonial and Foncia groups to Leemo’s net revenue. 
 An analysis of each group’s contribution could allow either (i) Primonial to increase its interest in Leemo to a maximum of 48,457 shares (49% of the share capital), or (ii) Foncia to collect up to €2 million in cash compensation.
 Accounting treatment applied 
 Based on the majority shareholding in Leemo and the governance arrangements in place, the Group decided that it retained sole control of Leemo and that it would therefore continue to fully consolidate the company. 

 The basis on which preferred shares may be converted also led the Group to consider that the financial asset adopted as consideration for the contribution (ordinary shares after conversion) did not represent a fixed basis for the exchange at 31 December 2018. Accordingly, it cannot demonstrate that a fixed number of ordinary shares will be offered as consideration for the aforementioned preferred shares. 
 From the perspective of applicable accounting standards and IAS 32 in particular, this consideration prevents the preferred shares from being recognised as equity instruments. The preferred shares are therefore classified as financial liabilities by default. 
 At 31 December 2018, considering that the “neutral” scenario was most likely, the liability was measured at 40% of Leemo’s enterprise value, i.e., €7 million, and was classified within non-current borrowings. 


-----

###### Implementation of a free share plan by Foncia Stark
 Characteristics of the plan:

 - Grant date: 23 May 2018  - Date on which the continuing employment condition is assessed: 23 May 2020  - Vesting period for the shares: between 23 May 2018 and 23 May 2020 - Maximum number of shares awarded: up to 205,000 free shares in the company, representing 5.125% of its share capital - Maximum aggregate amount of the free share plan: €410,000 - The shares awarded are monetised through a new liquidity contract which prices the share using a calculation formula. - Corporate social contribution (forfait social): 20% of the free share plan
 The value of the free shares awarded represents discretionary compensation granted to employees. Since a liquidity contract has been set up, the shares awarded to beneficiaries will be settled in cash. The free share plan therefore meets the definition of a “cash-settled” plan set out in IFRS 2. Consequently, the service cost is recognized on a straight-line basis over the vesting period against a related liability. 
 At 31 December 2018, the service cost amounted to €149,000 and was recognized within capitalised production with an adjusting entry to employee-related payables. It will be amortised as from the date the “Millenium” project (development of new management software for the property management network) enters into service. The service cost will be reviewed each year in light of budget assumptions and turnover. 

 Debt restructuring
 On 18 July and 3 August 2018, the Group restructured its borrowings with its lenders in order to secure better interest terms.

 (i) Modification of the ICA tranche on 18 July 2018 

 - Reduction of 50 bps in the applicable margin: the “cash margin” is reduced from 7.5% to 7%, while the “PIK margin” is reduced from 8.5% to 8%.  - Elimination of the 3-month Euribor 1% floor: in the current negative interest rate environment, the E3M benchmark rate is therefore reduced to 0%.  - Elimination of applicable 2% penalties in the event of early repayment as from 18 July 2019. 

 (ii) Partial repayment of the ICA loan on 3 August 2018 

 Repayment of €77 million of this loan. The related fees for early repayment amount to €1.5 million.

 (iii) Subscription of a new €80 million tranche (“B4”) of the senior facility
 The financing terms applicable to this B4 tranche are identical to those applicable to the B3 tranche renegotiated in March 2017 (see Note 4.11.3). The issuance fees for the new tranche amount to €1.25 million and will be recognised over the term of the facility by an adjustment to financial expenses at the effective interest rate as calculated at 3 August 2018 (3.68%). 
 IFRS 9 accounting treatment 
 From an accounting perspective, this restructuring is part of an overall initiative to optimise the Group’s borrowing costs. The modifications were therefore analysed as a whole to determine whether they are substantial and therefore ascertain the appropriate accounting treatment to be used. 


-----

###### Based on this analysis, using both quantitative and qualitative tests, there were substantial modifications to the initial terms of the ICA loan. As a result, the initial accounting treatment was discontinued, with all related unamortised expenses charged to profit or loss in an amount of €4 million. The fees due on early repayment were immediately expensed in an amount of €1.5 million. 

 Economic and Social Unit (UES)
 On 21 August 2018, in response to strong employee demand for a single and harmonized framework within which to exercise their duties, the Versailles Tribunal d’Instance recognised the existence of an Economic and Social Unit (Unité Économique et Sociale – UES) between the various legal entities belonging to the network comprising the Property Management France/Transactions businesses, plus Foncia Carrières et Compétences (124 companies at 21 August 2018). This decision signals the start of a new, inclusive modus operandi as the basis for implementing the Group’s growth strategy and securing the commitment of all employees within its network.

###### NOTE 3. ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND METHODS

 General principles used to prepare the financial statements
 The accounting policies described in these notes have been applied consistently to all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, with the exception of the standards adopted as described in Note 3.2.2, effective as of 1 January 2018, including those relating to the first-time application of IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers and IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments.
 The consolidated financial statements are prepared on a historical cost basis, except for assets held for sale and related liabilities, measured in accordance with IFRS 5, and certain financial instruments carried at fair value or amortised cost in accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9. 
 The consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management at 31 December 2018 were adopted by the Supervisory Board at its meeting of 11 April 2019, and will be submitted to shareholders for approval at the General Meeting on 29 June 2019. 
 They are presented in thousands of euros and amounts are rounded up or down to the nearest thousand unless otherwise specified. Consequently, the sum of these amounts may differ slightly from the total amounts reported.

 Accounting standards

 3.2.1. Basis of preparation of financial information
 Pursuant to Regulation (EC) No. 1606/2002 of 19 July 2002 as amended by Regulation (EC) No. 297/2008 of 11 March 2008, the 2018 consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and interpretations issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at 1 January 2018. The full text of the standards adopted by the European Union can be consulted on the European Commission’s website: 
 https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting_en
 At the end of the reporting period, there was no difference between the IFRS used to prepare these financial statements and the standards adopted by the IASB and applicable for the period presented.
 The accounting policies and bases of measurement applied to prepare these consolidated financial statements are described in Note 3.4 below. 

 3.2.2. Changes in accounting standards
 Main IFRS standards, amendments and interpretations in force within the European Union and mandatorily applicable as of 1 January 2018
 The accounting policies and bases of measurement used by the Group to prepare its consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2018 are identical to those used by the Group at 31 December 2017, with the exception of:

   - IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers

###### On 28 May 2014, the IASB published IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which impacts the timing of revenue recognition by the Group. IFRS 15 sets out a single model framework to account for revenue arising on contracts with customers. According to the fundamental principle of the new standard, revenue is recognised based on when the goods and services promised in the contract are provided to the customer, and for the amount of consideration to which an entity expects to be entitled in exchange.


-----

###### IFRS 15 sets out a five-step model framework for recognising and measuring revenue. The new standard, which replaces IAS 18, was not early adopted by the Group.
 It was applied retrospectively at 1 January 2018 using the simplified retrospective transition method, i.e., the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 15 is recognised at 1 January 2018 as an adjustment to the opening balance of equity. Accordingly, equity at 31 December 2017 has been restated for the impacts of IFRS 15. A summary of the impacts of IFRS 15 on each line of the statement of financial position is provided below.

   - IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments

###### On 24 July 2014, the IASB published a new standard on financial instruments replacing most of the existing provisions under IFRS, and particularly IAS 39. The Group did not early adopt IFRS 9. 
 The requirements of the standard in terms of the classification, measurement and impairment of financial instruments are applied by the Group retrospectively, with no adjustments to information for comparative periods. 

 • Phase 1: Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities 
 IFRS 9 introduces new requirements for classifying and measuring financial assets and liabilities based on the entity’s business model and the applicable contractual terms. 
 Under IFRS 9, all equity instruments should be measured at fair value in the statement of financial position, with gains and losses either taken to profit or loss or recognised through other comprehensive income in accordance with an option taken by the entity that cannot subsequently be revoked. In this case, only dividends will tend to be recognised in profit or loss. 
 The Group has reviewed and measured its financial assets at 1 January 2018 in light of the facts and circumstances existing at that date, and considers that the first-time application of IFRS 9 would not have a material impact on the classification and measurement of the items concerned. The only impact is on the Group’s shareholdings in Swiss property companies and cooperatives, some of which were sold during the year. 
 Classified as held to maturity under IAS 39 (and therefore carried at amortised cost), these shareholdings have been reclassified within equity instruments carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. In this respect, they were remeasured at 1 January in an amount of €685,000, with an adjusting entry posted to total equity.
 Concerning the measurement of financial liabilities, IFRS 9 introduces very few changes to the requirements that existed under IAS 39, and no impacts were identified as a result of the new standard in the 2018 financial statements. 
 The Group had analysed its debt repricing operations in 2017 in light of the principles of IAS 39 but also taking into account the changes introduced by IFRS 9. Accordingly, the first-time application of IFRS 9 did not have any retrospective impact in the 2018 financial statements in this respect.

 • Phase 2: Impairment
 As a basis for financial asset impairment, IFRS 9 requires use of an expected loss model rather than the incurred loss model under IAS 39. The expected loss model requires entities to recognise expected losses on its receivables, with any changes in these losses to be recognised at the end of each reporting period in order to reflect changes in the credit risk since initial recognition. 


-----

###### Since impairment is not material in the Group’s B-to-C business, no changes were made to the accounting policies used to recognise impairment provisions. The Group is exposed to limited bad debt risk on its commercial receivables as the risk is concentrated mainly in Foncia IPM’s operations, which accounts for less than 4% of consolidated revenue. 

 • Phase 3: Hedge accounting
 The new requirements for general hedge accounting maintain the three hedging categories identified under IAS 39. IFRS 9 offers greater flexibility as regards transactions that may be eligible for hedge accounting, particularly in terms of instruments that may be designated as hedging instruments and the type of risks that may be hedged in a non-financial hedge. The hedge effectiveness test has also been revised and replaced by the notion of an “economic relationship” between the hedging instrument and the hedged item. The retrospective assessment of hedge effectiveness is no longer required. Broader disclosure requirements for entities in terms of risk management have also been introduced. 
 The Group does not use instruments meeting the definition of hedging instruments for accounting purposes.

   - IFRS 16 – Leases

###### IFRS 16, the new standard on leases, was published on 13 January 2016 and will be effective for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2019. IFRS 16 will replace IAS 17 and any related IFRIC and SIC interpretations. 
 The new standard no longer applies a distinction between operating and finance leases. Accordingly, the Group will be required to recognise in its statement of financial position all of its lease obligations within the meaning of IFRS 16 in the same manner as currently required under IAS 17 for finance leases. The rights and obligations resulting from a lease contract will therefore be recognised in assets and liabilities, respectively, rather than in off-balance sheet commitments as is currently the case for operating leases. 
 The Group will apply IFRS 16 for the first time at 1 January 2019 using a simplified retrospective approach, with no restatement of comparative figures.
 The Group has a large number of leases across its entire French and international branch network. There are many different types of leases, from property leases to vehicle leases. The first-time application of IFRS 16 will therefore have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements.
 To prepare for its first-time application of the standard, the Group has been functionally assisted by an external service provider in charge of leading and coordinating the project at the level of all affected divisions (finance, operations, property). The project has involved: 

 - compiling data on leases for the France scope;  - reviewing the data compiled for the international scope;  - analysing data reliability based on a sample of different contract types; - validating the scope of application of the standard and its exclusions; 


-----

###### - calculating the Group’s incremental borrowing rates;  - quantifying the impacts;  - identifying criteria and options affecting the measurement of lease assets.
 All leases concerned by the standard have now been identified and their data analysed. In 2019, around 705 property leases in France will be accounted for in accordance with IFRS 16, including 281 contracts which are automatically renewable. This figure does not include any new leases that may begin in 2019, including those resulting from acquisitions. 
 The exemptions provided for by the standard as regards short-term leases (with a term of 12 months or less) and leases of low-value assets will not be applied. 
 The Group is currently reviewing quantified estimates of the IFRS 16 impact.

 Use of management estimates in applying the Group’s accounting standards
 The preparation of financial statements requires the Group to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets and liabilities and any disclosures provided in respect of contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. 
 Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the circumstances. 
 These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Where applicable, a sensitivity analysis may be performed if the estimates are material. Accordingly, actual results may differ from these estimates. 
 The estimates made by the Group in preparing its consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below. 
 ▪ Measurements used in testing goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment for impairment
 The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. 


-----

###### As with any estimate, the assumptions used in these calculations are partly based on uncertain factors and may therefore need to be adjusted in subsequent periods. Note 4.1.3 sets out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same note. 
 ▪ Measurement of provisions

 The Group used the best estimate of its commitments and obligations to calculate the corresponding provisions.
 ▪ Measurement of employee benefits 

 The Group operates both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. 
 Note 4.12 sets out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. The Group considers that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. 
 ▪ Measurement of fair value (Level 1)

 The Group uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure unlisted derivative instruments and cash and cash equivalents (see Notes 3.4.18 and 4.18). 

 ▪ Measurement of recognised deferred tax assets and liabilities and tax expense
 The Group’s tax position (see Notes 4.8 and 5.11) is based on its best estimate of future taxable earnings.
 ▪ Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business
 combination

 The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount. 
 ▪ Assessment of criteria for identifying discontinued operations
 In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, the Group is required to exercise judgement in determining whether an asset or group of assets meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale. IFRS 5 criteria are also used to identify any assets to be classified as discontinued operations. These assessments are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in light of changes in the relevant facts and circumstances.
 In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, the Group uses its judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements:

 ▪ present a true and fair view of the Foncia Group’s financial position, financial performance and cash flows;

 ▪ reflect the economic substance of transactions;

 ▪ are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects.
 Detailed disclosures in this regard are provided in the notes to the consolidated financial statements.

###### Basis of measurement

 3.4.1. Basis of consolidation
 The financial statements of the Group’s subsidiaries are prepared using the same accounting policies and over the same period as those of the parent company. 
 Controlled entities 
 Companies directly or indirectly controlled by the Group are fully consolidated. Control exists when the Group is exposed, or is entitled, to variable returns from its involvement with the entity in question and has the ability to affect those returns through its power over the entity. Control is analysed whenever facts and circumstances indicate that one or more of the inputs used to assess control has changed.
 A subsidiary is consolidated as from the date control is acquired, which is usually upon signature of the share transfer and disposal agreements (see “Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period” below). Consolidation ceases when control is relinquished. 
 Any interest in the subsidiary that is not directly or indirectly attributable to the Group is recognised within non-controlling interests. Profits and losses and each component of other comprehensive income relating to subsidiaries are allocated to owners of the parent and non-controlling interests, even if this results in non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. 
 Changes in the percentage interest held in subsidiaries that do not lead to a change in control are treated as equity transactions, since the transactions take place between owners acting in their capacity as owners. The impact of these transactions is shown in equity net of tax and does not therefore impact consolidated profit or loss. These transactions are also shown in the statement of cash flows under cash flows relating to investing activities.
 Investments in equity-accounted companies (associates and joint ventures) 
 Associates are entities over which the Group exercises significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling those policies.
 A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. 
 Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in the Group’s consolidated financial statements. 
 Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognised at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for the Group’s interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture. 
 IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments is applied to determine whether investments in associates or joint ventures need to be tested for impairment. Where necessary, the total carrying amount of the investment (including goodwill) is tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets. 
 Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period 
 Non-consolidated investments are classified as available-for-sale securities and mainly consist of shares in property management companies that will subsequently be consolidated.


-----

###### Before acquiring shares in a property management company, the Group agrees to acquire the shares and pays 10% of the estimated price to the seller. This part payment is included in “Downpayments on acquisitions of securities” within non-current financial assets. The remaining 90% is booked in “Off-balance sheet commitments” (see Note 9). 
 Upon signing the share transfer or disposal agreement, the Group pays an additional 70% of the estimated price to the seller. The estimated purchase price is included in equity investments, and the part payment already recognised is also reclassified to this caption. The acquired company is then consolidated. 
 Following a review of the acquired company’s financial statements, the Group pays the remaining balance and adjusts the purchase price of the shares. 
 Non-consolidated investments 
 Companies with the following characteristics are not included in the scope of consolidation:

 ▪ they are in the process of being wound up or are dormant;

 ▪ their business is not strategic for the Group.
 In accordance with IFRS 9, non-consolidated investments are carried at fair value. There are no material obligations or liabilities relating to these entities.

 3.4.2. Elimination of intragroup transactions
 All intragroup transactions and balances as well as any income, expenses, gains and losses resulting from intragroup transactions and included in the carrying amount of assets are eliminated on consolidation.
 When a Group entity carries out a transaction with a joint venture or associate, the related gains and losses are recognised in the Group’s consolidated financial statements only to the extent of the interests held by third parties in the joint venture or associate. 

 3.4.3. Foreign currency translation
 Presentation currency
 The consolidated financial statements are presented in euros, which is the Group’s presentation currency.
 Functional currency and translation of the financial statements of foreign companies
 A consolidated entity’s functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates. In most cases, the functional currency is the local currency. However, certain entities must adopt a functional currency other than their local currency when that currency represents the currency of the major transactions carried out by the entity and accurately reflects its economic environment. 
 The financial statements of foreign entities whose functional currency is different from the presentation currency of the Group’s consolidated financial statements are translated using the “closing rate” method. 
 Under this method, assets and liabilities are translated at the exchange rates prevailing at the end of the reporting period, while profit and loss and cash flow items are translated at the average exchange rate for the period. The resulting currency translation differences are recognised directly in other comprehensive income within equity under “Translation adjustments”. 
 Goodwill relating to foreign entities whose functional currency is not the euro are treated as assets acquired or liabilities assumed and therefore translated at the exchange rate prevailing at the end of the reporting period. 


-----

###### Foreign currency transactions
 Foreign currency transactions are translated into euros at the exchange rates prevailing at the transaction date or at the hedged rate. At the end of the reporting period, monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency are translated at the closing exchange rate, with the resulting gains and losses included in foreign exchange gains and losses under other financial income and expenses in the statement of profit and loss. 
 Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are measured at historical cost are translated at the exchange rate at the transaction date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are stated at fair value are translated at the exchange rate at the date on which fair value was determined.

 3.4.4. Business combinations and goodwill
 In accordance with the revised IFRS 3, business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method. According to this method, assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed that meet the recognition criteria under the revised IFRS 3 are measured at fair value.
 Goodwill is measured as the difference between the consideration transferred (purchase price plus the fair value of any previously-held interest and the value of any non-controlling interests) and the estimated fair value of the identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed. It is recorded under “Goodwill” in the statement of financial position. 
 Goodwill is calculated on a provisional basis at the time of the acquisition and is adjusted within 12 months of the acquisition date. 
 When the business combination is a bargain purchase, negative goodwill is identified. The corresponding gain is included in profit or loss in the period of the acquisition. 
 For each business combination, the Group may choose to account for non-controlling interests: 

   - either at acquisition-date fair value, resulting in the recognition of goodwill on the non-controlling interests
###### (“full goodwill” method);

   - or based on the share of net identifiable assets of the acquired entity measured at fair value, in which case
###### goodwill is only recognised on the portion attributable to owners of the parent (“partial goodwill” method).
 If the business combination is carried out in stages, the acquisition-date carrying amount of the previously-held interest in the acquired entity is remeasured to fair value at the acquisition date.  Any resulting gains or losses are taken to profit or loss.
 In the event of deferred settlements, the future amounts payable are discounted to present value at the settlement date. The discount rate used is the same as that used to estimate the value of the assets.
 Any adjustments to the potential price are estimated at acquisition-date fair value. The initial measurement may only subsequently be adjusted against goodwill if new information is obtained arising from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date and to the extent that the measurement is still provisional (maximum measurement period of 12 months). Any subsequent adjustments to the purchase price not meeting these criteria are included in liabilities or receivables, with an offsetting entry to profit or loss.
 During the 12-month measurement period, changes to the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed relating to recognised acquisitions are treated as retrospective adjustments to goodwill. After the end of the measurement period, changes to the estimated value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed are recognised in profit or loss, with no adjustment to goodwill.


-----

###### In accordance with the revised IFRS 3, costs directly attributable to the acquisition are expensed in the period in which they are incurred. The value of goodwill is reviewed each year and may also be impaired (see Note 3.4.7). 
 Earn-out payment
 The revised IFRS 3 gives certain indications as regards the accounting for contingent payment arrangements with employees or selling shareholders. These arrangements may be part of the business combination or may be considered as separate from the acquisition agreement for the target entity. In certain acquisitions, earn-out payments were considered part of the consideration for post-acquisition services rendered and are therefore expensed in the periods concerned and in future periods.

 3.4.5. Intangible assets
 Intangible assets are identifiable non-monetary assets with no physical substance. 
 In accordance with IAS 38, intangible assets that are acquired separately are initially measured at cost when the future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. 
 Intangible assets acquired as part of a business combination are carried at fair value separately from goodwill. 
 Intangible assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Intangible assets with a finite useful life (software and licences) are amortised on a straight-line basis over their expected useful lives: 

   - Client relationships: 18-21 years

   - Software programs: 1-10 years

   - Other intangible assets: 5 years

###### Intangible assets with an indefinite useful life are not amortised. They are included with other assets within cash-generating units (CGUs) and tested for impairment using the discounted cash flow method at least once a year and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. 
 When the recoverable amount of these assets calculated based on criteria prevailing at the acquisition date falls below their carrying amount, an impairment provision is recorded. 

 Trademarks
 Identifiable trademarks are measured using a multi-criteria approach which takes into consideration both their reputation and profitability. 
 The Group classified its main “Foncia” trademark along with the “Trévi” trademark in Belgium and the “Domicim” and “Brolliet” trademarks in Switzerland as indefinite-lived intangible assets. 

 Business software programs
 Software acquired is carried at cost (purchase price plus ancillary expenses). When allocating the purchase price, certain software programs may also be measured using the replacement cost approach.

 Business goodwill and client relationships
 Client relationships include the list of mandates held by the Group’s companies. A mandate is an instrument by which a person (the principal) gives another person (the agent) the power of proxy. France’s Hoguet Law requires


-----

###### professional property agents to hold a written mandate in order to put properties up for sale or let, and to manage property.
 Client relationships are measured based on the excess earnings method.

 Other intangible assets
 Other intangible assets mainly comprise the cost of acquiring new business.

 3.4.6. Property, plant and equipment
 Property, plant and equipment are measured at their historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses.
 The cost of an item of property, plant and equipment comprises its purchase price, including customs duties and non-recoverable taxes, and any costs directly incurred to bring the asset to working condition for its intended use. Any trade discounts and rebates are deducted from the purchase price. Subsequent expenditure is recognised in expenses, unless it improves the asset’s initial performance, prolongs its useful life, or reduces the operating costs previously determined.
 Depreciation is recognised on a straight-line basis over the assets’ estimated useful lives. In accordance with IAS 16, property, plant and equipment are recognised using the component approach, with each component depreciated separately over its useful life: 

   - Buildings: 20-50 years

   - Fixtures and fittings: 8-10 years

   - IT equipment: 4 years

   - Vehicle fleet: 5 years

   - Furniture: 10 years

   - Office equipment: 4 years

###### Useful lives are reviewed each year and may be adjusted if expectations differ from previous estimates.
 Gains and losses on asset disposals are calculated as the difference between the sale proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset concerned.

 3.4.7. Impairment losses on goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment
 The carrying amounts of non-current non-financial assets are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in order to identify any potential impairment: 

   - goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for impairment at least annually and
###### whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired;

   - all other assets are tested for impairment whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired.

###### External indicators of impairment include changes in the general economic and financial environment, downtrends in local economic environments and changes in economic performance. These are analysed by the Group to determine whether the assets concerned should be tested for impairment more frequently. 

 For impairment testing purposes, goodwill is allocated to cash-generating units (CGUs ) or groups of CGUs expected to benefit from the synergies arising on the business combination.  The Group decides whether or not to recognise an impairment loss by comparing the carrying amount of the assets and liabilities in a CGU or group of CGUs with their recoverable amount. A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets for internal management purposes. 


-----

###### The Group has identified the following three CGUs corresponding to its major development and investment strategies:

   - Property management companies – France

   - Property management companies – International

   - Other activities (service companies and other entities)

###### The recoverable amount of a CGU is the higher of its fair value (generally market price) less costs to sell and its value in use. 
 Fair value less costs to sell is calculated based on available information used to establish the best estimate of the selling price net of costs to sell in an arm’s length transaction between fully informed, willing parties. 
 Value in use as calculated by the Group generally corresponds to the present value of the future cash flows attributable to a CGU or group of CGUs, taking into account their residual value and based on the most probable assumptions adopted by management. 
 The assumptions used are based on the budgets and business plans prepared by management for each business. These budgets are the latest budgets approved by the Supervisory Board at the date of preparation of the financial statements. Other assumptions affecting the calculation of the recoverable amount include the growth rate, operating margin, the discount rate and the tax rate (see Note 4.1).
 The discount rate used to discount post-tax cash flows to their present value reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset or CGU. Where there is no specific discount rate for the assets tested, the average cost of capital is used. The discount rates are post-tax rates and are applied to post-tax cash flows. The recoverable amount calculated using post-tax discount rates is equal to that which would have been obtained using pre-tax rates applied to pre-tax cash flows, as required by IAS 36. 
 If the carrying amount of the CGU exceeds its recoverable amount, the related assets are written down to the recoverable amount. The impairment loss is first allocated to goodwill and then to the carrying amount of the other assets of the CGU, in proportion to their carrying amount. This must not result in the carrying amount of an individual asset falling below the higher of its fair value, value in use and zero. Impairment losses are recognised in other operating expenses and may not be reversed. 

 3.4.8. Financial assets
 The measurement and recognition of financial assets and liabilities is defined by the new IFRS 9 – Financial instruments.
 Unlike IAS 39, IFRS 9 applies a single analytical framework to all financial assets in order to determine the classification and basis of measurement to be used for accounting purposes. The four IAS 39 categories have been replaced by three categories, each associated with a specific measurement approach.
 More specifically: 

 ✓ Debt instruments held in a business model whose objective is to collect contractual cash flows that are solely
 payments of principal and interest (SPPI) on the principal amount outstanding, are generally carried at amortised cost. 
 ✓ Debt instruments held in a business model whose objective is achieved by both collecting contractual cash
 flows (whose contractual conditions give rise to cash flows that are solely payments of principal and interest [SPPI] on the principal amount outstanding) and selling financial assets, are typically carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. 
 ✓ All other debt and equity instruments are carried at fair value through profit or loss.

###### Operating leases
 Payments made under operating leases are expensed in profit or loss on a straight-line basis over the lease term. Rental income is included in income on a straight-line basis.

 Finance leases
 The Group acquires certain property, plant and equipment used in its operations under finance leases. These assets are recognised in assets in the consolidated statement of financial position.
 In accordance with IAS 17, assets acquired under finance leases are recognised as assets at the lower of their fair value and the present value of the minimum lease payments, with a matching entry to liabilities for the equivalent value of the assets. The Group subsequently applies the cost model rather than the remeasurement approach, in accordance with IAS 16 and IAS 38.
 Payments under finance leases recognised in the annual financial statements are restated to reflect the gradual reduction in the liability and the fixed or floating-rate interest intrinsic to the lease. Assets acquired under finance leases are depreciated over the same periods as assets of a similar nature that are acquired directly.

 3.4.10. Cash and cash equivalents
 The amount shown in cash and cash equivalents in the statement of financial position includes cash at bank and cash equivalents (short-term highly liquid investments that are readily convertible into a known amount of cash and subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value). 
 Short-term investments are remeasured at market value at the end of each reporting period. 
 Investments in listed equities, investments with an initial maturity of over three months and no early exit option and restricted (i.e., blocked) bank accounts are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and classified as current or non-current financial assets. 
 Short-term bank overdrafts are classified as borrowings within current liabilities in the statement of financial position


-----

###### For the purposes of the consolidated statement of cash flows, net cash and cash equivalents include the items defined above, net of short-term bank overdrafts. 

 3.4.11. Client accounts 
 Under their mandates, property management companies hold client funds consisting of guarantee deposits received, rent and expenses, joint ownership working capital and renovation funds, and funds received in connection with the Transactions business. As an agent, the Group undertakes to hold client accounts and to recognise them for each activity (transactions, rentals and management).

 3.4.12. Recognition and measurement of financial liabilities
 Borrowings are initially measured at the fair value of the amount received, net of directly attributable transaction costs. 

 Borrowings
 After initial recognition, borrowings are measured at amortised cost using the effective interest method. The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts estimated future cash payments to the net carrying amount of the financial liability in order to determine its amortised cost.

 Other financial liabilities
 Trade and other payables are carried at amortised cost.

 3.4.13. Derivative instruments
 The Group uses derivative instruments to hedge interest rate risks on floating-rate borrowings and foreign exchange risks. 
 In accordance with IFRS, hedge accounting may be applied to a hedging transaction provided that:

   - the hedge is documented (entity’s objectives, hedging strategy, identification of the components of the
###### hedging relationship, etc.);

   - the hedge is highly effective in offsetting changes in fair value or cash flows attributable to the hedged risk. A
###### hedge is highly effective if it meets all of the following hedge effectiveness criteria:

 - there is an economic relationship between the hedged item and the hedging instrument,

 - the credit risk is not of a magnitude that it dominates the value changes that result from the economic relationship,

 - the hedge ratio is the same as that resulting from the quantity of the hedged item that the Group actually hedges and the quantity of the hedging instrument that the Group actually uses to hedge that quantity of hedged item;

   - effectiveness can be measured reliably and is calculated in the context of continuing operations.

###### For the periods presented, no interest rate or foreign currency derivatives used by the Group are classified as hedging instruments. 

 In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, derivative instruments are measured on the statement of financial position at fair value. Changes in the fair value of instruments not eligible for hedge accounting are recognised in profit or loss under other financial income and expenses.

###### 3.4.14. Current and non-current provisions
 A provision is recognised when, at the end of the reporting period, the Group has a legal or constructive obligation to a third party resulting from a past event that is likely to give rise to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits and can be measured reliably.
 When the Group expects partial or full repayment of the provision, for example owing to an insurance policy, the repayment is booked as a separate asset but only if such repayment is virtually certain. 
 Since provisions are estimated based on assumptions regarding future contingencies and expenses, the amount thereof is based partly on uncertain factors and may be adjusted in future periods. The impact of discounting is taken into account only if it is material.
 Items giving rise to provisions (trade and labour disputes, etc.) are reviewed regularly to allow for any adjustments. The amount accrued in provisions represents the Group’s best estimate of the net outflow of resources.
 Provisions may also be recognised for contingent liabilities arising on business combinations. In this case, they are initially recognised at fair value at the acquisition date. At the end of subsequent reporting periods, they are measured at the higher of the amount recognized in accordance with IAS 37 and the amount recorded on initial recognition, less any cumulative income recognised in accordance with IFRS 15.
 Employee-related provisions (labour disputes, lay-offs, etc.)
 At the end of each reporting period, a provision is recognised and adjusted in line with the risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Human Resources department on a case-by-case basis.
 Provisions for rent payment guarantees
 A rent payment guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. Foncia bears the cost of any unpaid rent and advances to owners. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery. Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts (deriving from the del credere agreement) and are accounted for as follows:

   - the related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are deducted
###### from rents in the same way as basic fees;

   - once rent is reported as unpaid, a provision is recorded, calculated in accordance with IAS 37.

###### The Group has set up a provision for risks relating to rent payment guarantees based on a progressive provisioning rate that increases in line with the age of the debt. 
 Provision for occupancy guarantees
 An occupancy guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. 
 Provision for URSSAF social security audits
 A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the related risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Payroll department on a case-by-case basis.


-----

###### Provisions for risks on client accounts
 A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the risk exposure on customer accounts (debit accounts, etc.), as assessed by the Group’s Customer Operations department on a case-by-case basis.
 Provisions for third party and professional liability
 These provisions are recorded based on information provided by senior managers in charge of monitoring claims against the Group. The Audit, Legal and Accounting departments have the final decision in terms of whether or not to record a provision.
 Provisions for other disputes
 These provisions are intended to cover disputes, litigation and other foreseeable contingencies in connection with the Group’s businesses, along with miscellaneous contingencies and expenses.
 Update on the UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) dispute 
 On 1 October 2014, UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) brought proceedings against Foncia Groupe before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance (regional court) seeking damages for losses allegedly suffered by lessees of Foncia-managed properties who were unduly charged for receiving notices to pay (avis d’échéance).
 More specifically, UFC is seeking payment from Foncia Groupe of an amount of €2.30 per month and per lessee over a period of five years and estimates the number of lessees concerned at 318,400, bringing the total damages to €44 million. 
 In its defence, the Group argues that the French law of 6 July 1989 on residential lease agreements, upon the basis of which UFC filed its claim, made no provision for class actions at the time of the alleged offence; that no law existed preventing the company from charging lessees for receiving notices to pay; and that this was therefore a lawful practice. 
 Oral arguments were exchanged before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance in March 2018. The decision handed down in May 2018 dismissed UFC’s claims on the grounds that they fell outside the scope of a class action. UFC has appealed this decision and the case is pending hearings before the Court of Appeal. 

 The Group considers that no provision needs to be accrued in this respect in its financial statements at 31 December 2018. 
 Update on the dispute with franchisees 
 Certain franchisees brought proceedings against Foncia after having been notified that their contracts would not be renewed. They accuse the Group of wrongful termination and various breaches of the franchise agreements. Of the 19 initial lawsuits in 2014, Foncia either settled (most sensitive disputes), or won (before the lower court or on appeal) the cases. Only eight franchisees took their case to the Cour de Cassation (supreme court), which partially struck down the appeal rulings that had found in favour of Foncia. 
 The eight cases therefore face a retrial before a court of appeal to which the case has been referred. The decisions are expected in early 2020.

 At 31 December 2018, the provision set aside in respect of these disputes represented €1.1 million.

###### 3.4.15. Provisions for employee benefits

 Share-based payment
 As indicated in the “Highlights of the period” section, a free share plan was set up by Foncia Stark on 23 May 2018. The main characteristics of the plan along with the accounting treatment applied are explained in Note 2.4. 
 There are no stock option or free share plans in place at Foncia Management.

 Pensions and other post-employment benefits
 Short-term benefits 
 Short-term benefits (wages and salaries, payroll taxes, paid leave, etc.) are expensed in the period in which the corresponding services are provided by the employee. Any amounts not paid at the end of the reporting period are carried in current liabilities.
 Post-employment benefits 
 In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which the Group operates, Foncia participates in, or operates, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of the Group’s employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by the Foncia Group to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds funded in accordance with the applicable obligations and government regulations.

   - Defined contribution plans

###### Defined contribution plans and multi-employer plans are expensed as incurred in the statement of profit and loss.

   - Defined benefit plans

###### Defined benefit plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds. Pension obligations and expenses are calculated by independent actuaries using the projected unit credit method.
 This method is based on assumptions that are reviewed on a yearly basis, including the probability that the employee will remain in the Group until retirement, expected future salary trends, life expectancy and an appropriate discount rate for each of the countries in which the Group operates a pension plan. 
 The assumptions used in respect of 2018 are detailed in Note 4.12. 
 A provision is recognised in the statement of financial position for the difference between the related projected benefit obligation (actuarial liability) and any plan assets as measured at fair value, and includes past service costs and actuarial gains and losses.
 Expenses under defined benefit plans comprise three components, accounted for as described below:

 - Service cost is recognised in personnel costs. It includes service cost for the period, past service cost resulting from plan amendments or curtailments, which are recognised in full in profit or loss for the period in which they arose, and gains and losses arising on plan settlements.

 - Interest cost is recognised in other financial income and expenses and reflects the impact of discounting the obligations, net of the expected return on plan assets as measured using the discount rate applied to calculate those obligations.


-----

###### - Gains and losses on remeasuring the benefit obligation (plan asset) are recognised in other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss, and essentially comprise actuarial gains and losses, i.e., changes in the benefit obligation and in plan assets attributable to changes in assumptions and experience adjustments. Experience adjustments represent the difference between the expected impact of certain actuarial assumptions applied to previous measurements of the obligation and actual experience.
 If plan assets exceed the benefit obligation, a financial asset is recorded up to the amount of the present value of future refunds from the plan or reductions in future contributions to the plan.
 Other benefits: long-service awards
 In France, the collective bargaining agreement for the real estate industry stipulates that all active employees who so request are entitled to one month’s salary at every anniversary date: after 20, 30, 35 and 40 years of professional experience. Professional experience is considered overall and not as experience solely within the Group. However, the Group is only liable for the amount proportionate to the employee’s seniority in the Group.
 The Group’s obligation under long-service awards is assessed each year by an independent expert. 
 The assumptions used in respect of 2018 are detailed in Note 4.12. 

 3.4.16. Income tax
 Income tax for the period includes current and deferred taxes. Current and deferred taxes are recognised in the statement of profit and loss, except when they relate to items recognised in other comprehensive income. 
 The Group calculates its current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which its earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where the Group’s subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities.
 Deferred tax is recognised using the liability method on: 

   - all temporary differences between the tax base and the carrying amount of assets and liabilities, excluding
###### goodwill; 

   - tax loss carryforwards.

###### Deferred tax is calculated based on the tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date and are expected to apply when the deferred tax asset is realised or the deferred tax liability settled.
 Deferred tax assets arising on temporary differences or on tax losses and tax credits carried forward are only recognised to the extent it is probable that they will reverse and that the Group will generate future taxable profit against which they can be utilised.
 The following are taken into account when assessing the Group’s ability to recover these assets: 

   - forecasts of future taxable earnings;

   - taxable earnings in previous years.

###### Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when the entity has a right to set off a current tax asset against a current tax liability and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same tax authority on the same tax entity or on different tax entities when there is an intention to settle the amounts on a net basis.


-----

###### In accordance with the CNC (Conseil National de la Comptabilité – former French accounting standards-setter) position statement published on 14 January 2010, the Group has used its judgement in determining how to treat the CVAE (Cotisation sur la Valeur Ajoutée) tax assessed on value added in France. The Group considers that since the base for the CVAE tax is the difference between income and expenses, the tax falls within the scope of IAS 12. Accordingly, the CVAE tax is included under “Income tax benefit (expense)”.

 3.4.17. Current liabilities
 Current liabilities are liabilities to be settled or renegotiated within the ordinary operating cycle or within 12 months following the end of the reporting period.
 Due to their short-term nature, the carrying amounts shown in the consolidated financial statements are reasonable estimates of their market value. The value of items that will be paid over the long term is discounted.

 3.4.18. Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities at fair value
 The fair value of all financial assets and liabilities is determined at the end of the reporting period, either for accounting purposes or for disclosure in the notes. 
 Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. 
 IFRS 13 sets out a three-level hierarchy for determining fair value:

   - Level 1: quoted (unadjusted) prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.

   - Level 2: inputs other than quoted market prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or
###### liability, either directly (i.e., prices) or indirectly (i.e., price-based inputs).

   - Level 3: inputs relating to the asset or liability which are not based on observable market data (unobservable
###### inputs).

 The Group primarily uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure derivative instruments, cash and cash equivalents, available-for-sale financial assets, cash management financial assets and identifiable assets and liabilities acquired as part of a business combination. 
 The fair values of financial assets and liabilities are disclosed in Note 4.18. 

 3.4.19. Assets classified as held for sale and discontinued operations
 IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations sets forth the accounting requirements applicable to assets held for sale, along with the presentation and disclosure requirements for discontinued operations.
 A non-current asset or disposal group is held for sale when its carrying amount will be recovered principally through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use. For this to be the case, the asset (or disposal group) must be available for immediate sale in its present condition and the sale must be highly probable. 
 The assets and liabilities concerned are reclassified in assets held for sale and liabilities related to assets held for sale, and no offsetting is permitted. Assets reclassified in this category are carried at the lower of their fair value less costs to sell and their carrying amount, i.e., at cost less accumulated depreciation/amortisation and impairment losses, and are no longer depreciated/amortised.
 A discontinued operation is defined as a component of an entity that represents a separate major line of business and meets the criteria for classification as an asset held for sale or has been sold by the Group.


-----

###### Discontinued operations are presented on a separate line in the statement of profit and loss for the periods presented, which shows post-tax profit or loss attributable to discontinued operations and the post-tax gain or loss on the disposal or the measurement to fair value less costs to sell of the assets or disposal groups comprising the discontinued operation.
 Similarly, cash flows attributable to discontinued operations are presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of cash flows for the periods presented.
 A discontinued operation can also be defined as a component of an entity that either has been disposed of or is classified as held for sale and:
 ▪ represents a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; 

 ▪ is part of a single coordinated plan to dispose of a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; or

 ▪ is a subsidiary acquired exclusively with a view to resale.

 3.4.20. Presentation of the statement of profit and loss
 As allowed under IAS 1 – Presentation of Financial Statements, the Group has chosen to present operating expenses by nature.
 “Recurring operating profit (loss)”, “Operating profit (loss)”, “Cost of gross debt” and “Cost of net debt” in the statement of profit and loss and gains and losses recognised directly in equity are presented in accordance with the criteria set out in ANC Recommendation No. 2013-03 issued by the French accounting standards-setter (Autorité des Normes Comptables).

 3.4.21. Revenue
 Revenue corresponds to proceeds from sales of goods and services within the scope of the ordinary operations of fully consolidated companies. 
 All revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes. 
 In accordance with the new IFRS 15, the Group recognises revenue when the amount of revenue can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to the entity, and specific criteria are met by each of the Group’s businesses.
 Negotiation fees and commission (sales and rentals) are recognised in revenue when they are received or effectively due at the end of the reporting period. Interest income arising on client funds is also booked in revenue.

 3.4.22. Recurring operating profit (loss)
 Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses)”.
 Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss) restated for any non-recurring items. Costs relating to business combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss).

 3.4.23. Non-recurring operating income (expenses)
 Non-recurring operating income and expenses are recorded if a major event occurs during the reporting period that could distort the interpretation of the entity’s performance. Non-recurring items are limited, unusual and/or irregular items of a material amount and are detailed in Note 5 8


-----

###### 3.4.24. Operating profit (loss)
 Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions.

 3.4.25. Cost of net debt
 The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less financial income from cash investments.

 3.4.26. Earnings (loss) per share
 Earnings (loss) per share corresponds to profit (loss) attributable to holders of ordinary shares divided by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the reporting period (excluding treasury shares).

 3.4.27. Segment reporting
 The Group is not concerned by IFRS 8 – Operating Segments. Revenue is broken down by business in Note 5.1.

###### The holding company’s residual economic assets following the asset allocation shown above were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU to reflect the cost allocation of the holding company used to draw up the business plans.
 Calculation of the recoverable amount of the CGUs at 30 November 2018
 In accordance with the Group’s impairment testing approach (see Note 3.4.7), and in the absence of observable fair values in an organised market, the recoverable amount of CGUs corresponds to their value in use, which is defined as the sum of their net cash flows based on the latest forecasts for each CGU, determined using:

 ▪ a business plan prepared by management based on growth and profitability assumptions, taking into account past performance, forecast changes in the economic environment, and expected market trends;
 ▪ a terminal value calculated by capitalising normative cash flows obtained by extrapolating cash flows from the final year of the business plan, with a stable growth rate or a growth rate increasing steadily over the long term;
 ▪ expected cash flows discounted at a rate determined by reference to the weighted average cost of capital (WACC).
 The forecasts used in the impairment tests carried out at 30 November 2018 are taken from the consolidated “Low Case” business plans prepared by management in March 2018 covering a specified period of three years. These business plans were validated by the Board in March 2018 and presented to the Statutory Auditors in June of that year. The forecasts used were extrapolated through to 2022, to ensure that revenue, depreciation and amortisation approached normative levels.
 It should be noted that all holding company expenses not allocated in the consolidated business plan were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU. Corporate functions are managed at individual country-level for the Property Management International CGU and are considered not material for the Services CGU. 
 The discount rate used is the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), calculated based on a sample of six comparable European companies. A WACC was estimated for each foreign country based on their tax rates and the yield on their sovereign bonds. A WACC was then calculated for the entire Foncia Group based on a weighting of each country’s contribution to total EBITDA. On this basis, a single weighted discount rate of 7.4% was used for all of the Group’s CGUs.

 A long-term growth rate of 1.8% was used for the tests. This rate was estimated using information provided by public databases such as the IMF and EIU (Economic Intelligence Unit).

###### Trademarks 

 At the date on which Foncia Management acquired a controlling interest in Foncia Holding (September 2016), the Foncia Group and Domicim trademarks were recognised at an amount of €414.2 million based on their valuations. The Group also estimated the value of the Brolliet trademark at CHF €13.7 million (i.e., €12.1 million at 31 December 2018). 
 Concessions, patents and software 

 Concessions, patents and software include the systems measured within the scope of Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting at €16.2 million. Investments in the period amounting to €2.7 million mainly concern Foncia Groupe for €1.6 million. 

 Other changes amounting to €17 million chiefly concern the capitalisation of intangible assets in progress for €13.8 million, along with a €2.4 million adjustment to amortisation charged against software included in Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting. 
 Business goodwill/client relationships 

 At the time of Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting, the fair value of the Foncia Group’s client relationships was estimated at €460.8 million, breaking down between the Group’s three CGUs as follows: (i) Property Management France (excluding the Transactions business): €396.2 million, (ii) Property Management International (Germany, Switzerland, Belgium): €2.2 million, and (iii) Services: €62.5m.

 Following the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Brolliet group in September 2016, client relationships were valued at CHF 7.5 million (€6.6 million at 31 December 2018).

 Investments totalling €5.6 million primarily relate to acquisitions of business goodwill over the period. 

 Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €7 million reflect Primonial’s contribution of its entire stand-alone division as part of the business combination with Leemo (see Note 2.3 of “Highlights of the period”). 
 Other intangible assets 

 Other intangible assets essentially comprise the cost of acquiring new business. The €3.8 million increase in this item in the period reflects the capitalisation of the costs of acquiring new mandates, rebilled to other firms in the network.

###### At 31 December 2018, deferred tax assets recognised in respect of tax loss carryforwards chiefly concern tax consolidation arrangements (€6.9 million), tax losses reported by companies in the tax consolidation group (€1.9 million) and Efficity (€2.8 million). 
 The impact of the first-time application of IFRS 15 is an adjustment to the equity of the companies concerned totalling €31.1 million. However, this impact was deducted for tax purposes through an off-book deduction of the same amount (the amount had already been subject to tax in 2017). In the consolidated financial statements, the tax saving resulting from the first-time application of IFRS 15 was allocated to total equity in accordance with the simplified retrospective approach. 
 Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €4 million on other adjustments concern deferred taxes arising on the neutralisation of business goodwill existing before the companies concerned were consolidated.

###### On 3 August 2018, the Group repaid ahead of term its ICA loan in an amount of €77 million (see Note 2.5 of “Highlights of the period”). This repayment was financed by subscribing to a new €80 million tranche (“B4”) of its senior facility. The issuance fees for the new tranche amount to €1.2 million and will be recognised over the term of the facility by an adjustment to financial expenses at the effective interest rate as calculated at 3 August 2018 (3.68%).

 The initial accounting treatment was discontinued, with all related unamortised expenses allocated to the ICA loan (€4 million) charged to profit or loss under “Cost of net debt” (see Note 5.9). 
 Since 15 March 2018, the Group has continuously drawn on its revolving credit facility as part-financing for its external growth investments (acquisitions). The Group also draws on its €30 million authorised overdraft facility when necessary. 
 Liabilities relating to the put option granted to Trévi non-controlling shareholders (on 8% of the shares) and to the non-controlling shareholders of the Initiatives group and partners (on 55% of the shares) were remeasured based on actual 2018 figures against equity. Following the acquisition of an additional 25% stake in Somhome in March 2018, the €0.6 million liability relating to the put option granted to non-controlling interests was reversed against total equity.

###### Provisions for occupancy guarantees are calculated on a statistical basis. This enables the Group to determine the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The maximum term of claims is 180 days. 
 The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent.
 Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated).
 Provisions for labour disputes concerned 108 lawsuits compared to 117 lawsuits at 31 December 2017. Out of the 108 lawsuits, 32 relate to amounts in excess of €100,000. In all, the claims represent approximately €10 million. The resolution of labour disputes in the period resulted in expenses of €1.1 million and a writeback of €1.9 million from the provision.

###### In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, which set out the rules for measuring and recognising financial instruments, instruments with a positive fair value are recognised in assets and those with a negative fair value are recognised in liabilities. Fair values of financial instruments are provided by the financial institutions with which the transactions are carried out.

 4.17.1. Interest rate derivatives 
 Further to its refinancing on 7 September 2016, the Group entered into an interest rate cap agreement on 7 December 2016 under the terms and conditions set out below: 

 • Notional amount: €527.9 million 
 • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor 
 • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1% 
 • Hedging period: 7 December 2016 to 6 December 2019
 On 19 October 2017, the Group also entered into an additional deferred interest rate cap agreement under the following terms and conditions: 

 • Notional amount: €400 million 
 • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor 
 • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1.5% 
 • Hedging period: 7 December 2019 to 6 December 2020 
 The premiums paid in respect of these cap agreements totalled €915,000.

 4.17.2. Foreign exchange derivatives
 To hedge some of the foreign exchange risk on the loan granted to its subsidiary Foncia Suisse, the Group had entered into hedging contracts through to end-December 2019. Further to the amendment to the loan agreement acknowledging the absence of any repayment date and the adoption of net investment hedge accounting as from 29 June 2018, the Group unwound all of its hedging positions.
 This transaction, which had no impact on profit or loss, led to a cash inflow of €787,000, recorded in the consolidated statement of cash flows under other cash flows from (used in) financing activities.
 At 31 December 2018, the Group no longer had any financial instruments hedging its foreign exchange risk.
