###### It should be recalled that following the acquisition of Foncia Holding by Foncia Management on 7 September 2016, a new tax group was formed, effective as of 1 January 2017. The new group opted for a tax loss carry-forward system along the lines of the former tax consolidation group, but with a broader scope. 
 In 2018, the tax consolidation group benefited from an off-book deduction of €29.9 million in respect of the IFRS 15 impact, recognised in equity in the individual financial statements. This amount had already been subject to tax in 2017. Based on the allocation by the holding company of deductible financial expenses and the deduction of the share of acquisition fees of Foncia Holding securities in an amount of €5.4 million, an additional tax loss of €5.6 million was generated in 2018.
 Within the tax consolidation group, tax loss carry-forwards at 31 December 2018 are as follows:

 • Loss arising on tax consolidation: €23.8 million (after a tax loss of €5.6 million generated in respect of 2018). This tax loss has been recognised in full in view of the high probability that sufficient future taxable profit will exist against which it can be utilised. 

 • Proprietary tax losses of consolidated companies: €25.4 million, of which €18.6 million were not recognised, mainly relating to Foncia Holding (€8.9 million), IDHA (€4.8 million) and Foncia Développement (€2.8 million).

 NOTE 8. FINANCIAL RISK EXPOSURE

 8.1.1. Interest rate risk
 The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralised basis. They are mainly indexed to 3-month Euribor. The risk management policy is set by management. 
 Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for the Group’s companies are centralised under a cash pooling agreement and managed by the Group’s Treasury department. 
 The Group’s Treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritises liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month Euribor or is at fixed rates (term accounts).
 At 31 December 2018, interest rate risks can be broken down by management outlook as follows, taking into account interest rate maturities applied to the asset/liability financing position:

 Credit risk € thousands Client accounts 557,899

 - Credit line (1,513,760) + Interest rate cap 527,850

 A sudden 1% increase in short-term interest rates applied to the net position of assets and liabilities affected by interest rate fluctuations at the end of the reporting period would result in a rise of €6,167,000 in financial expenses.

 In 2018, the Group still has hedges in place for its credit facilities with an underlying valued at €527,850,000. The cap in place fixes the maximum 3-month Euribor rate at 1%.

###### 8.1.2. Foreign exchange risk
 The Group is exposed to two types of foreign exchange risk:

   - A foreign exchange risk on assets resulting from the Foncia Group’s shareholdings in its Swiss subsidiaries.
###### Although this risk is measured, it is not subject to specific risk management as the investments are intended to be held over the long term. 

 At 31 December 2018, the Group’s foreign currency positions were as follows:

 CHF thousands Assets 327,831 Liabilities 212,001 Net position before hedging 115,830 Forex hedging 0 Net position after hedging 115,830 Currency value 0.8854 Net position after hedging (equivalent value in € thousands) 102,556

 Accordingly, the Group’s foreign exchange risk exposure on assets is not material. 

   - A foreign exchange trading risk arising on commercial and financial transactions carried out by the Group’s
###### companies in currencies other than their local currency. 

 This risk arises solely on the business of Swiss subsidiaries and concerns the Swiss franc. Since the vast majority of local transactions are carried out in Swiss francs, this risk is not material. 
 It should be noted that currency options had been set up through to December 2019 to guarantee the CHF/EUR exchange rate with respect to the loans granted by Foncia Groupe to its subsidiary Foncia Suisse. On 29 June 2018, Foncia Groupe unwound its entire CHF 13.7 million forex hedge, generating proceeds of €787,000. 
 Foncia in fact signed an amendment to the loan agreement between Foncia Groupe and Foncia Suisse on 29 June 2018, eliminating all repayment clauses. Given that no repayments have been made and that no repayment plan has been set for the foreseeable future, this loan is considered as a monetary item and as part of the net investment in Foncia Suisse as quasi-equity, in accordance with IAS 21 – The Effects of Changes in Foreign Exchange Rates. As from this date, foreign exchange gains and losses arising on the loan will be taken to other comprehensive income under translation reserves.

 In accordance with this law, Foncia provides financial guarantees to clients equal to the maximum amount of funds held on their account. These guarantees are presented under commitments given.

 Commitments given on the acquisition of equity investments correspond to amounts due to the sellers of the companies or business goodwill acquired, the ownership of which had not yet been transferred to the Group at the end of the reporting period.
